articleText:
Beaudesert Observance

' THOSE who fell in two World Wars were honoured at Beaudesert yesterday, wlicn commemoration services were held to celebrate Anzac Day. Proceedings commenced with a Dawn Parade at the monument, and after services at the churches there was a march, followed by a

ceremony at ,the monument, during which wreaths were laid, on the

stone in mercury of the fallen. The Beaudesert Branch of the Q.C.W.A. entertained a large number of ex-servicemen, and women, and others to a luncheon at - the

Technical Hau. There was an attendance of some 50 people, including a number of women at the Dawn Parade. At a given time, Mr. J. Piatt, who was Company Sergt. Major in the V.D.C., called the gathering to order, and It ' formed two ranks facing the monument. The speaker was Mr. A. L. Lane, who said that throughout the year people passing the memorial should let their thoughts wander, to those men who had given their lives, that others might be . free. ' He recalled the sacrifices made, and thanked those mothers and wives whose sons and husbands had paid the supreme sacrifice for their country. It was a touching ceremony, the quietly spoken words falling on a stilled air. On behalf of Vthe Beaudesert Sub- Branch of the R:S.S.A.I.L.A., Mr. Colin Kassulke (vice) president) placed a poppy wreath orvthe monument. After the sounding of the Last Post by Bugler W. Franklin the gathering dispersed. - Church services were well attended, and speakers made appropriate ad dresses. ; Close on a hundred returned men, members of the Buffs Lodge and citi zens marched behind the Town Band, under the direction of Mr. H. Dauth, from the Railway. Station gates to the monument. A large number of people lined the street, and there : was a big gathering at the monument. The Band provided music, supported by a choir comprised of members of the Lutheran and Methodist Church choirs.

x uuuwuig uic mtttiuutii niiidicm, xvev. J. J. Wilson led the gathering in pray er, and Rev. J. Lee Warner gave a Bible Reading. .-V Afterjthe'hyntn "O God ,- Our Help-In i Agi's Past," Mr. A. 'apMuller 1 "TSilivA-i/ moved the forpfal .-solutions, which were being presented to gatherings throughout Australia. They are: (1) On the thirty-first anniversary of the immortal landing at Gallipoli, this Meeting of Citizens of Queensland expresses its loyalty and devotion to the Throne and person of His Majesty King George VI., and to the British Com monwealth of Nations. (2) This meeting (i.) re-affirms its admiration of the magnificent heroism, self-sacrifice and endurance of the Sailors, Soldiers, Airmen and Nursing Sisters of Australia and New Zealand who, on the first Anzac Day and throughout the Great War of 1914-1918, conferred a glory on Australia and New Zealand that will never fade, (ii.) Avers that the lofty ideals of service of the Anzacs pervaded the dauntless spirit of Australia's gallant sons and daughters, who, during a period of six years of fierce and intensive warfare, on land, on sea, and in the air, from 1939 to 1945, gave such heroic and self-sacrific ing service in the cause of Liberty, (iii.) Voices its heartfelt sympathy with the relatives of those who paid, during the War, the supreme sacrifice, and with those who have suffered on behalf of the Empire. (3) This meeting gives its assurance that those who have fallen shall be held in sacred memory, and that those who have survived the perils of War will ever be honoured and remembered with gratitude by the people whose hearths and homes they went forth to save so that our Freedom and our free institutions under the British Common wealth of Nations might survive. Mr. Muller said that they owed a debt of gratitude lo those men who had offered their lives for their country. Seconding the resolutions, Capt, G. Abbott called on the gathering to re member God at all times, and not to cast Him aside now that peace had come to Australia. He tributed those men who had put their country first, and mentioned the great work of the womenfolk who had been ever active behind the scenes. .Capt. Abbott added: " We have come to Anzac Day again with very much upon our minds and hearts, of whal has taken place in the last Great War of 1914 to 1918, and the War that has just passed. This day is in memory of the first Anzacs, which consists of the Australian and New Zealand men who fought in Gallipoli in 1915, and also the men of 1939 to 1945. "The bravery of our men was of an outstanding character. They spared nothihg to save their country and to bring about freedom for us all to en joy. "We also must not forget that our gallant women engaged in every source of work. These women of our Empire, helped on all fronts to relieve the suf fering of the men. Many lost their lives; yet they were heroes of a very deep character in word and in deed. "In turning to our Bibles we find in Psalm 71, the testimony of David, how he found God to be his guide during his trials and difficulties. We find David gave all his credit and success to God. God was the key and centre theme of his life. We in return should do like wise, but we are prone to take all our success to ourselves, and God in many ways takes second place and we as a vast Empire owe a lot to God for our success and guidance. "The children of Israel were guided by the Almighty hand of God; their victories were not of self glorification, but of the Glory of God. They were brought through the Red Sea by God's hand, helping Moses. We see again they were heroes because God was with them and God is with us If we are willing for Him to guide and help us. "Our men and women we can txuely call heroes to the very letter, but' yet nothing could have been done If God had not been with them and been at the helm of the battles. (CONTINUED ON PAGE SEVEN)

HEROES OF ANZAC REMEMBERED m a

(CONTINUED FROM PAGE ONE)

"In closing may I say can we take a pattern not only in heroism but in loyalty to the great hero, Jesus Christ, to whom we owe a lot. I am afraid half of our people are not realising the

importance of holy living, being heroes for Christ, but would far rather oe heroes for the Devil. May God give to each one of us a deeper desire not only to be loyal to our King and Empire, but to the King of Kings, Jesus Christ." During the singing of "Abide With Me" wreaths were placed on the me morial. | jilRjj/ Mr. W. Karoll (president of the Commemoration Committee) read the "Act of Remembrance" as follows: It is fitting that we should remem ber before God all those, who during this conflict, laid down their lives for us and our. country and for liberty of mankind. Let us call to remembrance to silence — Those who forsook all at the call to serve; The Sailors, Soldiers and Airmen, who went forth and returned no more; The Ministers of help and healing, the Chaplains, Doctors and Nurses, who saved others but not themselves; The men and women who have gone from this district; Those whose names are written deep to our hearts and who are more than conquerers, through Him Who loved us and gave Himself for us. - Bugler Franklin sounded the Last Post, following a minute's silence, and Benediction was said. Mr. Karol! referred to the fact that the occasion wouid te the last on which Clr. Jos. Hopkins would be"iJT££Sn.t at function in his official capacity Chairman of the Beaudesert Lhue Council. He thanked him for every thing he had done for the returned sol diers in the past. Mr. Karoll also thanked all who had given any assistance with the cele brations. Clr. Hopkins returned thanks. Members of the Roman Catholic faith attended a church service, break- tog off at the conclusion of the march. The members of the Beaudesert branch of the C.W.A. excelled them selves, providing a luncheon that earned the appreciation of all pre sent. Just over 100 guests sat down to the splendid repast. The President of the Beaudesert Sub- branch of the R.S.S.A.I.L.A. (Mr. A. Stephens) toasted the C.W.A. He said that the Beaudesert ladies went to a tremendous amount of trouble each Anzac Day to provide a dinner. This was appreciated, particularly by coun try residents. Servicemen owed a, good deal to the C.W.A. Mr. Stephens said that it was said men fought the war, but he thought all would agree that It was the womenfolk who carried on who had a harder cross to bear than the lads who went away. Mr. Stephens read a letter from Mrs. A. R. Ludwlg. President, who was ab sent In N.S.W. judging at a show. The letter said the branch felt privileged to be able to conduct the luncheons. Mr. Stephens said Clr. J. Hopkins had given a good deal of time to the or ganisation which was appreciated. Clr. Hopkins said that the C.W.A. not only came forward on Anzac Day but the members were to the fore to patrio tic efforts. Nothing was too much trouble for members. He hoped that they would continue the good work. Mrs. T. Jurd (secretary) returned thanks, and said members appreciated the remarks made. Mr. Muller complimented the ladles on the luncheon. He was sorry Clr. Hopkins could not carry on the chair manship a little longer. In 27 years Clr. Hopkins had contested one election, being returned unopposed nine times. That conveyed to the speaker that Clr. Hopkins had given satisfaction to the district. Mr. Muller welcomed returned men

DaCK no civil me, luiu aaiu uiie peuyin would remember their action when things looked blackest. Mr, Muller said that he could not see the new order that had been spoken of during the war. The only new order was when they found some men did not want work, and they were not returned

men. K<; nounaed a note of warning, arid tote, '-he people wanted better cuE'IIi-tChs thy wanted to make up their minds to sti2£-"t.£JLes and work. " . Mr. Muller said- that the legislation brought to by the State to loan money interest free to those desirous of .en gaging in primary production was the only bill of value to rehabilitation. Other bills spoken of Included little or no service to returned personnel. He hoped that to the next few years that the people would drop some of the sel fish spirit so pronounced to the past. Clr. Sharpe (Chairman of the -Tam borine Shire Council) returned thanks for honouring the returned men. He said Diggers appreciated the opportunity given them to get to- gether and honour their dead, and also join in the general celebrations. Men in the country did not have many chances to get together, and Anzac Bay was looked forward to. They owed a debt of gratitude to the ladies for providing the repast. He read with interest the fact that Beau desert had an active sub-branch. He advised all returned men to Join their sub-branch, and so be in a position to be able to assist those not so fortunate as themselves. Mr. L. Teese (President of Rathdow- new Sub-branch) said it was appre ciated that Anzac Day was the day of 1914-18 returned men. Mr. R. E. Stephens, who was O/C of the parade, on behalf of those who marched, expressed appreciation to Band Conductor Dauth and members of the band. He congratulated them on the job done, and said he hoped the band would be with them for many years to come. "Colonel Bogey" was a great old tune, and they enjoyed marching to it. Mr. Stephens also said it was a won derful thing for people to organise Anzac Day celebrations. He thanked Mr. Karoll for providing seating ac commodation at the monument. Official wreaths were placed on the monument by: Beaudesert and Rath- downey sub-branches of the R.S.SA.I. T. A TIaotirloenwf D crl Prrtec n W A «

Buffs Lodge and Loyal Beaudesert Lodge M.U.I.O.O.F. The Beaudesert Shire Council had secured a wreath, but when the Beaudesert Returned League wreath did not come to hand in time the Council handed theirs to the Returned League.
heading: Beaudesert Observance
snippet: THOSE who fell in two World Wars were honoured at Beaudesert yesterday, when commemoration services were held to celebrate Anzac Day. Proceedings commenced with a Dawn Parade at the monument,

articleText:
BEAUDESERT GOLF

In response to an invitation ex tended by the Woodenbong Golf Club, Mick Fiynn and Cyril Bios- nan made a trip on Sunday to take

part in the open day events, spon sored by that Club. Beaudesert's representatives held their own with visitors from sur rounding towns, as well as War wick and Killarney. The club spirit which existed between members, associates and v.sitors quite impressed the local players. The function concluded with a pre- sentat.on of trophies and speeches. Our local secretary accepted an Invitation to speak on behalf of the Beaudeser. Club, explaining that owing to heavy en.istments of members and associates, the club had been closed down for four years, and that the committee would not fix a date for an open day untii the links were in flrst-class playing order — which it is hoped will be early in the New Year. All present expressed a wish that they would like to attend, and will be looking forward to receiving an invita tion. On Saturday next at 2.30 p.m. a com petition will be held for all associates. Members who have learnt to play golf since January, 1946, are requested to take part in this competition. It will be played for handsome trophies pre sented by Mr, Tim Doyie, which com prise an E.P.N. S. cake tray and salt and pepper castors, which are on show. Men are working on the links all this week to get the putting greens in order. The new growth of grass is mak ing the links one of the beauty spots of Beaudesert. New flags and poles are in place. All mowers have been put in first-class order, and possibly this week or next a start will be made to mow the fairways. The committee would like to see more members taking part in competitions on the week-ends. Do not forget the dance at the club house on Tuesday. October 22. A valuable trophy most suitable to members has been donated to the club. This will be presented to the winner of the 18 hole stroke competition which will be played for on Sunday, October 27.

articleText:
Beaudesert Defeats

gEAUDESERTS A grade team severely trounced the pick of the four teams in the Wynnum competition on Sunday when they met in the opening game of the Geraghty Cup competition at the Beaudesert shoivirrounds.

> Although Wynnum had a day out as far as scrummages were con- | cerned, D. Anderson, and his men, did not let up from go to whoe, i and' finished up by winning easily by 44 to II after an interesting and i cleanly played game. | Beaudesert's'sB team met a second Wynnum team and was outclassed, i the score . being 65 to nil in V. _ jn.r.r 's "-vour. The sohoolboy match ' 1 provided a runaway game for the visitors.

i On the day Beaudesert- would have ! held its own with many teams, and i the game served to show that the ma- ' terial is available. If handled j Beaudesert should have no difficulty ui going through the competition unde- 1 feated, and then go on to beat other | strong sides. i However, it would not be $air to the players to carry on In the same manner i as in the past. The team that played i on Sunday is always subject to altera- tion, but it is safe to say that it will i take reversals of form on the' part of 1 representative players, and good dis- | plays by others not in the side, to bring about alterations prior to the next match. Consequently money should be spent in developing the team. If it is" at all ' possible the players should be brought I to Beaudesert for training under the I electric light, and the services of a | coach should be engaged for those | training periods if this Can be done. The Beaudesert team is not perfect, j because no team can ever expect to reach that stage, but it can develop greater understanding that will help no end. Understanding between players means that the man with the ball anticipates ; that there is somebody with him all the time, and, consequently, he" uncon- ! seiously overcomes any desire to hang on to the ball and go on his, own, Backs also know that forwards are trailing them, and' it gives them con- j fiderice. They 'also know that their for wards ace fanning out after winning scrums, to make extra men, or follow- j ihg in expectation of dropped passes or intercepts. ; It is well worth the while of tho j league to give consideration of coaoh- | ing. these young players, because, 'they, ; in turn, will he able to pass the know- j ledge oh to their club mates. There are I manv in. the representative side with ; years of"fC0t!?9U ahead of them, and a j comparative smairoutfay now will pro- | yide benefits for a long time to cSnlC: —

Sunday's gqme could have proved disastrous because a team losing the bail from the scrums is at a great dis advantage. Beaudesert won but 18 ef- . fective scrums to 30 in favour of Wyn num, the half time position being 13-7 Wynnum's way. 'Greater credit is due to Beaudesert for overcoming this impost. They also Infringed more, having 10 Iree kloks , against them in the first half with six in their favour, (file second half tally was 4-2 against them. On the day it would be difficult tq displace any Beaudesert player. A team with such a margin qf superiority can hot but shtao? The backs were grand ip attack, and it stands to reason that the defence work must have been good to stop the chances that Wynnum had. The pivot mep did not get the amount of work given their opposition,

jpit when they did secure the leather from the scrums they moved fast, with Plunkett winning applause for his ef forts. Wellington, on the wing, was outstanding. He did not wait for the ball, his ideas of the work of the win ger being such that he went looking for opportunities, or chances to make op portunities for himself. He certainly got results. Anderson gave his forwards every en couragement by setting an example that they followed. The match was interesting through out all stages because Wynnum, with so much of the ball,- was- always likely to stage an attack. Had It not been for the spotting of the forwards, Kay would have given more trouble than he did. He was a very tired man after half time, no doubt due to the attention he received during the match, following on the hard game of Saturday, At times he showed the football that has made him an interstate, and potential international player. The game was refereed by R. White, of Brisbane. The teams were: Wynnum: Full back, E. Glass; three- quarters, M. Ackworth, D. Pye, F. Elms, G. Fuller; five-eight, T. Baxter;

half back, J. Thurlow; forwards, R. Ross, P. O'Connor, Eckland, N. Cloherty, M. Annan, R, Kay. Beaudesert: Full back, S. Callanan; three-quarters, G. Wellington, K. Panitz, P. Deane, K. Morrissy; five- eight, T. Plunkett; half back, W, Col lins; forwards, V. McGovern, D- Cahill, R. Dauth, W. Day, R. Smith, D. Ander son. A scrum at half way started play, A minute after Dauth attempted a goal from five yards from half way. Another free kick a minute and a half later, and Dauth. made no mistake, giving his side an early lead.' Beaudesert set up an offensive. They kicked through, and Wellington fol lowed on. He ' dribbled the ' ball, and, when it was over the line, he touched down. It was a clever piece of work, Dauth missed. Wynnum won a scrum near half way, but lost the ball. Wellington secured and he raced everything for the corner. Dauth's effort was particularly good, and after 4 minutes Beaudesert led by ten points. Exciting football followed. From the kick off Fuller and Baxter handled, but the latter was forced out. Play was now in the Beaudesert quarter, arid Kay went close to the chalk line before be ing forced out. Cahill retired with a fractured wrist and F. Callanan took his place, Beaudesert initiated a move in its own quarter, and Morrissy received near half way, He won the race to the posts. Dauth again came to light — _ ' Kay made a dash, gave to O'Gonnor, and was there to take the return. He had only to pass S. Callanan, and he was at hia top. Callanan dived at the right second, and grassed his big op ponent, saving the situation. Dauth forced his way through the resultant ruck, but soon after the side was penal ised. Glass kicked a goal, and his side was 13 points in arrears after 174 min utes. Glass attempted a goal from two yards over half way. Wynnum dropped a ball at its own quarter, and Welling ton was at his top when it went to him near halfway. It was a one sided race for the line. Panitz missed.

After 26 minutes K,v. kicked from well out, to get a nice Knai, F. Callanan was seen in some heady work. Up to this st:n>e Wynnum had won 13 of the 16 effective scrums, and Beaudesert had Ijeen penalised eight times tq four ta their favour. Kay jiicked another goal and Day went over from a move started at Beau- desert's quarter by S. Callanan. Cal lanan had cut holes in the opposition. Dauth missed. Kay missed a long kick at goal, F. Callanan followed on on his own, but his good work was nulli fied for want of support. Wynnum's fullback was seen in a -long run that beat tho opposition, and, Wheripre's'seScill: forced out by Wellington. It was a dangerous position. The bell went a ininute later. After oranges Beaudesert attacked with vigour, and had play centred in the opposition quarter. Wellington made a "dribbling" rush, and it devel oped into a race between Thurlow and he for the ball. The former was in a handier position, and he just got there to save. After englu minutes Dauth, who had done so well with liis boot, missed an easy one. Soon after Thur low was taken off in the ambulance car. To McGovern'went the honour of the opening try of the second half. He scored from a ruck for Panitz to con vert. Beaudesert was playing part icularly good football, and Deane gave "Panitz f.lie chance to top off a brilliant move. S. Callanan failed, and the score was 29—6 after 18 minutes play. E. Glass went close to beating the opposition when he came from well behind to out holes in the Beaudesrt side. Panitz delighted the crowd when he kicked ahead, raced after the ball, and scooped" it up when still at his full. He went over the -line mixed up with Kay, but lost the ball before he could ground it. The pick up was the type of movement that will always be appre ciated by the crowd, Another popular movement went wrong through a fumble of an easy take. Anderson was hemmed in, and he threw, a long pass to Morrissy, who

lost it. The move is one that has been exploited to the full by international teams, and generally gets results. After 25 minutes Wynnum was in no end of trouble, and the side was lucky to keep its line clear as long as is did. Panitz was forced out bv a tanklar

when well set for the line. From the scramble after the scrum Dauth gave to Collins, and lie sent to Plunkett, who swung in, to throw the opposition off its balance. He scored a nice try. Morrissy added the extras, Wynnum came to light with a splash of snappy passing but it was soon broken up. F. Callanan Initiated a move that allowed Plunkett to run Deane into position, and Deane to score under the uprights. Day caught the lineumplres' flags. Kay, who had been taking things quietly, came Into the picture. He de lighted his supporters, and earned the appreciation of the home slders, by scoring well out. He added paid to the account with a splendid kick. This spurred Beaudesert and in a flash they had McGovern over, with Panitz kicking the goal. Only two minutes of play remained, SECOND MATCH Beaudesert's B grade team was de feated by Wynnum's second' A grade team by 65 to nil, after being in ar rears 27-0 at half time, The order in which Wynnum scored is as follows: J. Pascoe, J. Jones, V. Bltossi; S. Green (conversion), Sim- monds, S. Green (conversion), R. Jones, Bitossi, Green (conversion), J. Coogan, Green (score and conversion), Bitossi (score and conversion), Bitossi (score and conversion), Ramsden, Thurlow (conversion),' R. Jones, J. Green, Thur low (conversion). Ramsden, Thurlow (conversion), D. Drew, Thurlow (con version), J. Jones . and k7Qulnn.. of _Wynnum, "Wereinjured in the first halC'tand- Bitossi retired in the second half with an injured knee.

articleText:
Beaudesert Branch

Mrs. A. R. Ludwig president) pre sided at a meeting of the Beaudesert Branch of the Country Women's Asso ciation held at the Rest Room on Wed-

nesday, 7th insl. Others present were Mesdames Goodwin, Pascoe, Struss, Ferguson, Manderson, Dennis, Keating. Aldridge, and Jurd (lion, secretary). Apologies were received from Mes dames Summers. J. Drynan and Ward. Mrs. Ludwig extended a welcome to two new members, Mesdames Mander son and Ferguson, and also to all old members. A bosket of flowers was re ceived from Mrs. Summers and was much appreciated. The finnncial statement showed a credit balance cf £156/10'6 and was adopted on tin; motion of Mesdames Pascoe and Aldridge. Accounts amounting to £3/3/4 were passed for payment on the motion of Mesdames Goodwin and Dennis. On the motion of Mesdames Dennis and Manderson £5 was donated to the Legacy Club. £1/1/- to the Lota Sea side Home, and £1/1/- to the Southporl Seaside Cottage. A general discussion took place re garding attendances at meetings and it was eventually agreed that these would improve as meetings in future commenced at 10.30 a.m. This would give country people an opportunity of attending, and at the same time allow them to do any shopping required and to return home early. It was resolved on the motion of Mesdames Keating and Dennis that the Beaudesert Shire Council be requested to have the grass around the Rest Room mown. The treasurer drew all members' at tention to their subscriptions which are now due. It was also suggested that each member endeavour to introduce new members and thus assist this worthy institution, The secretary was instructed to for ward a letter of condolence to Mrs. Lane on the death of her mother. The meeting closed with a vote of thanks to the chair.
heading: Beaudesert Branch
snippet: Mrs. A. R. Ludwig (president) presided at a meeting of the Beaudesert Branch of the Country Women's Association held at the Rest Room on

articleText:
BEAUDESERT, PREMIERS

Beaudesert Club, by defeating the Christmas Creek team by 24-10 on Sunday, won the Beaudesert and District Rugby- League 1946 A

grade competutun, having ueen undefeated on the field in that period, although they forfeited one » match to Creek during the last round. The match, played at the Beau desert show grounds, attracted a gate of only £11, showing how interest in the game had waned. On paper it looked as if the men from the country would have a chance, but towards the latter stages of the game they petered out, and Beaudesert went on to stack up the points. At half-time Beaudesert led 6-5, having secured the points per medium of the boot of the captain, Sid Cal- lanan. He added another two soon after half time. The season, which opened with great promise, did not prove the success that it might have. The withdrawal of Waterloos before play started left three teams in the competition. With Ger- aghty Cup matches, and other hap penings, teams did not get the foot ball that is necessary to retain interest of players and supporters. Canungra forfeited to Christmas Creek at an early stage, and in the last round Creek won two matches without hav ing to strip.

Naturally this upset Creekers who claim that they were given a "raw" deal because the two teams involved were able to get a team together when the match was on their home grounds. In addition the Ambulance Cup was also made a fixture, which caused dis satisfaction with some of the offic:als, although the Ifengue took the precau tion to have both Beaudesert and Creek agreeable to the change in plans, Sunday's match did not have any cf the cup final flavour about it from any point of view. Except for the players, there was little enthus iasm and apparently many of them were not enthusiastic enough to train for the event. The home combin ation had it over the opposition, and this because obvious in the iat- ter stages when the points began to mount. Early, Christmas Creek gave away some penalties, which proved costly, but in the first half there were 13 to them, and ten against. Infringements in the rucks gave them an advantage after half time, receiving ten to three. Raking honours were even before half time, with 11 each, and the ad- vantage to Creeks after oranges was 12-10. Collins, who has been out of com mission with an injured hand, put new life into Beaudesert's play. He always moved fast when he received the bail, and he had the advantage that he was given more protection than his vis-a-vis, and. besides that, his for wards broke faster, and did not allow the opposition to take advantage of the ball received. Plunkett was always dangerous, and Brosnan earned his place as centre. A quick mover, he also showed that he can tackle when called upon to do so. Panitz was in good form and, while O'Brien had an off day as far as hand ling was concerned. Wellington was better than he often is as far as taking

the ball is concerned. S. Callanan was as sound as ever. Beaudesert's forwards were better in all departments, and F. Callanan, play ing second row, was seen to better ad vantage in the open than he is when tied up in front row. D. Cahill, who broke his wrist in the first interleague match, stripped for the first time since then. He and the remainder of Creek's vanguard were seen to advantage spasmodically, with V. McGovern the pick of the bunch. There was not sufficient cohesion be tween them to make the pack a serious strik.ng force, but this can be attribu ted to lack of match play. The game was in charge of Mr. S. McVie. . Teams were as follows: Christmas Creek: Full back, K. Ryan; three-quarters. D. Rafter, K. Morrisey, D. Doyle, T. Binstead; five- eight, P. Deane; half back, M. Skelton; forwards, F. Sykes, D. Cahill, V. O'Neill, A. Ward, D. Dennis, V. Mc Govern. Beaudesert: Full back, S. Callanan; three-quarters, G. Wellington, K. Panitz, J. Brosnan, E. O'Brien; five- eight, Tom Plunkett; half back, W. Collins; forwards. R. Dauth, T. Mur ray. T. Draper, F. Callanan, K. Little, W. Day. In the first minute of play Christ mas Creek received a free kick, and McGovern missed a shot at goal. The visitors continued to attack, but play was transferred to halfway. S. Cal lanan kicked a good goal from well out after nine minutes of play. Six minutes later S. Callanan and Binstead collided, after Callanan had run up, and just delivered the ball. Both were out of commission for a lit tie time. At 20 minutes Sykes missed a kick at goal. Wellington failed to hold the ball, and a scrum followed. Although the home side won the leather, they were hard pressed, and finally kicked clear, to relieve their line. Sykes and McGovern came back again, but the side was penalised. The kick went out on the full. The scrum was aga.n won by Beaudesert, and they kicked to half way. At 24 minutes S. Callanan kicked at goal but it failed. There was some excitement when Beaudesert won a scrum. The ball went out to Wellington, who looked a chance. As Wellington ran along the line there was a scatter of sawdust, causing some Christmas Creek officials to clami that the player must have been out for the line to be disturbed. The linesman ruled otherwise. It was a close call for Creeks. At 32 minutes Callanan again raised the flags from a hard angle. Another three minutes and Callanan added a further two points. Just on half time a free kick was given Creekers, and they elected to put the ball into the air, S. Callanan who was behind his line, took the ball, and put his toe into it, Mc Govern, who had followed on fast, charged the ball, stopping its pro- press. He then dived on it to score, Some claimed that he touched the leather with his hands, but it still would not have made it a knock on, it being legal to touch the bali in a charge. Sykes made no mistake, and Beaudesert led 6 to 5. Christmas Creek resumed playing into the sun. They were called on to defend, and again an infringement al lowed Callanan to kick a goal. Collins was seen in a great piece of work. He moved from the base of the scrum, cut in beside it, and set his side in operation. When the ball went to O'Brien he knocked on. Creek put in some solid defensive work before they were able to clear. Callanan missed a kick, and at ten minutes Sykes also failed. A minute later Beaudesert kicked from the home line, and followed on. Wellington streaked down the line and toed ahead. Panitz was with him, and he kicked and went on to score. There was disagreement about' the legality of the try, it being claimed that a Creeker going for the ball had been illegally tackled, but the referee ap parently ruled that it was a legal push, Serious interference had taken place as far as Panitz was concerned, and had he been stopped by the Creek player, the referee was more than en titled to award Beaudesert a penalty try. Whatever took place the referee called a Creek player to him, and spoke to him. Panitz converted his effort, and his side led 13-5. The visiting forwards worked like Trojans, and McGovern 'went through the ruck, and must have been almost there when he was grounded. A five yards scrum was the outcome. Beau desert cleared:- but Dennis came through, "and left Draper standing watching him to get within striking distance. In a ruck O'Neill battled his way over. Sykes made no mistake, and Beaudesert's lead was reduced to three after 19 minutes. Dauth attempted a long kick with out success. There was an exchange of kicks between fullbacks, with Creeker's representative- practically on his own line. He fumbled, and there was a mix- up that finished with Wellington, who had followed on, diving over on the loose ball. Callanan missed and after 25 minutes the score was 16-10 Beau-

desert's way. Ryan and Cahill were both out of commission together, and Ryan sub sequently went up, and Deane dropped into his place. At 39 minutes Collins scored from an individual effort. He found a great opening when he went around the scrum. The first opposition was the fullback, and he found no trouble in swerving around him and finishing under the posts. Dauth did the rest, and the score was 21-10. Creeks were completely disorganised, and, although they made several indi vidual efforts, Beaudesert was soon over. Day started near half way, and ran for the corner, to beat a few would be defenders. It was too much for Dauth. Four minutes extra time was necessary because of time lost through injuries. When Creek kicked off the players were determined to reduce the leeway. They went at it with a will, and they were battling hard close to their ob jective when the final- bell went, leav ing them defeated by 24-10. THE PREMIERSHIP At the conclusion of play in the competition the points are as follows: j e I £ a I S I 5 I ' Beaudesert .... 7 6 1 - 12 Christmas Ck . 7 4 3 - 8 Canungra . 6 - 6 POINTS SCORERS The table of points scorers in com petition matches is as follows. (Christ mas Creek won three matches when their opponents forfeited. This put their players at a disadvantage as points getters are concerned): BEAUDESERT Try. Goal. K. Panitz 10 4 T. Plunkett 1 0 W. Collins ' 0 0 N. Freeman . . 1 0 R. Dauth 0 9 G. Wellington .. ..6 0 W. Day .7 3 - 0 S. Callanan 0 8 E. O'Brien 3 0 CANUNGRA Try. Goal, W. Crooks .. 0 1 L. Jerome 1 0 K. Geiger 1 8 R. Smith 1 0 K. articleText:
BEAUDESERT'S HOSPITAL

"JHE Beaudesert public hospital is keeping its doors, or at least some of them, open, but this is only being made possible by the determined ef-

forts of Beaudesert executives con nected with the institution. For many month's the nursing staff position has been serious, and the Medical Superintendent (Dr. W. A. Beet) has applied to Brisbane for extra staff in vain. The only relief provided has been absorbed as replacements, and efforts to induce girls to become probationers have not been successful. At present private wards are closed, and only country, people and the very sick from the town are being taken into the institution, and patients are being allowed to return home before they would in normal circumstances. The threat to close the hospital still hangs over the heads of members of the community. This state of affairs cannot be al lowed to continue indefinitely. The hospital is controlled by the Brisbane and South Coast Hospitals Board, which probably believes in cen tralisation, to the detriment of centres placed similarly to Beaudesert. Remote control is not always a suc cess, and it is to be regretted that the local authority representative on the board was not invited to Beaudesert immediately, as soipe of the members of the Beaudesert Shire Council sug gested, because he might have been able to do something to alleviate the position. Whatever happens, the hospital must not be closed. Former servicemen who were engaged as nursing orderlies dur ing the# war should be employed to I work the men's wards, and. if neces- I sary, former nurses, who are now mar- ried, and can spare the time, could be I invited to lend their services for the j time being. I

The latter plan has operated suc cessfully at other centres in time of adversity, such as during epidemics of sickness, and accident to nursing staffs. No doubt Beaudesert people would re spond as wholeheartedly. Naturally this should be a last resort only, but the male attendant proposal should be fully investigated and "nurs ing" ethics temporarily forgotten., if necessary.
heading: BEAUDESERT'S HOSPITAL

articleText:
the beaudesert trip i

(By F. Crockford, President of Kyogle Bowling Club).

We. went for a trip one Saturday, , We went in a bus out Beaudesert way. i Algy Ford was very late, And we pulled up the 'bus outside his

gate. When at last we did get going, Wc turned our thoughts to Leslie Owen. And wondered why he told old Bert, That the trip was off he knew for cert. We travelled along the winding track, Up and down like a camel's back. And at last we came in sight of the i town, i Eyes lit up— there wasn't a frown. j We were met on arrival by Abby Hood, He supplied cold beer straight from the wood. i The Beaudesert boys were there in force, 1 Frank Hodgson, Mick, and Jack Fenton ! of course. ; Another one, now. wait a minute, i I think his name was Teddy Winnett, ' ( Ernie Henley and Harry Buss, 1 They all came out and made a fuss. ! The rinks were picked and in we went, , To win the game we were all intent. i They gave us a lunch that was fit for i Kings, i Poultry and ham and all good things. ! The usual compliments had to be paid ! About the game we had. and the scores i we had made. i The Senior Vice President— You know 1 the onel 1 Had something to say and caused some ! fun. i By this time things were getting hot, 1 So we went to the bar and had a spot. 1 Tills was the end of a Perfect Day, ' So we got in the bus and on our wav.

articleText:
beaudesert water scheme

THE Chairman of tho Beaudesert Shire Council (Clr, E. E. Henley) and Clr. J. Aldridgc at the first meeting of the newly formed council on Tuesday reaffirmed their pledge to fight for a water supply scheme for Beaudesert.

Clr. Henley said that he favoured a water scheme, and he hoped that the councillors would support him. He was sure that the divisional councillors would support him. He believed, that the people who were to use the water were prepared to pay for it, and it was the council's i, duty to push the scheme- ahead. . . . . "A town without a water supply is not a town at all," added Clr. Henley, who said that they must have water if they wanted parks, Clr. Henley concluded by again appealing to the councillors to sup port him in this matter. . , Clr. Aldridge said that he hoped to get a water supply during his term of office. He did not think that there could be an objection from other councillors as those people who used the- water would pay for it. The Beaudesert "Times" was surprised that no reference was made to the fact that a report on a water scheme is now almost a month late. The last meeting of the Council received a letter dated April 8, 1946, from the Engineer in charge of the Department of Local Gov ernment, stating: "The report on the investigations made concerning a water supply scheme for Beaudesert will now be available by the end of this month." When it was found that something had gone wrong hi Brisbane the council could have decided to make some inquiries, or, better stilt,' send Clr. Henley to Brisbane to introduce himself to Government departments, and at the same time follow up inquiries made previously. There might still be no reply by next meeting, and a month will have been lost.
heading: BEAUDESERT WATER SCHEME
snippet: THE Chairman of tho Beaudesert Shire Council (Clr, E. E. Henley) and Clr. J. Aldridge at the first meeting of the newly formed council on Tuesday reaffirmed their pledge to fight for a water supply scheme for Beaudesert.

Mr. Saville, she said, had been paying rates for 40 years, and the wet portion of the road was the same as it was 40 years ago. Clr. N. F. Gittins said good work had ., been done on other sections of the road as it was permanent work. About half

the road had been done. It was decided that it would be a , recommendation to the incoming coun- i cil that the work be Included in the programme for the coming year. , T. B. Trace, Maclean, Jimboomba, i advised that the main bitumen road to his property was very washed out and in a bad state. It was decided to secure a report on the matter. George Scott accepted the condi tions offered by the Council to do work on his road from the dip on the turn- off to Ipswich Road. He was to mam- tain the road for two years for £25. W. articleText:
BEAUDESERT CATTLE SALE

M. Selwyn Smith & Son wish to draw attention to the fact that their next cattle sale in Beaudesert. will be held on Friday, 3rd May, 1946, instead of Wednesday, 8th May 1946. The reason

of the change is that Wednesday, 8th

May, will be the first day of Beau desert Show, and, consequently, the yards would not be available for the selling of cattle. It 1s hoped that, be fore that date, a settlement will have been made of the Brisbane meat strike, and that a market will then be avail able for beefy and tinner cattle. Of course, nothing definite can be done at present, but, if Intending sellers keep in touch with the auctioneers, they will pass on any information they may re ceive and, even should a settlement be made any time prior to the date of the sale, it should be ascertained what eattto sua be accepted.

articleText:
Beaudesert Bowlers Win

A rink skippered by E. Lancaster and comprising W. A. Lupton, C. Waldron and H. A. Teske, won for Beaudesert the Dewers Cup at the Easter Bowls Carnival held at

Warwick.

Beaudesert Club was represented by two rinks and another went to Gympie. The cup won by Lancaster's rink is on show at Enrights and it will be held by the present holders for a -year. In addition there is a trophy of £3/3/- for each player. Dealing with the competition the Warwick "News'' of Tuesday has the following to say: The Beaudesert rink skipped by E. Lancaster won the final of the fours championship at the Warwick Easter bowls carnival. Lancaster won 21 to 20 after an extra end had been necessary to decide the winner, the scores being level at 20-all 'at the completion of the scheduled 25 ends. The pairs championship went to F. Melllsh and W. Warner, who defeated H. Warner and E. Tessman in the final. The consolation fours was won by K. Price's Southport rink, with three vic tories and a margin of 57 points. Semi-finals of the fours champion ship were played on the Warwick green yesterday morning, and both were pro ductive of keen competition, In the game between rinks skipped by Hartley arid Parker (Coorparoo) the latter started splendidly with threes on the first two ends, and after four heads led 8-2. Harley, however, then scored .a six to equalise, and with a two on tlie hext end went to the front and never surrendered the le£d thereafter. Winning seven heads out of eight, after being down 18-9 on the 11th end, Parker got to within one of Harley on the 19th head, the score being 20-19, but Harley's four thereafter dominated the play, scoring a two and four singles to the opposition's single and won by 26 to 20.

The Lancaster-Clarke game was also productive of a keen struggle over the early ends, deciding factor being a seven on the 13th head to Lancaster, which gave him a lead of 17-9. Clarke won the next three heads to reduce the leeway to two, forfeited a two and then scored a five to take the lead on the 18th end at 20-19. Lancaster equalised on the next end, scored another single and then registered a four to lead 25-20. Although Clarke won three of the last four heads, Lancaster was aoie to maintain his advantage to win by 27-24. The final, played on the Warwick East green in the afternoon, was an epic struggle, and produced some of the best bowls ever seen - en the green. Harley's four started the better to lead 6-1 after four ends, but Lancaster scored three twos In succession to Har ley's single and after eight heads the scores were even at 7-all. Four singles in succession gave Lancaster a 11-7 lead, but Harley then registered a three to get within one of the opposition. Winning the next two heads, Lancaster increased his advantage to 14-10, but Harley equalised with a four on the 16th end. Lancaster again assumed command with two twos to the opposi tion's single, but a two to Harley on the 20th head reduced his leeway to a single. With both rinks playing splendid bowls, the next five heads were pro ductive of some wonderful bowls, with each rink keyed up to fever pitch, Lancaster scored two singles to lead 20-17 with three ends to go, but Har ley won the next two ends for singles and when the final end was entered upon the score was 20-19 In Lancas ter's favour. Excitement was intense as the large crowd watched the dowis on the final end. 'When Lancaster picked up his last bowl Harley lay 'game with two shots. Lancaster's last bowl reached the shot wood, a toucher, sprang the kitty a fraction and reduced the score to a single, making the scores 20-all, thus necessitating another head to reach a decision. Lupton set a splendid standard by drawing a beautiful shot just short of kitty with his first bowl, and followed with another counter. Teske consoli dated the position by drawing a beau tiful toucher for -Lancaster \yhich tucked the kitty in behind his own woods in a difficult position for the opposition to get at it, and Lancaster held, four shots. Leadbitter, Harley's third, drove in an endeavour to open up the head, but missed, and the skips changed (over with Harley four down. Harley's first firm sliot .was wide, Lan caster drawing a positional bowl, but with his second he promoted one of his own woods to second shot, to give Lan caster the game 21-20. After winning their first two games on Friday, Lancaster's rink went on to take three on Saturday and Sunday. The scores were: Lancaster v. Mclntyre 28-17, Jones v. Lancaster 19-17, Lan caster v. Warner 19-14. MonHow'c eomi-flnalc nnrl finnl vo

suited: W. Luptop, e. C. Waldron, H, Teske, E. Lancaster (Beaudesert) .... 27 V. G. Rolleston, M. H. Clarke, 0. Palmer, T. C. Clarke (New Farm) . . , , . . . . . , . . , , , . 24 ! O. Evans, A. Marshal, G. Leadbit ter, K. P. Harley (Warwick) , . 26 v. W. M. Mackay, W. J. McGown, O. A; Davenport, L. C, Parker (Coorparoo) 20 FINAL Lupton, Waldron, Teske, Lancaster 21 . v. Evans, Marshall, Leadbitter, Harley 20 D. R. Brownlie's rink comprised of P. Lesley, M. Bunck and H. Buss, won two of the six played. They won against Hooper 21-20, and Weeks 20-10, both Warwick representative rinks. They went down to Lancaster and Harley, both of whom went to the final, and the narrow margin of one resulted in their defeat by Warner's rink. (Warner al ready-had his name on the trophy). Blunck and Lesley got to the quarter finals in the doubles; defeating Brown- lie and Buss. Printed at Beaudesert and Published In the Beaudesert and Tamborine Shires for Beaudesert Times Pty. Ltd., by H. R. Tomlinson, Brayford Street, Beaudesert.

articleText:
. BEAUDESERT WALTZING CHAMPIONSHIP

The Beaudesert Branch of the a.l.p. is preparing for Its annual kiddles Christmas tree party, and as a means of raising funds, a dance Is to be held

in the Technical Hall on Friday night, August 16. In addition to engaging the services of Reid's Dansonians to Srovlde music, the many novelties will lclude a waltzing championship. It is many years since a championship was conducted, and the event should draw entries from all parts of the district, particularly as the judges are two well known dance professionals, Mr. and Mrs. Larsen, of Brisbane. During the evening the judges will also give an exhibition of old time waltzing.
heading: BEAUDESERT WALTZING CHAMPIONSHIP
snippet: The Beaudesert Branch of the A.L.P. is preparing for its annual kiddles Christmas tree party, and as a means of raising funds, a dance is to be held

articleText:
BEAUDESERT & DISTRICT DEVELOPMENT ASSOC.

There was an attendance of sixteen at a meeting of the Beaudesert and District Development Association held at the Technical Hall on Wednesday

night, at which Mr. T. J. Ennght pre sided. Disappointment was expressed by Mr. Karoll at the absence of re presentatives of other organisations who had signified their intention to be present. He felt that they were sin cere, and if they recognised the im portance of this movement they would be keen about it. The secretary (Rev, J. J. Wilson) suggested that a circular letter be for warded to all organisations before the next meeting stating just what is to be dealt with and advising the date of ihc meeting. Messrs. W. Blunck, J. J. Wilson, and T. J. Enright were ap pointed a sub-committee to draw up , a list of those organisations to be circularised. ELECTRICITY Mr. Lane said that everybody knows wlm t is happening with regard to elec tricity from reports in the press. As far as water is concerned the corres pondence gives all the information up to lire present time. It is the intention of the City Electric Light Co. to take certain routes front Beaudesert to the rural areas. The last visit of Mr. Guy L'Eslrange to the rural areas was for the purpose of knowing what route the lines would take. The coming here is it means to an end and they must go outside to balance the load. He was told that it was the intention of the Company to make circuits right throughout the Shire of Beaudesert. Mr. W. Keaveny: We must keep on working for the electrification of the country areas and it is only by a co operative effort that this will come about. Mr. Lane said that he expected City Electric Light would be here at the end of April. Mr. Karoii moved and Mr. W. Kea veny seconded that a letter be for warded to the State Electricity Com mission expressing appreciation that a start lias been made to take over the Beaudesert township and that they will see their way clear to reticulate the rural areas without undue delay. The motion was carried. SECONDARY SCHOOL

Mr. Karoll said that at the last meeting four men were appointed to : go into the rural curriculum, but ow- ; ing to the holidays nothing had been : done in that particular matter. With : regard to a secondary school, a letter was sent by the Department to Mr. i Muller stating that at present owing j to the small number of children in : the higher grades there would not be j sufficient to carry on classes they j would like to sec. Since then fuvther : information has been sent to the De- j partment which has thrown another : light on the question, and the matter ' is now in their hands. The numbers i in the lower grades are very high, and : the numbers in the higher grades, very ; small. ; Mr. Hodgson said he could not : understand why tills should be so. The : numbers should be about the same unless children left the school before i reaching the higher grades. At the last : scholarship examinations only nine or eleven passed in the whole district and lie was of the opinion that greater numbers would sit for the examinations if a secondary school were established : in tlie district so Hint children could continue their studies. Mr. Karoll said there wore 40 in . lower grade class and 14 in a higher grade. Lots of children leave before they arc 14 years of age. This year 20 sat for the scholarship examinations and a few years ago 50 sat. He was of the opinion that the reason for this is that there is no secondary schooi in the area.

Rev. J. J. Wilson said that this was a very vital question. Tlie children in the country should not. be handicapped because there were not sufficient num bers. He had difficulty in getting two boys into a secondary school in Bris bane. Tlie fees are high and some who have passed their scholarship cannot get accommodation. Mr. Keaveny: Anyone who puts up a good case will get what, he wants. Mr. Enright said that every child should have a secondary education should lie or she desire it. It was resolved on tlie motion of Mr. P. Hodgson, seconded by Mr. Wilson that the Minister for Public Instruc tion be requested to establish a sec ondary school at Beaudesert. and that a copy of tlie letter be forwarded to Mr. A. G. Muller, M.L.A.. and that lie be requested to further our claim. SERVICE CAR It was agreed that the State Trans port Commission be asked to expedite tlie request that provision be made to allow tlie Beaudesert service car to carry 28 passengers, JIMBOOMBA BRIDGE It was resolved that a letter be for warded to the-Main Roads Commission drawing attention to tlie considerable inconvenience caused to travellers and commercial people, and milk transport to Brisbane through the flooding of the bridge near Henderson's at Jimboomb'a. The next meeting was fixed for 17tlr April.

articleText:
SEARCHING FOR BEAUDESERT

The Rev. Father Brosnan, who had 1 not enjoyed good health for some time, has been appointed to the Beaudesert < Catholic Parish. He spent some time in the narish nreviouslv. following his

return to Australia After many speak ers had welcome him at a function on Sunday night Father Brosnan told of his difficulties in finding Benudesert on the occasion of his first visit. He said he got on a tram, and went to Central Station and asked for a ticket to Beau desert. After being observed in silence for a few minutes, he wns advised that the train left from the other side of . Brisbane, Later he confidently pre sented himself at the interstate station. From there he was referred to the right place, and found his way down, having a "rattling" good trip in the rail motor.

articleText:
BEAUDESERT'S FINAL BURST

Piling on points in the latter stage of the game, Beaudesert Club defeated Canungra in the final fixture match of the Beau- desert and District Rugby League

competition played at- Canungra on Sunday. At half time the scores were three all, and it was not until 16 minutes of the second half had gone that Canungra "packed up," as it usually does, and was de feated 22-8. Beaudesert unfolded good foot ball, once it had the opposition run off its feet, and there were .some classy movements. The game was poorly attended. Ca nungra was scrapping until the last minute to get a team, the last man being secured as the side was to take the field. Both had to call cin players who were not- considered in the early stages of the season. It was farcical to see the - 14 year old Frank Parrish matched with the tall and speedy George Wel lington. The lad, who has a ton of football brains, and the ability a pro mising player requires, did not disgrace himself by any means, but he is not being given a chance. If he is called on to play this class of football next sea son he will be "burnt" out by the time that he has developed, and should be getting to his prime as a senior player. It will be surprising if he reaches the heights that he may achieve if he is continually called on to face older and seasoned footballers. There are limits to the endurance of even the toughest boys. Beaudesert won a majority of scrums, and, even when it lost the ball, its for wards were round the pack smartly to stifle the opposition before it could get going. The "pigs" turned on a grand display of spotting. The match was in charge of Ref. L. Jacobsen. Beaudesert fielded: Full back. P. Callanan; three-quarters, G. Welling ton, K. Panitz, T. Kassulke. E. O'Brien; five-eight, J. Brosnan; half, W. Day; forwards, T. Draper R. Dauth, T. Ald- ridge, M. Barrett. K. Little, T. Murray. Canungra was represented by: Full, back, E. Day; three-quarters, L. Day, R. Lnwton, R. Murphy, F. Parrish; five-eight, J. Finch; half, C. Thomas; forwards, K. Holden, K. Geiger, T. Breeze, M. Finch, T. L'Estrange, R. Smith.

J. ' Finch was seen in a nice cut through in the early stages. Wellington looked like getting away, and he had an opening, but Parrish grounded him with a nice tackle. Holden was seen in a great run.- and his side had a chance but it kicked instead of passing. This brought about a change to Ca- nungra's side, Murphy going into half back position. In a great run Holden all' but reached his objective. Canun gra was given a free, and kicked ahead which allowed Wellington to take play to half way before he was stopped. After play had been in progress for 16 minutes. Smith, who was making an extra back, received at the base. <,.,e scrum near quarter r.ay lie went di rect for the ii'.ve, and, although Wel lington '-ras h.-.ndy. he got a start. ?.rf(Vth went over with several oppnsi- 'i>i 'tying to push htm back. Geiger .-a'cd, and Canungra hitu a three point -;ld. When Wellington dropped a pass, and it landed in Parrlsh's hands, the little fellow raced half the length of the field before he was grassed He was on his own and the advantage was lost. Beaudesert transferred the thea tre of play with snappy passing, but that to Wellington, when he was all set for the line, was forward. Dauth attempted a kick at goal. Beaudesert initiated a passing move ment and the ball went across the field from hand to hand. O'Brien raced down the wing at top speed, and took a high pass. Nobody had a chance of getting near him travelling so fast was he. Panitz failed, and the whistle sounded with the scores three all. Soon after the resumption Smith sent Murphy away on a great run. to be grassed near the line. Beaudesert cleared when Canungra was given a free kick. Smith went away on nis own, but he was not given support. Canungra added to its score that came as a surprise. L'Estrange had made a run, but he was- claimed by two' or three opponents. His own side also'joined in the tussle, making about six players in a wrestling crowd. Sud denly Geiger, who must have pulled the ball out was seen going for the line to force his way over. Play had been in progress for seven minutes. E. Day missed. A- scrum was ordered at Canungra's quarter, and the visitors won it. The leather went to Panitz, who finished off a good movement. Dauth missed what is often an easy one for him, and at 16 minutes the scores were even at six. J. Pinch retired at this stage with a fractured collarbone. Beaudesert took play up, and the opposition was held on its own line. A free kick saw Beau desert put the ball into the air, and a scrum followed. Loose play resulted, and Panitz sent Wellinrrton over. Panitz raised the flags with a great kick, and Beaudesert led 11-6 after 18 minutes. The next Beaudesert try was an easy one. Starting at half Way the baT was slung about, for Panitz to give Wel- lingtqn the honours. Panitz missed this time, and 13 minutes of play remained. Five minutes later Wellington re ceived well out near half way. He raced infie'd for an opening, and when that was closing, he wheeled, and swung out again, to swerve back, and make a gap that allowed him to finish under the uprights. Day missed a sitter. A few minutes later Holden kicked a, field goal, and the score was 17-8. With a minute to go Panitz received, and, swerving in, he 'threw the opposi tion out of position. He turned again, and touched down where the goalkick- ers like them. Dauth made no error, and the final score was 22-8. THE PREMIERSHIP Beaudesert Club is heading the premiership competition with ten points. Christmas Creek has two less. The three clubs have ""played" six matches each, even though some were won when clubs forfeited. There were two in the third round. Christmas Creek getting two wins without having to play. The fact that the Ambu'ance Cup match was also made a fixture com pleted the competition. With the right of challenge, Christ mas Creek will play off with Beaudes ert. The position in the competition is:' I d -S I 3 alls! Beaudesert .... 6 6 1 -10 Christmas Ok. .6 4 2 -8 Canungra .. .,6 - 8 -

articleText:
Beaudesert Ambulance Report

"The Committee has interviewed the Architests, Messrs. Hall & Phillips, about the proposed New Ambulance Build.ng, and the plans submitted by them has been accepted with a few minor alterations. The Building is to be a two storey brick building, with a t.le roof, and will include a plant room

to accommodate lour Cars. The est.mated cost is between £6000 and £7000. With the money on hand, plus a loan of £1500, free of interest from the Q.A.T.B! Executive Commi.tee, it leaves a ba ance of approximately £1500- to be raised, and we feel confident that th s amount will be forthcoming. Captain E. R. B. Pike, General Secretary to the Q.A.T.B. Execuave Comm.t- tee, alter viewing the plan, remarked ihat he was pleased we inte.ided to build a modern structure, and that It would be .a credit to our town and district, and also to the QA.T.B." s.atgd the President of the Beaudesert QA.T.B. Committee (Mr. T. J. Enright) in his annual report. The report adds: In presenting this the Eighteenth Annual Report and Financial Statement of the operations of your Brigade during the year ended 30th June 1946, it gives me great pleasure to record another period of sound progress, and to express your Committee's high appreciat.on of the continued support ac corded to the Beaudesert Ambu.ance from ail parts of tr.e community, which may be regarded as a confirmation of the Subscribers' confidence in those who have charge of the administration, and the efficiency of the Staff of your Centre.5 : ' The "Calls" upon the services of your Brigade during the year were numerous. -The number of cases and mileage show.;, an increase on ths pre vious year's activities. Cases attended to were 2576, showing an increase of 40/ cases. The mi cage travelled was 33,511 miles, being an increase oi 7237 miles. We sincerely uust you feel p.oud tnat y-.ur district possesses t.'.is excel.ent Ambu.ance &civ.ce. The bene,. us rendeied by the Ambu.ance du.mg the year demonstrate, the efficiency oi your Brigade. To the membeis of our Ambu.ance Lad es' committee, we wish to express our sincere thanks, and desire to p.ace on record our appreciation and grati tude for the consistent enthusiasm displayed by the lad.es. During tne year just ended our ladies raised £116/2/2 wnich proves tnat without tne Lad.es' Committee's aid, our Ambulance functions would not have ceen the great success they have been. Again your Committee acknowledges its sincere thanks to the members of the various district Benef.t Committees, for their continued efforts on our behalf. Your Ambulance Centre is under- a deep debt of gratitude to these many persons who have generously devoted so much of their time to this charitaDie work. During the year, Benefits which have been held have proved very successiul — £615/3/6 was the result of their efforts. The Honorary Centres at Chr.s.mas Creek Hillview, Tabooba, Tamborlne Mt., Gleneagle, Lanungton, Barney View, Mt. Gipps, Lahey's and Bucnanan's Mi.., are ah doing an excellent service, and your Committee tender to the Hon. Bearers in cnarge of these Centres, tneir sincere thanks and apprecia- t.on lor the sp.endid services rendered. The Br.gade S aif consists of Superintendent Arthur Dux, who also is our Secretary, Bearer M. Pryke, Hon. Bearers James Gill, Edward B/own, C. W. Timms, S. N. Coe, R. G. Bartlett, and Hon. Memoers F. Silcox, K. Rohan T. R. Doyle, W. Carroll, B. Moioney, and Harvey Lahey. The Com mittee realize that they have an efficient and loyal officer in Superintendent Dux, and are thankiui to lun for his organizing of so many suscessfu, func tions, with the result our revenue from this source was £615/5/6, an increase of £11/19/3 on the previous year's activities. Bearer M. Pryke is also a most efficient officer, and always attentive to his duties. Both Hon. Bearers J. Gill and C. W. Timms have rendered valuable assistance to the Brigade dur ing the year by being on duty at the Brigade centre when required. Mrs. Dux has been most helpful during the absence of the Staff, attend.ng to calls and helping in various oilier ways. We are extremely grateful to her for this va.uabie assistance. The Brigade's Plant consists of One Mercury Ambulance 1942 model, One International Ambulance 1939 model, One Fontiac Ambulance 1942 model, One Whippet Car, also One Bicycle. During the year your Committee pur chased through the State Stores Board from the Army Disposals Commission, one 1942 model Pontiac Sedan. This Sedan is being converted into an Ambulance Oar, and it. is expected to be placed in commission during July. The Beaudesert Centre Ambulance Cars are fitted in every detail to ensure our patient's every comfort whilst being transported. The mileage travelled by the Ambulance Cars is steadily mounting up; the Mercury Ambulance has now travelled 29,418 miles, the International Ambulance 71,978 miles, whilst the Fontiac Ambulance has travelled 424 miles. The Financial statement covers the whole of the operations of the Brigade. The year commenced with a Credit Balance of £542/19/6 in the General Account, and a Credit Balance of £2750 in the New Ambulance Build ing Fund account. The year c.osed with the following Credit Balances. General Account, £1710/5/4; and the New Ambulance Building Fund account, £2750. In accordance with the requirements of the "Hospitals Act," an election for a committee for the next three years, was held in April 1946. The follow ing contributors were dmy declared elected by the Returning Officer: Messrs. T. J. Enright, John Aldrldge, William Schmidt, F. Hodgson, J. E. Jerome, H. E. Badke, William Lesley. During the year your Committee held 12 ordinary meetings, and 2 special meetings. At the first meeting of the Committee, after the Triennial E.ection, the following members were elected to the following office: Chair man, T. J. Enright; deputy chairman, William Schmidt; treasurer, John Aid- ridge; executive representative, T. J. Enright. Attendances at Committee meetings were as iollows: T. J. Enright (13), William Schmidt (14), John Aldridge (13), F. Hodgson (11), H. E. Badke (10), W. P. Daley (7), J. E. Jerome (4), William Lesley (1). We find it diff.cult to adequately express in a suitable manner our deepest gratitude to ihe many who have assisted the Brigade during the year. Our very sincere thanks are accorded to the excellent team of helpers who spared no elfort to assist with our Chocolate Wheel, and I can assure them that the Beaudesert Centre .s deeply grateful for this very valuab.e assistance. Our sincere thanks and apprec.ation are accorded to the public generally, Sports Commitless, (lie Medical Profession, Matron and Nursing Staff of the Beaudesert Hospital, Societies, Associations, Football C.ubs, Police Off.cers, Postal Authorities" the Beaudesert "T.mes," to Mr. Aldridge lor aaowing Hon. Bearer Gill to leave his work in cases of emergency; a;so to Mr. Knowies for h.s generous gestures, and fina.ly ail iirms wno have kindly deducted their employees' Contributions, and the business houses who ahow our collection boxes to be placed on the.r counters. The Treasurer's report read: It is with pleasure that I present the Financial Statement of the Beau desert Ambulance Centre, for the year ending 30th June 1946. It reveals a/ain the public's confidence and support wh.ch our organiza tion has so consistently received during past years. For this our thanks are due to a great extent to the members of our Ambulance. Contribution Scheme, organ.zers, and promoters of benefits. The year commenced with a Credit Balance in the General Account of £542/19/6, and closed with a Credit Balance of £1710/5/4. Your Committee did not transfer any monies into the Building Fund Account during the year, as it is their intention in the very near future to commence with the erection of a new Ambulance Building. The BuLding Fund Account commenced the year with a Credit Balance of £2750, and closed with the same amount in credit. In reviewing the Financial Statement for the year, you will notice that income irom Subscriptions and Donations was £129/15/- more than last year. On- the Expenditure side of the Statement the only increases are those actu ally due to the extra work performed by your Centre, and also an amount of £315/9/9 which the Pontiac Sedan has cost to date. Your Committee has still to pay for the converting and painting of this car. By caraful study of our Financial Statement you will find that we have managed to keep our ex penditure at a minimum without endangering the efficiency of the Brigade. The following is a record of calls attended to dur.ng the year: — ACCIDENTS !>8(i. TRANSPORTS 737. OFFICE CASES (SEVERE 206, SLIGHT 1217). TOTAL OF 2576 CASES. Mileage travelled in connection with these cases:— FOOT GO." rujsr.ic CONVEYANCE 233. MOTOR MILEAGE 31,187. BRIGADE MILEAGE 2031. TOTAL MILEAGE 33,511 MILES. COMPARATIVE STATEMENT WITH PREVIOUS YEARS: Total Year Accident Transport Severe Slight Total Mileage 1939-40 240 405 214 388 1247 17439 1940-41 135 424 150 512 1221 - 16455 1941-42 144 422 151 565 1282 17568 1942-43 140 583 132 869 1733 21111 1943-44 201 665 153 909 1928 24658 1944-45 37'1 680 149 966 2169 26274 1945-46 386 737 206 1247 2576 33511

M. Selwyn Smith & Son advise that next week, owing to the fact that Mon day Is a public holiday, ttieirjiig sale will be held on Tsdayfand inOfdier

to get pigsaway in the afternoon, a staEt-4»HHje made at 11 am. Carriers "are therefore asked to note the altera:- tion in the day, and also the earlier starting time. Bacon pigs, porkers, and store pigs will be sold by auction, while baokfatters - will be purchased over the scale, at market rates. Carriers will be advised of the quota they can bring forward to the sale, so that sellers who have not already booked with the auc tioneers, should get in touch with their carriers, and make arrangements for the transport of their pigs.

articleText:
A BEAUDESERT CASE

In the Brisbane Criminal Courl on Friday, Ray Anderson (18) was charged that on May 13, at Beau desert, he attempted unlawfully to

kill Cecil Anderson, and that at the same time and place he unlawfully wounded Cecil Anderson, Mr. Justice Brennan told Mr. C. J. Cosgrove, who prosecuted, that he did not think the Crown had much of a case. . Mr. Cosgrove submitted that the youth was not Justified in using a lethal weapon. The Public Defender (Mr. W. E. Ryan) said that apparently the elder brother went berserk, galloped a horse at his mother, struck at her with a stirrup iron, and broke the jaw of a sister who had two babies in her- arms at the time. Another brother and the father had gone for the police, leaving Ray there, Mr. Ryan added. His Honour: What could he have done if he had not taken a rifle? Mr. Cosgrove then entered a nolle prosequi. In 'his opening, the prosecutor said that evidence would be that the father and Cecil were drunk when they re turned home about 3 p.m. on May 13. Cecil and his brother, Colin saddled horses and the mother spoke to. Cecil, for she thought fie would take Colin and get him drunk. Becoming angry, Cecil rode full gal lop at his mother. She caught the bridle. He dismounted and struck at her with a stirrup iron. His sister, Elsie, put her hands over 'her mother's head 'and took the blow, which frac tured a finger. Cecil hit his mother on the head with a piece of hames. Elsie then struck Cecil with the haimes. Mr. Cosgrove said that Cecil chased his sisters and struck Gladys, break ing her jaw. A report was then heard, and Cecil ran into the bush followed by Ray, who threw down a, rifle he was holding. Sergeant Holding, of Beaudesert gave evidence that Ray Anderson told him: "I had to do it. I shot him be cause he was fighting with the. family and my mother." Cecil Anderson, 30 gave evidence that . he got_ortiis horse to adjust the stir rup! His ii, 'Other spoke to him. He rushed towards his mother and told her to shut her mOllfh:-> -When,he got off he still had the stin'iip-jl'Qn. in his hand, but did not hit anybody -with it- Gladys hit him on thevhead .with a hammer and knocked him .down. He had no further recollection for a time after that, and did not see his brother Ray until after he was shot. Mr. Justice Brennan said- that he would recommend to the Authorities that, on Cecil Anderson's undertaking that he would leave Beaudesert with his wife and five children, part of a sentence he was serving for assult arising from incidents that day should be remitted.

articleText:
BEAUDESERT PIG SALE

M. Selwyn Smith & Son heid their regular weekly sale of pigs at Beaudesert on Monday last, when 400 nigs were yarded. The usual

representatives from looal bacon factories were in the market, but, owing- to the reduced number of prime pigs yarded, only one New South Wales buyer operated. Competition for all classes of prime baconers was well maintained at the best of recent rates, making 9d. to 91d. per lb., heavy descriptions at slightly lower rates. There was another big yarding of all claSses or store pigs, the continued dry spell and feed shortage forcing these descriptions on the mar ket. Three outside buyers operated, in addition to a limited local demand. Recent rates were not quite main tained, but sellers weie prepared to meet the market. Eackfatters were again taken over scales at recent rates. The following were the ruling prices: Heavy bacon pigs £4/1 u. - to £6/10/-; light to medium bacon pigs £3/16/6 to £4/17/6; porkers" £3/10 - to £3/14/6; forward store pigs £2/12 .'6 to £3/4/-; medium store pigs £1 15 - to £2/11.'-; slips £1/1/- to £1/12 : stickers and weaners 9/6 to 19 backfatters £3/19/- to £8/17/6.
