articleText:
| Classy Fields at Beaudesert

THE field for the Beaudesert Victory Handicap, of £150, raced at Eelhogan on Wednesday, was one of the classiest seen at a Queensland country meeting, and provided every justification for the decision of the Beaudesert and District Amateur Race Club to include a £150

open handicap at both the meetings to be held in May. The Victory Handicap attracted ten starters, and honours went to Doubtful, by Double Remove from Karawak, with Mannawonga and j Plutocrat filling the minor places. Bomb, John Apple, Fayhe, and I Master Gaine were some that failed to secure a place.

The meeting attracted the best at- : tendance of any for some time, and 79 i bookmakers, who paid £5/5/- each, called the odds. In addition, the I totalisator was well patronised, the : turnover being £442/10/-, which com- i pares favourably with the previous best i meeting. j Horses from Toowoomba and New- i castle had a day out, three from the i former centre winning, and the coal i city getting a double. The meeting went off without a hitch, : and, although the Stipendiary Steward : (Mr. G. Hunter) had a chat with sev- eral riders before they raced, there was : no cause to hold an inquiry on the : seven races decided. Fifty-five horses started, the best field being ten, with two of nine, and a like : number of eight!" : Monty's Force, who comes from Too- : woomba, carried off the Handicap Hack : of five furlongs, although the fast fin- : ishing Your Idea got within a short ; head of him after being»2i lengths in 3 arrears as they swung into the straight. : Fours, and more, were available about ; the field, with the winner starting at ' 6 to 4 on. It was exciting finish with j the judge the only man able to give 5 the winner.

5 Punters were given a posed in the 3 Fourth Division. They knew how good = Smash and Blue Cap were on the 2 track, but Red Mick and Hakoon were 2 unknown qualities, the former coming = from Newcastle, and being ridden by E stable jockey, Thompson. There was 5 money for him, and he started at 5 2 to 4, although evens was acceptable = to some. Smash opened at fours, drlft- E ed to sevens, but came back to fours. 2 Red Mick was as good as his price, and 3 won by three lengths. = The thiyd race, the Fifth Division, 5 provided another good finish, the 6 to 4 = Tavourite Hospidale, another Toowoom- s ba entry, just getting up to get the de- = cislon by a short head. Fives were E called about Winning Score, who ap- 2 peared to have the race in hand, s Badly placed in the early running E the 5 to 1 Condemn finished with a E dash to take the Sixth Division of 5 S furs. Price Hygeia and Our Force = led into the straight and failed to take E a place, Dawnle Standfast, the 7 to 4 E favourite, was second, with Gashfleld s third. E The Victory Handicap, of £150, over E 7 furs, attracted ten starters. It was jg a good betting race, with Doubtful |c backed from fours to twos. John Apple

drifted from fours to sixes, but short ened a point. Plutocrat, who made the running, was supported at fours, and Mannawonga at sixes. Plutocrat led to the straight, and then the favourite took command, and gave his stable a double, and jockey Thompson his sec ond winner.

Up to fours were available about McKinley, who took off the Seventh Division, of five furlongs. Black count and Lydon disputed betting honors, the latter being quoted with caution in the early stages. McKinley, always well placed with Black Count, had plenty in hand to win by three lengths. Your Idea made amends for his de feat in the first race by taking the last, the Seventh Division, of about 5 fur longs. The public support was strong, and he started at 6 to 4 against, with from "fours" the others. The local horse, The Wren, was badly away, but put up a good run in the latter stages. Bonnie Gain also finished well. RESULTS ' Handicap Hack Race, about 5 furs. MONTY'S FORCE, 8.5 (Morsillo) 1. Your Idea, 9.1 (Bennet) 2. Bonnie Gain, 8.12 (W. Brown) .. 3. Others: Mr. Doughboy, 9.3 (Walsh), Rahiri Blu 8.12 (Fisher), Burnbank 8.10 (Neilson), Palmon, 8.8, 51b allow (Bogart), Vain Mint, 8.8 (Chandler) Betting: 6/4 on MONTY'S FORCE 4 Your Idea. 10 to 14 others. Dividends 6/6, 3/6, 5/6. After playing up at the barrier, Monty's Force was with the leaders early, and gradually drew away to have 21 lengths to spare in to the straight. Your Idea, who had been running handy, finished far better, and the official placing was that he was beaten by a short head, with three lengths to third. Time 1.31. Forth Division, about 6 furs. . RED MICK 8.3 (Thompson) . . . . 1. Caution, 8.0, 51b. allow. (Towner) . . 2. Smash 8.8 (King) 3. Others: Blue Cap, 9.3 (Bennett), Hakoon, 8,5 (Briscoe), Alfresco, 8.3 (Finn). Betting: 5 to 4 RED MICK, 2 Hakoon, 4 Smash, 7 Alfresco, 10 Caution, 20 Blue Cap. Dividends: 19/6, 10/-. Hakoon made the straight early running, but Red Mick was in charge as they swung into the straight, and won easily by three lengths. It was a good race for secqnd, with Caution getting up to get the decision by a head. Time 1.162. Fifth Division, about 6 furs. HOSPIDALE, 7.10 (Wrigley) . . 1. Winning Score, 8.6, 51b. allow. (Wellburn) 2. Conglad, 8.8 (Bennett) 3. Others: Cast Well 8.6 (Williams), Mainfan 8.2 (Morsillo). Betting: 6M HOSPIDALE. 2 Cast Well, 5 Winning Score, 7 Conglad, 10 Mainfan. Divi dends: 10/-, 8/-. After hitting the front early Winning Score had two lengths to Hospidale and Mainfan with two to go. Hospidale finished far bet ter and just got up in time to win by a short head, with four lengths to third. Time 1.171. Sixth Division, about 5 furs. CONDEMN 8.8 (Williams) .. .. 1. Gashfield 8.7 (Genn) 2. Dawnle Standfast 8.10 (Sinclair) ... 3. Others: New Bint 8.9 (Byrne), Coo-

ing 8.7 (Bennett), Prince Hygeria 8.4 (Morsillo), Cavilona 8.3 (Hone), Our Force 8.0 (Finn), Auriferous Find 7.7 (Oakes). Betting: 7/4 Dawnie Stand fast, 5 Condemn. Cooing, Prince Hy geia, Our Force, 6 Gashfield, Cavilona, 7 New Bint, 20 Auriferous Find. Divi dends, £1/5/6, 9/-. 4/-. Our Force was first to jump, and Prince Hygeia ran into the second place, Our Force had a slight lead on Prince Hygeia as they swung into the straight, but the re mainder of the field was on them, and there was a great race over the final distance. The margin was li lengths with 11 lengths. Time 1.3. BEAUDESERT VICTORY HANDICAP about 7 furs. DOUBTFUL 7.13 (Thompson) .. 1. Mannawonga 7.3 2over (Towner) . . 2. Plutocrat 8.8, 71b allow (Robinson) 3. Others: Omapo 9.0 (Sinclair), Bomb 8.11 (Byrne), War Zone 8.8 51b allow (Heffernan), Fayhe 8.5 (Gordon), John Apple 8.2 (Morgan), Master Gain 7.9 51b allow (Rheadon), Marble Bar 7.2 111b allow (Bennett). Betting: 2 Doubtful 4 Plutocrat, 5 John Apple, 6 MANNAWONGA, Fayhe, 10 others. Dividends 15/-, 4/-, 5/6. At the half mile Plutocrat was three lengths clear of the field. Doubtful was running second, as they passed the three, with with another length to Marble Bar. Plutocrat was still in charge as they entered the straight, with Mannawonga out wide. Doubtful broke away to win easily by four lengths, with a length to third. Then came John Apple, Bomb, Marble Bar, Master Gaine, War Zone, Fayhe, and Omapo in that order, Time 1.322. Seventh Division, (First Division) about 5 furs. McKINLEY 8.4 (Williams) .. .. 1. Lyndon 8.5 (Wrigley) 2. Master Monash 8.2, 21b over (Finn) 3. Others: Black Count 8.13 (Ralston), Mr. Doughboy 8.9 (Walsh), Ahipo 8.6 (Sinclair), Ben Avon 7.13, 21b over (Rolls), Lilypal 7.10 51b allow (Towner), Descedo 7.8 (Bennett). Betting: 2 Lyndon, Black Count, 4 McKINLEY, £1/5/-, 3/6, 17/6. 6 Ahipo, 8 to 10 others. Dividends: Black Count went to the front early, but at the two McKinley had run up to him, with Lyndon a half a length worse. McKinley won easily by three lengths, with a length to third. Time 1.22. Seventh Division, (Second Division) about 5 furs. YOUR IDEA, 8.7 (Bennett) 1. Bonnie Gain, 8.4 (W. Brown) .... 2. Dhemell, 8.1 (Dwyer) 3. Others: Mon Lad 8.9 (Schultz), Little Golly 8.8 (Lee), Bonnie Gain 8.4 (Brown), The Wren 7.12, 5 lb. allow. (Towner), Vergold 7.7, 7 lb. allow. (Rob inson), Master Ruffian 7.0 (Genn). Betting: 6/4 YOUR IDEA, 4 Little Golly The Wren, 8 Bonnie Gain, Dhemell. Vergold, 10 others. Div. 12/-, 6/-, 12/-. Vergold was best away, and she and Dhemell set out together, but with two to go Your Idea -and Bonnie Gain were in charge. The latter went on to win by 11 lengths with three to third. Time 1«.

articleText:
beaudesert footballers prevail

(By H.R.T.)

After holding' their heavier and more experienced opposition until soon after half time Canungra Rugby League team went down to

Beaudesert to the tune of 31 to nil in a hard match played on the Sel- wyn Park "Flat" on Sunday. The match was to be a fixture, but when the official referee did not pnt in an appearance it was decided on a friendly game, with Doug. Sullivan as referee. The encounter served to show that Beaudesert has the material required for a good side, but the players will need to burn, not the midnight oil, but some of the early evening power in training. They fielded a good solid pack, with plenty of weight, in fact a little too much, when it comes to fol lowing on play, and backing up. More than one try was lost to Beaudesert because of the inability of the van guard to carry on, and be there when the fast moving backs were stopped almost within striking distance. The visitors did well to stave olf the opposition for so long. Their side was very light- in comparison, and gener ally speaking were mo:o youthlul. They stood a severe gruelling, and on many occasions made the mistake or keeping the ball in the ruck, instead o. slinging It out to the quarter line. When Canungra did finally pack up altogether, Beaudesert turned on sever al passing movements that had the hallmark of quality stamped all over them. Players were a little too keen to score, and did not take advaneage of the opportunity of making a practise of it. It is always advisable when well ahead in friendly games to devote energy towards working out moves which can be put to good use later. Beaudesert has two good wingers, who should produce the goods if they get the opportunities. That means that the inside men have to get the ball, and ensure that they draw their men. Time after time on Sunday inside men failed to run straight, with the result that wingers were crowded before the leather got to them. G. Wellington, a newcomer to the district, looks like being a scoring machine once he settles down, and K. Panitz should hold his own against anybody likely to oppose him in the fixtures. The Beaudesert forwards' gave W. Collins a good share of the ball, and he exploited several nice moves, with suc cess, but needs to have better under standing with his teammates for these tricks of the trade to continually pay dividends. . Better handling will come naturally If the team concentrates on its training. Canungra players were better condit ioned, but they could net stand the continued pounding of the opposition. Some unnecessary buffeting was en countered trying to play a heavier side at its own game when it adopted for ward tactics. Scoring opened when S. Callanan kicked a goal. Five minutes earlier

he missed a fairly easy one. Shortly after the interval Wellington was sent over' in the corner, Panitz raised the flags with a beautiful kick from a few yards from the side line. , Five minutes later a passing move ment in which the ball went out to Plunkett, and then to Panitz, saw the latter go under the posts. Panitz added the other two, and the score was 12 to nil. From loose play Dauth scored, but Panitz. missed. A movement in which Plunkett, Day and Wellington featured had its reward with Dauth scoring in the corner. Call anan missed. The ball was kicked well into the Beaudesert's territory from the kick off but Beaudesert turned on classy football to transfer play to within a few yards of their objective, Panitz secured and scored, for Dauth to earn applause with a good kick. With three minutes to go Wellington crossed, after shaking off several would be tacklers. Dauth missed. Scoring was not over because Panitz received the pill, changed direction, throwing the tired defenders off their balance. He had an open go for the posts. It was an easy one for Collins to kick, bringing the score to 31 points. The teams were: Canungra: Full back, W. Crooks; three-quartefs, E, Day, L. Day, G. Bland,. M. Day; five-eight, J. Finch; half back, T. Mahony; forwards. K. Holdern, K. Geiger, T. Graham, E. Rowe, M. Finch, R. Murphy. Beaudesert: Full back, M. O'Brien; three-quarters. G. Wellington, W. Day, T. Plunkett. K. Panitz; five eight, S. Callanan; half back, W. Colljns; for wards, R. Dauth, N. Freeman, T. Crotty, F. Callanan. T. Draper, T. Ald- ridge. SUNDAY'S MATCH Beaudesert team will travel to Christmas Creek on Sunday to meet the home team which has a win over Ca nungra in the only fixture match played so far this season. A second team will also travel to play the Christmas Creek B graders. The Beaudesert side is as follows: E. O'Brien, K. Panitz, ..W, Day, T. Plunkett, G.. Wellington, S. Callanan, W. Collins, A. Waters. T. Draper, T. Aldridge, F. Callanan, N. Freeman, R. Dauth. Emer gencies: T. Crotty. P. Callanan, T. Murray. The Beaudesert Club is keen to get sufficient teams so that B graders can be catered for with a competition. The following will represent their B graders at Christmas Creek on Sun day: O. Plunkett, B. Stuart, D. Day, N. Smith, P. Callanan, J. Plunkett, M. Barrett, T. Kassulke, R. Dauth, T. Murray, J. Murray; W. Draper. Transport will leave at 12.30 and the match commence at 2 p.m. WATERLOOS WIN Waterloos added another win to their list by defeating West End Pastime Club in a match at Davies Park last Sunday, the final score after an inter esting game being 17-8 in their .favour. Scorers for the home side were Gill and Hardy, and Davis kicked a goal. Trygetters for Waterloos were C, Crust, V. Everdell, J. Ferguson, J. Mc Arthur, W. Blow with the latter also converting.

articleText:
Beaudesert Milk Tops Test

HAIRY farmers were given very heartening news on Saturday when attending the annual meeting of suppliers to the Logan and Albert Co-operative Dairy Association Ltd, The Chairman (Mr, T. Flood Plunkctt) who is also Chairman of the

Dairy Produce Board, told members that he did not think that there was any occasion to hesitate about developing the industry further, and said that it should expand and establish itself during the next five years. Mr. R, L. Harrison, a director, and member of the Milk Board, informed the meeting that the last official tests of milk supplied to the Brisbane market had shown that this Beaudesert milk was at the top of the list of supplying factories as regards butterfat content and keeping quality, but he advised suppliers not to rest on their oars. The district had also increased its supply in time of drought. The amount of deferred pay available for distribution— £12,494/3/10 for cream, and £703/15/5 for milk— was the largest amount paid in this way. Cost of butter manufacture and sale of butter was shown at 1.71 d.

The meeting was well attended, the Chairman (Mr. T. Flood Piunkett) presiding. Also present were Messrs. H. Bruxner, T. Egan, A. Drynan jnr. and R. L. Harrison (directors) and the manager (Mr. W. Wilshire). Mr. Piunkett said that at the last annual meeting the matter of joining the Co-operative Union of Queensland came up for dscussion, and was han ded to Mr. R. L. Harrison for investi gation. As far as the board was con cerned it wns agreeable to joining. Mr. Harrison explained that the scope and objects of the union justi fied membership by co-operative asso ciations. There were 34 co-operative company members, and a great num ber of them were dairy associations. All the companies that took the trouble to find what the union was doing, and what it proposed to do, commended the work of the union. The membership fee did not come to much. He had no hesitation in recommending that they accept membership. On the motion of Messrs. Webb and Richardson it was decided to join the Union. ... In his report Mr. Piunkett said: "The amount of money distributed amongst suppliers for the term easily constitutes a record, being £24.449/17/2 more than tiie next best in 1940. The amount of deferred pay available for distribution of £12,494/3/10 for cream and £703/15/5 for milk, is the largest amount paid in this way. The amount of cream received, although not a re cord, shows an increase of 1,231,837 lbs. over last year, and the butter output an increase of 637,875 lbs.

"The milk department continues to expand. We handled 678,729 gallons during the year, which, w.th the sub sidy added, made a nett return of 10.86 pence per gallon to suppliers, whilst the average amount paid to cream sup pliers for all grades during the year was 1/8.60 pence, which compares more than favourably with other associa tions in the State. "In the balance sheet you will find that the total assets have been con siderably reduced. This lias been brought about briefly by stocks of but ter which were held pending shipment . last year having been cleared, whilst against this the reserves have been in creased. On the assets sicte you will note the item, Commonwealth interest free loan, this year has disappeared, as we have received this amount back from the Commonwealth Treasury. During the year we have purchased a

block of land and re-erected a nouse thereon, which will be available for rental to some of our employees. "The new wing to the factory cost £2957/15/8 and the extra plant £6088/16/-, a total of £9046 11/8. This new plant is now in operation, and should prove very efficient in dealing with milk temperatures, a previous difficulty. In the profit and loss ac count practically all items, with the exception of "depreciation," show a saving. "As the government is allowing a special rate on all new buildings and plant we have, on the advice of our auditors, taken advantage of it. Ice sales have fallen off due to the troops leaving. Interest charges show a credit of £611/17/7, as the Equalisation Com mittee allows bank rates on butter held in cold stores, which worked out at £1200/7/4, while your association actu ally paid £588/9/9, leaving a profit of £611/17/7. Profit from the milk section was approximately £5944. After pro viding for a deferred payment of 5d. per lb. for cream suppl.ers and one farthing per gallon to milk suppliers for the full year there remains a pro fit of £390/7/4. Of this amount your directors recommend that £100 be pro vided for taxation and the balance to reserve. "In the trading account the amount received by exchange was £50.896/10 9, Commonwealth subsidy £64,478/4/11. Butter Board refund to us was £2069/16/- from the pat siheme. The Cold Storage Federation continues the good work, and refunded £997/12/2. Dairy Products Co-op. Coy. continue to handle the sale and export of our but ter satisfactorily. The amount shown in the balance sheet does not include the amount received for 1946, which was not received in time to include in this year's balance sheet. "The Co-op. Dairy Coy's. Assn. con cerns itself with all matters pertaining to the dairying industry, especially Arbitration Court matters. The new contract price for butter arranged be tween the Commonwealth Government and the Minister of Food (U.K.) at the rate of 1/11 per lb. is an increase on previous contracts, but the method of Its distribution has not been decided up to the present. "Your directors would like to place on record the splendid results achieved by the management and staff which had many difficulties to contend with during the year. With our manufactur ing and sale costs at 1.71 the average price of 1/8.60 is a splendid result, and reflects great credit on all those con cerned." Mr. Piunkett said that on no occa sion in the past were the shareholders more indebted to the staff than they were this year. He appreciated their work very much. Mr. Piunkett added that they had spent a good deal of money on im provements to enable them to show results. The figures of the factory compared very favourably with those of others. The cost of production was 1.71(1. He was agreeably surprised to see the figures after the time they had been through. The figure was the second lowest of any factory figure they knew of. To Mr. Richardson the chairman said that the treatment cost of milk was Id. a gallon, which was the usual charge. Mr. A. S. Hudson said that as far as the manufacture of butter was con cerned a creditable return to share holders was shown. He viewed the future of butter with a certain amount of alarm, He was more concerned about milk. When things looked smooth he was inclined to look ahead to the time when the fall would come. Beau- desert's milk had been criticised as to quality. He thought that it was exag geration but It was claimed that the milk was poor quality. He thought it was the duty of the factory to go into the matter, and explore every avenue to see that the milk was improved. Mr. Hudson referred to the lead some " other interests were giving, and in stanced where one Northern Rivers, N.S.W. company would assist farmers by buying a bull, If required. He was not criticising the directors, but they might go Into this phase of trying to bring about , improvements. It was no use shutting their eyes to the criticism, and the more they advertised It the more they would boost their problem Along.

Mr. Hudson expressed himself as being 100 per cent. In favour of herd testing, and said that he thought every hera prov.dmg mi:k suould oe tested lor milk. He thought die matter was a factory obligation, ana die factory should pay ail costs and debit all sup pliers. He understood that it cost 3/- a cow to test, and lie personal.y was not going to pay that. Mr. Hudson said that it was worth inquiring as to whether they could provide milk for a company asking for 2,000 gallons a day. They wanted all the avenues of demand they could get. He suggested the possibility of regis tering as milk wholesalers m Bnsoane with their own floor. Mr. Hudson advocated sending the manager about to inspect other fac tories, and so bring back new ideas. If Mr. Wilshire had not been abroad he offered it as a suggestion. Mr. Hudson sa.d that he did not think the matter of a veterinary sur geon should have been put before tiie shareholders, and he thought the sub ject should be reviewed by the board, which had been put there by the shareholders. A veterinary surgeon was necessary in the district, and what he had lost by not havmg such services available would have provided 8 p.c. on the salary the veterinary would have been paid. Tiie d.sirict was big enough to provide a veterinary. Mr. Hudson said that the figures produced showed the ability of the di rectors to handle the affairs of the shareholders. Mr. Piunkett said that lie was pleased to know tliat the quality of the Beaudesert milk had improved and tliey had asked Mr. Harrison to keep a tag on the quality. Mr. Piunkett said lie had discussed the matter of herd testing with the Minister for Agriculture and Stock (Mr. H. H. Collins). He recognised that in any scheme unless tliey got the official stamp on it Is was not much good. In Victoria tliey were paying 6/- a head for testing. He aiso brought up the matter at the Australian Dairy Produce Board,, anil suggested that body be the foundation head of a herd testing scheme, and suggested it be done in the same way in all states. N.S.W. scheme was different to that of Victoria. His idea was to get uniform ity so that testing would be recognised all over the Commonwealth. The ad vantages to farmers would more than pay the cost of the scheme. Mr. Piunkett said that they had an inquiry regarding luriher milk but they decided that, tliey might get into difficulties over the matter. The dairy ing industry should take into consid eration. and as a matter of fact it had considered the matter, of a selling floor, the idea being that the farmer snouid get the fun benefit from his production. Previous difficulties might nave gone by the board with new legislation being introduced. The fac tory had been given a fair spin from its wholesaler. If they were going to look to the future, and hand their milk over to somebody else, it was not co operative. Mr. Piunkett said that it was a good idea to send the manager around. Nothing was done in New Zealand that they did not know. An expert told him it had been -proved that a bull put

the butterfat'int'o the cow, irrespective of the ability of the mother of the cow to produce. Hd also said it paid to have a veterinary to rush to if they had illness in their stock. Mr. Harrison said that a "recent report seen by him gave returns of two samples of milk from all sup plying factories. Beaudesert was at the top of Die list. Voices: Hear, hear. Although nn improvement in but ter fat and keeping quality was shown. Mr. Harrison said it was not wise to get too optimistic because tests varied, lie had always doubted the fact thai Beaudesert's tests were the worst of the lot. This time he was able to get the test officially. The daily average supply figures from July last year to August showed an increase. Beaudesert held its posi- t'on despite the drought. He did not think that there was a district that had maintained its supply as Beau desert had. Tn July, when the condi tions were good the figure was 2,100 gallons. Others were August 1,700, Sep tember 1,700, October, November 1,400, December 1700, January 1,800, Febru ary 2,200, March 1,800, April 1,900. May and June 2,000, July 2.200, and last month it was expected to be 2,500.

Mr. Harrison said that this showed the ability of the district to produce in probably the worst drought they had had. He said that the Chairman of the Co-operative Union intended mov ing to call the appropriate peop.e to gether to discuss the problem of a milk ttoor in Brisbane. Mr, Plunkctt said that tlje factories had been called together on a num ber of occasions. He was glad to hear the remarks on herd testing, and a vetenn., iy officer. They were things that were wanted badly. He thought they should go for a veterinary officer when one was available, and give sup port to a herd testing scheme. Mr. Piunkett said that it was not the fault of the factory that tliey did not have more coolh.g towers in the district. The producers did not come along with the readiness to put them in, and there was a shortage of trades men. There was apathy on the part of the suppliers to provide the equipment which would improve the quality of their milk. Mr. Piunkett said that the Butter Board was experimenting with home refrigerators, which would provide for household supplies and milk. He was informed that under mass production conditions the unit could be produced for £120. It was not ready to put on the market. They had involved the Commonwealth Government in help ing to finance the scheme on reasonr able lines. » Mr. J. Hopkins asked if members did not think that poor quality could be attributed to obsolete methods of transport, and referred to having to stop a vehicle for two hours to allow the tyres to cool off Mr. Harrison said that the milk fig ures quoted were for the factory only. Mr. Piunkett said that they could not get professional men to join the staff as there was no accommodation available at Beaudesert. It appeared that in the not very far distant future they would have to move the residence of the manager to the block of land on which they had built a cottage. If the residence was removed, they would have room to go ahead, because they could not expand the other way. Mr. Piunkett said that a milk tanker cost £5,000 and. it was made in Mel-

articleText:
BEAUDESERT HAS WIN

Although Christmas Creek came at them str-ngly at one stage in the Acond half. Bcaudcscrt's A grade Rugby League team revived,

and ' came out winners by 19 to 6 . in the second competition game of the season played at Ilillvicw on Sunday. The game was hard fought and, except for several splashes of smart football, lacked brilliancy. There was a fairly good crowd present to wateli the game, which was preceded by a B grade match which also went to the visitors. Beaudesert A graders had the upper hand, but the side lacked condition and finish. At times the side was given a severe buffeting by the men from the ' Creek, their forwards failing to stop the rush. It was only In the latter stages that their superiority became pro nounced, and they finished off the good work established earlier. Casualties were the order, tjie result of the ruggedness of the tussle. This meant a number of changes in the position of the teams. Christmas Creek was without several of their usual players, and two' who played in the first half of the B grade match made their second appearance, Beaudesert missed G. Wellington.

their star winger, who suffered an in jury several weeks previously. He played a week earlier, but it was decided to spell him on Sunday to give the injury a chance to heal. K. Farrell, who has been transferred to Casino, and who was to depart on Sunday night, played fullback, and was unfortunate enough to receive an in jury to the mouth. Shortly after S. J. Callanan, five eight, hurt his shoulder. Consequently Callanan went to the full back posi.tlon, and Farrell played win ger to Panitz. Panitz was one of the unluckiest players on the field. He is a strong run ner with his mind always set on the line, but almost without exception his team mates sent the ball to the other wing, and hq was left without anything to do for the greater part of the game. It was unfortunate that this happened. Beaudesert's forwards did not put the vim into the game that they did a week earlier. Aldridgc and Freeman were ever on the move in (lie open. Al though he did not show out, as he did a week earlier, Dauth did some good work in the rucks. It was understand able that he should be restricted in his efforts because he suffered an attack of malaria during the week. Frank Cal lanan was a tower of strength hi the open, and took part in several good movements. Collins and S. Callanan worked well behind the scrum, but did not have the understanding that is necessary for the pivot men to have with their quarter line. Collins has a , nice cut in movement, but has a tendency to overwork it instead of using his supports. O'Brien was given no end of work, and stood up to it well. Unfortunately he is prepared to take the dump more than he should, and he was given this far too often. Gameness is not every thing. Almost without exception O'Brien

was crowded when the ball got to him, because his inside men would do every thing but run straight ahead, and draw the attack before passing. If tlie cen tres could overcome this trouble their side would score more tries than they do. P. Deane, the Creek captain, was ever on the go, and he received a nasty bump over the eye which required medical attention. F. Sykes, a winger, has a good turn of speed, and will always be dangerous. Their half. Skel- toh, did some nice work, and K. Ryan, who started at full-back, but suffered a leg injury early in the second half, blossomed as a forward. The pick of the pack was McGovcrn, who was on the ball all the time. The vanguard de fended well. Both sides were too prone to keep the ball in the "pigs" many being satisfied to adopt soccer rules far too much. This robbed the game of much of its interest. The Hillview field is not all that it might be, and it is up to the home club to consider plans 'for its im provement. It is anything but level, and it would be surprising if all measurements conformed with regu- lations. Of course it is not the only 1 ' field that requires attention, the

i "Flat" at Sehvyn Park being anything but a perfect playing arena. i The game was in charge of Mr. L. | Corvi. of Brisbane, i Teams were: i Christmas Creek: Fullback. K. Ryan; ! three-quarters. F. Sykes, D. Doyle, P. i Deane, W. Dennis; five-eight, R. | Gudga: half, T. Skelton; forwards, D. | Cahill, H. Russell, D. Slater, P. Rohan, i V. McGovern, V. O'Neill. 1 Beaudesert: Fullback. K. Farrell; three-quarters, K. Panitz, T. Plunkett, i W. Day, E. O'Brien; five-eight, S. J. 1 Callanan; half, W. Collins; forwards, | A. Waters, T. Crotty, T. Aldridge, R. i Dauth, N. Freeman, F. Callanan. ! The game started at a fast bat, and i four minutes after. Christmas Creek I was awarded a free kick from a handy I I position, but Skelton missed. Beaudes- 1 1 ert attacked with vigour, each man tak- I1 ing .an opponent, but their handling 1 1 was bad, i The first score came after 17 min- i1 utes. Play was centred in front of the ' posts near the home team quarter line, Ji and Dauth threw out a long pass. The i ball went on to Day, and S. Callanan, i and then to Panitz who went for the J" line to top off a nice movement. Panitz i could not finish it off. J' Collins, S. Callanan and Plunkett ij were seen in the next successful drive, i Callanan initiating the move that sent i' Plunkett over near the sticks. S. Cal- '! lanan missed, and after 27 minute Ji Beaudesert led 6—0. '! Gudca caused a thrill when Beau- J1 desert dropped a pass near half way, "J and he transferred play to close to the Ji line. A scrum followed, and McGovern i1 went over from the ruck to open 'J Creek's account. Skelton missed. J i There were no further scores In the ij five minutes remaining to half time, i Ryan was hurt and was off for some J ' time, this causing a rearrangement .of i the Creek team. < Beaudesert had a worrying time i' when Deane intercepted, and went for i the corner. Farrell was equal to the i occasion, and spreadeagled him with a 1 1 beautiful dive.' Finally Beaudesert ' | kicked clear. i J Creeks went back again, and J i stormed the visitors' line. It was then V. that Farrell had to retire. Deane went

through again, and was held up- within striking distance. Dauth forced his wav through the resultant ruck, and saved (lie occasion. S. Callanan was injured, and he- dropped back lor Farrell to return and play outside of Panitz. Collins and Waters combined in a run, with Collins taking the ball over the line. Panitz missed, and the score was 9 — 3 .against the visitors with 20 minutes to go. Creeks were praying at their best, and from loose play Ryan went over for an unconverted try. Fortunes soon swung away from the homesiders. OTirien went down the wing, and sent in Day, and he inpassed to Collins in the open, who wrote paid to the account.. Dauth's effort was a good ono. and Beaudesert was now leading 14-6. The next try fame soon after. Free man intercepting near the Creek half way. He raced everything for the line., and Dauth raised the flags. A few minutes ol' play remained, and just on the whistle- Beaudesert was knocking at the door, with the score 19-6 in their favour. THE "B" GRADERS

The B grade match was something in the nature of a try-out for players. Beaudesert had more than enough men and the opposition was short, so they were given the visitors' surplus. Even then Christmas Creek changed players at half time to give some of their pros pective players a chance to show their worth, Beaudesert won by 5 to nil, J. Plun kett scoring, and Kassulke converting. The game was in charge of Doug. Sullivan, The teams were; Beaudesert: O. Plunkett, J. Plunkett,. Paul Callanan. B. Stewart, D. Day, J. Brosnan. M. Smith, J. Murray; W. Draper, K. Bishop, J. Kassulke, Rex Dauth, M. Barrett. Christmas Creek: N. Ryan, G. Gielis, H. Russell, T. Slater. A, Gielis, S. and L. Mugridge. A. Whitby, R. Davis, W. Connelly, C. Cahill. Beaudesert players assisting them were R. Wright, J. Mur ray, Jim Plunkett. A GRADE COMPETITION g b. - " & g to &' -2 2 S q S- p & £ 3 ft h Beaudesert 1 1 - - 2 Christmas Creek . . 2 1 I - 2 Canungra 1 - 1 Beaudesert and Canungra are to play in the first round. TOINTS SCORERS Players who have scored points in tlie competition are: BEAUDESERT Try Goal K. Panitz 1 T. Plunkett 1 W. Collins . . 2 N. Freeman 1 R. Dauth - 2 CANUNGRA Try Goal . W. Crooks - 1 L. Jerome 1 K. Gelger - 1 CHRISTMAS GREEK Try Goal V. McGovern 1 K. Ryan i ..... . 1 R. Morrlssey 2 1 D. Anderson 1 W. Dennis . . . . . J 1 , i \
heading: BEAUDESERT HAS WIN

articleText:
f Beaudesert Wins I Again

|S Beaudesert and District Rugby League further enhanced its chances of winning this year's Geraghty Cup competition by defeating South Coast League's representative A team in a match at Southport on !| Sunday.

Both sides had failed to score at half time and although in the lead tor a short period at one stage the scoring was five all until 28 minutes of the second half had passed, when Beaudesert scored and converted. Beaudesert's B graders went down by 34 to nil in a match in which they were badly outclassed, the opposition including players who would be welcomed with open arms by Beaudesert A grade teams.

After defeating Wynnum by 44 to 11. ana uoutn coast losing to wynnum uy llll 2d to 3, it was assumed uy many uuu, Beauaesert wouia nave an easy wai, out mis proved to be anyunng out me ease, u Beaudesert piayea tne siue as it came S oil tne field against wynnum. 5 On the other nana Boutn Coast S claimed that its side was weaker man s that which met Wynnum. 'three of tne r best players, it was said, nad been = dropped because they naa fanea to ac- - tend training. Arrangements nad neen S made to have the lormer weii-known" S footballer, Fred. Laws, coach the siue. S In view of previous experiences wnere = piayers did not put in an appearance it S was decided that those who did tram - should take the field on Sunday. Fred. = Laws had the side for two nignts, and = three piayers lost their places. E Against this is must be conceded that E Beaudesert piayers, taken as a wnoie, 5 have not had much footoail in recent s weeks, let alone training. = Never was the need for training as E a side more obvious tnan it was uu S Sunday. Xhere were stages wnen E Beaudesert was a spent torce, w.tn S its forwards standing about, and no- 5 body keen to go tor tne bah. xhere E were many close calls, witn sound r tackling the only thing saving tne E situation. E In the first half Beaudesert won 12 = of the 20 effective scrums, and ui the - second half me margin was 18-13 m = their favour, the figure mounting to- E wards the closing stages wnen Beau- = desert was on top. E It was generally conceded that Smith, r while he proved that he has not lost jjj any of his ability as a rake — lie was E N.S.W. hooker some years ago — was = wasted in that position because it took E him too long to get clear of the = scramble following scrums. When he = did get the ball In the open he made s up ground, although he has a tendency = to try to do too much on his own. Had E he been in second row he wouid have = been more useful to the side. E It might be different if the league S was short of a rake, but K. Geiger is E well worth giving his chance in this z position, Instead of on the line. = Anderson was a tower of strength to z his side, and set a good example. The - others flashed out at times, but not E as they have done in the past. = Collins worked like a trojan behind = the pack, but he was given little room z to work by the fast breaking oppjsi- - tion. He endeavoured to offset th-s by » going through the pack, but this told on his strength because he has not the weight to keep this up. Just the same he did not lose a friend, his tenacity winning him support. The back lino could do great things, if only it had understanding. With Wellington crowded almost every time he got the ball, he did not get the chances that generally result in scores from him. There was a re shuffle at half time, and Fanitz went in as five eight and he did not tail by any means. Morrisey lost some chances and caused some uneasiness at times. There were too many bad and dropped passes. Except for a couple of mistakes, S. Callanan, who was given more than a fair share of work, stood up to the strain, and saved many a dangerous position by his positional kicking and cool .handling of situations that were fraught with possibilities. '

In the first half South Coast was awarded 10 free kicks, and in the sec ond seven, and those given Beaudes ert were six and three respectively. . The match was played at Owen Park, Southport, which was a "sea" of dust. It did not need a scrum to raise' a cloud that must have made conditions very trying for the players. Spectators were allowed to sit along the line, and towards the closing stages ewas held up while spectators, who crowded onto the field, were ord ered bock. The visiting players and officials were entertained to dinner at the Grand Hotel. The President of the South Coast League (Mr. Proud), who

£ M twou iuo/u i vi ouubiipur i>, CAteuacU <x welcome to the visitors, saying that he i hoped they would enjoy themselves, and take away pleasant memories of i the outing. ,i Responding Mr. A. Dux (treasurer) 1 1 said that it gave him great pleasure i, to respond because Southport was his home town. He was very pleased to be i present that day, and he was sure that ,i all would enjoy the day. | There was a good attendance at the 1 1 game, but the sale of programmes net- 1 1 ted only £25, which must be considered i to be a poor response. ,i The teams were: | South Coast: Full back, R. Allen;' 1 1 three-quarters, A, Cheers, C. McDonald, 'i J. Melrose, C. Melrose; five-eight, P. i Melrose; half, R. Napper; forwards, A. Slingsby, C. Rankin, R. Slingsby, L. Smith, N. Smith, J. Menzies. " i Beaudesert: Full back, S. J. Callanan; i three-quarters, G. Wellington, K. ! i Panitz, P. Deane, K. Morrisey; flve- ? eight, T. Plunkett; half. H. Collins; for- i| wards, D. Anderson, W. Day, V. Mc- % Govern R. Dauth, R. Smith, F. Cal- J lanan. ' Two minutes after the kick off Dauth J - failed at an attempt at goal, and a minute later Allen assayed a kick for J, Southport. When play had been In pro- i Kress five minutes Beaudesert was de- ,i fending, but a free kick allowed them i to transfer play to half way. Southport J was moving nicely at this stage. Dauth made a good attempt at ten minutes, 1 1 and shortly after Beaudesert was with- i' out the services of Collins, who was off 1 1 for some minutes for treatment to his i nose. ji Panitz went away in a nice run, but J i his pass to Morrisey was weak. J. i 1 Melrose tried his goal kicking ability at i 15 minutes. S. Callanan cdme to light , with a nice kick when his side was in i trouble. Wellington initiated a move J i and gave in to Anderson, and he sent i1 Morrisey for the line, but the ball was i forward. < , A scrum in a handy position followed J i and when Collins saw he was hemmed | in by the fast breaking opposition for- i| wards, he went through the pack, i Smith secured next and tried to force 1 1 his way over, but he was grounded. The !i pressure was on, but Beaudesert was J i over-anxious, and was penalised in 1 1 ruck play three yards off its objective, ji The homeslders followed on from i 1 the free kick, and in a flash play had I been transferred to the other end of , the field. It was a close call when C. - J i Melrose followed on, but lost the ad- ji vantage when he put too much ij weight Into hia kick. 1 1 When the clock showed 23 minutes Panitz failed in a comparatively easy 1 1 kick. Five minutes later R. Napper i missed, and at half time there was no < i score. i The second session had been in pro- i1 press nine minutes when Allen raised i ! the flags to give Southport the lead. 1 1 It was only temporary because two 1 1 minutes later Morrisey had the honour i of scoring Beaudesert's first points, rip! Four or five of the side had handled;

and there was a scramble on the op position line. Tne uaii came from tne scrum, and Morrisey finished off. Dautn made no misiake, and the score was 5—2 in favour oi Beaudesert. Southport got nuvmg nicely with Beaudesert players well out of position. Colin Melrose raced lor the corner, with three Beaudesert players after, him, but he beat tliem. Allen's kick grazed .the bar, but the right way for Beaudesert, and the teams were level alter 17 minutes. Beaudesert set up an offensive and Panitz thrilled the crowd with his work. He gave to Collins, and he to Plunkett, but the latter knocked on when it looked a case oi shut the gate. Beaudesert was penalised five yards from the home line. S. Callanan ran up after taking the ball, and it was a close call when he passed back, but nobody was there to take the ball. Good t ickling retrieved the position. Play was held up while the line was cleared of spectators, Fanitz, Wel lington and Plunkett gained a good deal of ground, and Smith went through the ruck, but a breach was ruled when a try seemed certain. For ward play followed, and Dauth forced his way llivvgh. and paved the way for McGw o to . cross. Dauth's kick was a |n»nl one, and this put his side five jw.. is in tbv oe ' after 28 minutes.' Except for severe 'stag-" wbe, den . . port players made- a unvr. met .. .. pinned in their own o-!- rr. 1 remainder of the., gi- BeavwA. slung the ball about us if It were hot, but they could not finish off their movements. They were penalised twice in quick succession, but they came back again. Once they had Southport where they wanted them, but the ball was passed to the wing where the players were crowded instead oi to tin: inside where the way was clear, with three men waiting. Beaudesert was again penal- sed. Sound tackling by the visitors pre vented Southport mukaig the most of the advantage gained and there was no change in the position at the bell. A GRADE SCORERS Beaudesert scorers in the Geraghty Cup matches are: Try. Goal. G. Wellington 3 V. McGovern 3 K. Morrisey 2 1 W. Day l 1 K. Panitz 1 2 T. Plunkett . . . ; 1 P. Deane . . 1 R. Dauth ... . - 5 When it was found no referee was available for the B grade match Jim Gill, of Beaudesert, lormer well-known half back, and keen official, agreed to officiate. He made a good job of It. J. Furcell, a hefty forward, scored four tries for South Coast. Wintlj e- cured two, and converted five. P. y and Wright added one each. The naif time score was 19-0 and the game fin ished up 34-0. "B" teams were: South Coast: Pull back, N. Batten; three-quarters, A. Blah, N. Ruddy, R.

Schniderr, A. Lawrence; five-eight, S. Gates; hall, W. Wintle; forwards, R. Naumann, J. Mitchell, B. Bernoth, M. Wight L. Dolan, J. Purcull. Beaudesert: Pull back, J. Brosnan; three-quarters, T. Benstead, S. Parish, D. Rafter, P. Callanan: five-eight, T. Skelton; half. C. Cahill; forwards, G. Bishop, T. Kassulke. W. Dennis, B. Boike, N. Freeman, T. AlUridge. Beenleigh schoolboys defeated a Southport team 5-3.

articleText:
Beaudesert Bowlers Arrange Matches

MEMBERS of the new green sub-committee of the Beaudesert Bowling Club were congratulated by the committee of the club at the monthly meeting on Thursday of last week. Speakers said that the green had been put down in record time, and

it was a credit to all concerned. The meeting also discussed proposed matches with Booroodabin and Kyogle Clubs and fixtures were arranged.

Those present were Messrs. F. Hodg son (president). E. G. Dauth, H. P. Ebellng, Dr. Beet, M. J. Doyle, A. Hood, J, C. Grier, J. V. Shay, M. Blunck, J. Aldridge, T. Enright and Div Bogle. Opening the meeting, the President referred to the death of Mrs. Brownlie snr., mother of Mr. Ben. Brownlie. A motion of sympathy to Mr. Brownlie and family was carried by all standing. With reference to the revision of rules, it was suggested that the secre tary obtain copies of rules from differ ent clubs, to act as a guide. Mr. Doyle said that he had person ally got in touch with other clubs, and he had about half a dozen copies on hand. He had also contacted Mr. Win ning, secretary of the Q.B.A., who in formed him that the Q.B.A. intends drafting a set of rules for all clubs. Mr. Doyle thought this matter should be finalised before the annual meeting, and they should get busy and do some thing right away. Mr. Ebeling was of the opinion that nothing could be finalised as it had first to go before a special general meeting. It was resolved that the sub-commit tee meet at its earliest convenience to go into the matter. Referring to the purchasing of shrubs and hedges for the new green, Mr. En- right said he had written to Stanthorpe. Toowoomba and Warwick, asking what shrubs and hedges would be most suit able for the climatic conditions existing here, but so far had had no reply. Mr. Blunck passed on some sugges tions that had been made to him. It was left to the sub-committee to finalise matters. Replying to a question regarding bringing the club's honour boards up to date, the treasurer said they would be finished by April 3. An Invitation was received from the Booroodabin Club to send as many rinks as possible on a suitable Wednesday afternoon (preferably June 5), in re turn for which they would send rinks to Beaudesert on a Sunday. It was resolved that as many rinks as possible be sent on the day speci fied and that an invitation to visit Beaudesert be sent the Booroodabin Club. A letter from the Beaudesert Shire Council, stating it had no objection to the shifting of the fence approximately six feet was received. The treasurer's financial statement showed that at the last meeting the chedit balance was £224/18/2,. Receipts were £162/3/- and the expenditure £71/5/-, leaving a credit balance at, this meeting of £315/16/2. Accounts amounting to £89/17/3 weve passed for payment, on the motion of Mr. Doyle and Dr. Bogle. Whilst reporting on the new green, Dr. Bogle said that as it was Hearing completion he would recommend hand ing over to the green director that night. Dr. Bogle also suggested that the sec retary make inquiries to ascertain if a ball-bearing, split roller, is available. Reporting on the proposal to put down a new well, Mr. Aldridge said that as the cost of Hume materials and labour would cost £130/12/2, the sub committee was of the opinion that there was a plentiful supply of water in the present well, and the spending of further money was not necessary. The games director (Mr. J. C. Grier) reported that the Pairs Championship was well advanced. During the month the Patron's Pairs was finalised and1 .proved one <>:' the most enjoyable com petitions .so far played. The next round of the Cock and Tiger Competition would take place on Sunday, March 31, and to date everything was going ac cording to schedule. Mr. Ebeling (green director) said they were preparing for top-dressing in the spring, so as to level the green. This would give a faster and truer playing surface. The mower had been sent to Brisbane for repairs during the month

and had been returned in good order. A new tank had also been ordered. Mr. Ebeling also reported that during the next month he would have the club house floors thoroughly scrubbed. As the green director's term had expired that night, the appointment of a successor was before the meeting. Dr. Bogle was nominated but de clined the position, and Mr. Ebeling, nominated by Mr. T. Enright and seconded by Dr. Bogle, was re-ap pointed for the remainder of the year. Mr. Ebeling thanked the members for re-appointing him, and said he would do his best for them. He also appealed for their co-operation and assistance. Dr. Bogle moved that the new green be handed over to the green director as from that night. This was seconded by Mr. A. Hood. Mr. Ebeling spoke of the amount of time and work put into the new green by the sub-committee, and congratu lated the members on their fine effort. He was supported by Mr. Grier, who said that in spite of adverse criticism , at the start, they had kept at it and the green was a credit to them. | Mr. Hodgson, on behalf of the sub- : committee, said he doubted if they ; would have got the job done but for : Dr. Bogle. He was the main reason why ; the green was finished in record time, i Mr. C. Fisher's action in giving them i loam for top-dressing was also much ; appreciated. He had come to their as- i sistance at a critical time, and the soil I proved to be the best they had ever | submitted to Brisbane for analysis. The motion was carried. The nominations of Messrs. R. E. . Jurd and S. A. Barron for membership

ot tne ciub were approved and placed on the notice board. With regard to the proposed visit to Kyogle It was decided that preliminary arrangements be made and a tentative date be submitted to the Kyogle Club. The President's At Home was fixed for Saturday, April 13. Mr. Dauth said he would like to see the seats put in good order for the President's At Home. This was left in the hands of the green director, The arranging of a match between old and new Digger members and mem bers of the club was left In the hands of the games director.

articleText:
Win fox Beaudesert

By defeating the South Coast team by 27-9 in the Geraghty Cup j competition match at the Beaudesert Show Grounds on Sunday, Bean- desert and Wynnum have won three matches each in the competition, which entitles them to play off in Brisbane.

With the home side outraked, and very often outruckcd, it did very well to win, although the back division was far better than that brought from Southport. In addition Beaudesert was without one of its best open forwards, K. Holden, for all but nine minutes of the second half, that player having been injured. The gate takings were £44, as against almost the century when Wynnutn played earlier in the season. The only means of transport this time was by rail motor and car, whereas Wynnum League was able to charter a special train. The, reserve team won its first match of the season, showing vastly unproved form.

The Beaudesert side took the field as selected a week earlier, Had the backs received more of the ball the vic tory wouid no doubt have been greater. In the first half the home side won 12 scrums against 18 by the opposi tion, and in tne second hall they had nine to 15 against them. Beaudesert continually infringed, and belore half time, received but four of the 13 free kicks, and, after oranges, it was 6 to 2 against them. With so little ball the team did well to hold its own. At times Beaudesert unfolded brilliant football, slinging the ball about with abounden. Then at times Beaudesert was like a ship at sea. Players stood while heavy opposi tion lorwards barged through, reducing valuable ground. It was a tar better side than that fielded at Wynnum, but it will have to improve to nave a chance against Wynnum in the final. The material is there, and training together for several nights a week for a lortnight would work wonders. The selectors should have seen the, fallacy of "tieing" Smith up in the scrums. Had he oeen a free lance all the time he would have given more worry to the men- from the seaside. As it was he scored two tries, and saved his side some trouble more than once. After K. Holden had been hurt the . pack was rearranged, allowing Smith freedom in this regard. Holden made some good runs, but was not as outstanding as he has been. O'Neill was seen continually in the rucks, and, after he settled down, F. Callanan was seen in the open. Behind the pack Day started some scoring movements, and except for weaknesses in passing, the backs could not be condemned. O'Brien covered himself in glory by his topnotch per formance. Once he received the ball he took some stopping, despite his lack of weight. Cqlianan's fullback display was everything that could be desired, his faults being slight, even though he had to work hard. It was unfortunate that (lie setting sun hi the closing stages had the ball obscured because a try was scored through this.

Tlie outstanding player for the visit ors was M. Dowling, the diminutive hall back. He was a fast mover, and he gave some trouble, being so elusive, and receiving so much bail and pro tection from his forwards. M. Napper always seemed to be there when mere was a chance of his side scoring. The teams were; South Coast: Fullback, D. McMahon; three-quarters, T. Berrigan, C. Melrose, M. Napper, c. McDonald; five-eight, N. Wintle; half back, M. Dowling; for wards, J. Guinea, Ray Collings, L. Smith, F. Collings. C. Rankm, A. Slingsby. Beaudesert: Fullback, S. Callanan; three-quarters, G. Wellington, K. Panitz, P. Deane, E. O'Brien; -five- eight. T. Plunkett; half back, W. Day; forwards, V. McGovern, R. Smith, R. Dauth, V. O'Neill, K. Holden, F. Cal lanan. Smith went close to scoring in the first minute of play. F. Callanan kicked and Holden followed on and caught it. but his pass to Callanan was knocked on. Beaudesert unfolded good football, taking play half the length of the field with about eight players handling the leather as It was transferred from one sideline to the other. S. Callanan caused the opposition fullback to knock on in Ills own quarter, but the attackers stood back, and the oppor tunity was lost. O'Brien Intercepted a pass well over his half way when he was at his top. and he went to McMahon. He short kicked over McMahon's head, and raced for the line with several players handy. The ruling was a try by McGovern. Panitz did the rest, and, after 12 min utes, Beaudesert led by five points. Beaudesert started a movement from its own line. S. Callanan cut holes in the opposition, and took play to half way. The opposition came back, and' Wellington kicked out of touch just In time. Soon after Beaudesert was again called on to defend and this time Smith bustled through the ruck, and. was not grounded until he had reached half way. Beaudesert won a scrum awarded for a breach and Day, receiving, worked the blind side. He ran out to wards the line, at the same time calling instructions to O'Brien. The latter con tinued to run almost beside him, as if expecting the ball, but he swung in, and took an inpass at the quarter line. A race for the line followed. An op position player reached out for O'Brien's jersey, but just missed, and by that time O'Brien had crossed the chalk/. Panitz missed an easy one, and bis side led 8.0, The locals went up again, and In a scramble Wellington was penalised for pushing tlie opposition in an effort to get the ball. Two minutes later tlie leather was kicked to Panitz, who failed to get close enough to get Ills hands on It. It appeared to bounce off his legs near the knees. He picked up when it bounced, and ran to the op position quarter, and finished up 5 yards from the post. Panitz did the rest, giv ing his side a 13 point lead. Smith was responsible for starting the movement that gave the next try. He sent Plunkett down the middle of the field, and in turn he passed to P. Deane and he gave to O'Brien. That player went to McMahon. but appar ently he was doubtful if he could get the ball to his supporters when tliev

were ln.position. Instead of sending a doubtful pass lie poked the ball at Mc Mahon several times and that player swallowed the trick, and O'Brien was over. S. Callanan missed, and with four minutes to half time Beaudesert led 16-0. F. Callanan was seen In a- great run, but the visitors came back with a rush just on the bell. After lemons South Coast came back strong, and went at it with a will, pin ning the opposition In its own quarter. Holden started well back on his own. After crossing the halfway line he was tackjed, spearing into the ground with great force. This put him out of com mission for a minute. He was able to resume, but a minute later went down to a tackle. An examination revealed a fractured collarbone. Play had been In progress 8i minutes. South Coast got away and their play ers moved half the length of the field. Wellington downed his man when a try was In the offing. Ruck play followed, and Dowling went over. Wintle failed. Shortly after Smith' went over to the corner from a ruck, and Dauth failed, making the score 19-3. / Dowling was Injured, but was able to resume a few minutes .later. With his side under pressure, Wellington kicked ahead, but the ball bounced

high towards Beaudescrt's quarter, beating the locals. Napper secured, and he passed to Dowling, for him to score. The kick failed, and after 24 minutes, the visitors were 19-6 In ar rears. Smith scored a try, running ,irom tlie opposition quarter line. Dauth missed. Panitz set off from his own quarter, and S. Callanan, who ran up from the fullback position, was there - to take his pass. He dummied when he got to McMahon, and drew his man. While he may have got there by going on his own he sent an easy pass to Deane, who completed the remaining few yards. Callanan secured the other points, making the score 27-6. Beaudebert was now in full charge. McGovern and Wellington handled within striking distance, but they could not finish off. Then South Coast kick ed clear, and S. Callanan was unable to see the ball. He shielded his eyes from the sun, b.ut missed. Smith saved the situation when Napper had only him to pass. It was temporary re spite because Ray Collins charged over from a ruck. Wintle missed, making the final score Beaudesert 27. South Coast 9. ' Beaudescrt's reserve team won its first match of the season. The league started badly by playing a junior team, as laid down by the combined leagues, but apparently Beaudesert was the only league to abide by the rules. Beaudesert fielded its .strongest sec ond team on Sunday, and it made a good fist of it, although the forwards showed that they were lacking in con dition when it came to open play. Had a similar side been brought together earlier Beaudesert would not have been at the bottom of the list.

The teams were' South Coast: Fuilback, J. Bauniont; three-quarters, A. Blair, R. Schneider, G. McKenzie, R. Ryder; five-eight, S. Yates; half-back, H. Rankin; forwards, J. Purcell. M. White R. Stuart, B. Behr- endorff, R. Naumann, S. Reives. Beaudesert: Fullback, P. Callanan; three-quarters M. Barrett, T. Kassulke, D. Doyle, J. Benstead; five-eight; J. Brosnan; half-back, T. Skelton; for wards, T. Murray, W. Dennis, F. Sykes, T. Draper, T. Alclridge, K. Little. Beaudesert should have scored in the early stages, but it seemed that a number of players wanted the honour, and they hung on instead of passing out, leaving the home side backs In the clear. Finally Barrett went over. Beaudesevt was on the job immed iately. but could not finish off its move ments. After loose play on the line South Coast passed the ball back over its line and a player kicked It. Sykes who followed on fast took the ball after it had travelled only several yards, and he dropped on it to score, the result of keeping on the game. The kick missed, and Beaudesert led 6-0. Two minutes later and the visitors scored from a passing movement. Pur cell getting the honours. South Coast In arrears 6-3, was attacking at half- time. On resuming the visitors set up an offensive and soon bad the locals pen ned in their own quarter. Play had been' In progress ten minutes when Brosnan Intercepted, and placed his side in a good position. The side car ried on, and a passing movement fin ished with W. Dennis scoring. Sykes added the extras with a splendid kick, making the score Beaudesert 11, South Coast 3. Play had been in progress 17 minutes when M. White was taken from the field. With eight minutes to go South Coast scored near the posts after forc ing through a ruck, Naumann getting the honours. Purcell's boot made the score 11-8. Just on time the home- siders were defending but they kicked clear.
heading: Win fox Beaudesert
snippet: By defeating the South Coast team by 27-9 in the Geraghty Cup competition match at the Beaudesert Show Grounds on Sunday, Beaudesert and Wynnum have won three matches each in the competition, which entitles them to play off in Brisbane.

articleText:
Beaudesert Show Drawing Near

THE Beaudesert Show Carnival which takes place from 8th to 11th May, is expected to be much In advance of any previous show held in Beaudesert. The facilities for holding the carnival will be more in keeping with the great district in which we live.

The great improvement made at both the Beaudesert show grounds, and at the campdraft grounds, will enable the stewards to put the programme through with little or no delays, and the public may look forward with confidence, to seeing great entertainment.

At the Show, there will be five thrill ing trotting events on the new track, and to put the programme through. in good time, it will be necessary to keep at least two events going in the show ring throughout the whole period of the Show. New hurdles for the hunting events and a special high jump has been built, and with the new show ring in use, the jumps will be placed in a position of advantage where all pat rons of the Show will have a much better view of these events. The trott ing events will be conducted by a spec ial number of qualified stewards, who will spare no pains to keep this branch of the ring attraction in full swing. The hackney events will occupy the show ring centre, and all fast moving events, such as pony speed tests etc., will, of course, be confined to the new track. The grand parade on Thursday, May 9, is calculated to provide the greatest showing of live stock ever seen in the Beaudesert Show ring. In addi ction to our usual large showing of Jer seys, and A.I.S. dairy cattle, there will be five teams of Ayrshires which will add colour to the pageant. The generous prizes offered by the Society and the special prizes do nated by its supporters, have been responsible for entries being received from many great trotters and pacers, blood horses and hackneys, and it is already known, that in the sphere of hunting contests, a large entry is on the way from some of the best jump ers in the land. Preparations are also being made by the Society for a record entry in the fat cattle and pig sections, while poul try promises to be a record on this oc casion. A feature in the dog section will be large teams of Cocker Spaniels and other breeds from Brisbane, and at least one or two local exhibitors, and an exhibit of Great Danes. Visitors to the show will find the dog section a

most interesting one. Adequate arrangements are being made to control traffic at the show and campdraft grounds, and traffic police officers under Sergeant T. Holding, will officiate In tills regard. An officer from ihe Quneensland Automobile Club, with an effective staff, will supervise _a the parking of cars within Lhe grounds. The new arena and shutes' at tha campdraft grounds are nenring comple tion, and will be ready for use for the Bushman's Carnival. The "set-out" of the new arena is entirely different from - the old one. The new arena is pear shaped, with the cattle camp at the extreme end, and facing the grand stand. The removal of the old yards and cattle camp has eliminated the "bottle neck", which in the past has been a' "nightmare" to those in charge of the parking of cars. Special arrangements have been made to ' prevent the public from crowding the shutes, and every en deavour is being made to provide the public with a first class view of the carnival. The reserved stand bookings are heavy, and the secretary, Mr. E Henley advises all patrons to avoid disappoint ment by booking a stand without dehty as already the list is almost filled. Night entertainment during Show carnival week is in the capable hands of Messrs J. V. Shay, A. L. Lane and Harold Graham, who will announce full particulars in the columns of this paper in due course. The annual show ball and the campdraft dance will be held as usual, and other entertain ment reccommended iby the general committee will be carried out if pract icable. It is anticipated that at future shows the show grounds will be used for en tertainment, for with improvements and special lighting at the grounds, it will be possible to carry the Beaudesert Show on for two days and two nights. 1 =_
heading: Beaudesert Show Drawing Near
snippet: THE Beaudesert Show Carnival which takes place from 8th to 11th May, is expected to be much in advance of any previous show held in Beaudesert. The facilities for holding the carnival will be more in keeping with the great district in which we live.

articleText:
"Tmfes? excluded

Efforts of the Bwndesert "Timee" to have representation at the test match at. Brisbane on Saturday in order to secure/a' full, report M, the

match between prayers from the Beaudesert, Wynnum, and South Coast Leagues and a Brisbane re serve ' team .have been unsuccess ful,- the Queensland Rugby League having refused to provide the necessary accommodation. On Monday the "Times" sent the secretary of the QJtL. a reply paid telegram pointing out the strong dis trict representation in the match, and asking for press facilities. A reply was received that the limited press enclosure precluded acceding to the request. The. "Times" then wired : Your reply means Beaudesert-SouthCoast-Wyn- num match will not be fully reported by any newspaper. We require exten sive cover. Please reconsider. To that a reply was received yester day stating that it was regretted that the decision could not be altered. Efforts to contact the President of the Q.R.L. (Mr. V. Jensen) to lodge a protest against the lack of facilities for country reporters were unsuccess ful, it being stated that Mr. Jensen was away from his premises, smd it was not known where he could be contacted. It has been learned from another source that, there is little accommo dation for pressmen Rt. the Exhibition grounds, and that preference was be ing. given only to papers covering the test match. ' Consequently it appenrs that Beau desert readers will not be given the service to which they are entitled, par ticularly as they have seven men In the main curtalnraiser.
heading: "TIMES" EXCLUDED

articleText:
BEAUDESERT SHOW I FEATURES i TROTTING EVENTS

= Trotting events will be one of the 2 special features of the ring attrac- — tiens at the coming Beaudesert . — Show. 3

Over £60 has been allocated and = subscribed for special trotting events to open the new show, ring, and it is calculated that many of the champion trotters will be at- | tracted to the show for the occa- I sion. The ring is to be mown, and the track rolled and levelled during the next few weeks, and it is expected that the going will be little short of first claw on show day. The John Aldridge & Sons trotting speed test over one mile in harness for the ten guinea prize presented by this . firm, will be one of the main events, in which the fastest time will be recorded as the new track record. Wh'le the ring events are expected to be superior to any previous Beau desert show it may also be said that the dairy cattle and the pig sections promise to eclipse all previous records.

Prize schedules are nearly ready to be distributed and members tickets have been posted to all members whose fees are now due. In this regard, the show secretary has requested members to forward their cheoues for member ship fees early, so that they will be financial before the date of the show. The campdraft programmes have been distributed and preparations are being made for a record entry. This year the Collins draft prize money has been augmented by an extra £30 :i making the total prize money in this c event, £S1. E The Mnrkwell draft remains at £50, E and the Dry nan draft at £20 making = the total for the three big drafts total z £121. Members of the Collins family have donated £30. and Mr. E. C. Mark- z well £10, for their respective drafts, z while Mr. John Drynan has donated all E prize money nnd cup for the Drynan z Memorial Draft and a'so supplies su't- = able cattle for use in this event. Mr. r Kevin Tillev will loan cattle for the = Collins draft, and Mr. Burgho Joyce £ has generously lent cattle for the r Novice draft. £ The fat bulJock for the weight guess- ; ing competition at the Show has been s presented to the Society by Messrs. B. r Stephens & Sons whose generosity in = this regard, is most commendable. j The Show Society will need all the : support of the public to carry them : over the present period of heavy ex- ; penditure involved in the construction : of the new show ring, but the district \ will have every reason to be proud of : their oval which, eventually, will be one : of the best in the State.
heading: BEAUDESERT SHOW FEATURES TROTTING EVENTS
snippet: Trotting events will be one of the special features of the ring attractions at the coming Beaudesert Show.

articleText:
WHERE THE "TIMES" GOES

The Beaudesert "Times" has sev eral subscribers in America, and copies go (o many other places. Writing to her people, Mr. and

Mrs. G. Robinson, of Rathdowney, Mrs. Don Federson, of Columbus, Montana, mentioned that Glcm Byrnes, an American, had received a copy of the "Times" in which there was mention of a message from her. It would be interesting to know just where the "Times" is sent and if subscribers who forward their copies away would advise the "Times" of the addresses these will be published from time to time.
