articleText:
Beaudesert Band to Become Effective

THE Beaudesert Band, which has been In recess since 1941, will become effective shortly, according to information given a public meeting on Monday night. The meeting was held, following a discussion, at a Beaudesert

Chamber of Commerce meeting several months- ago, with a view to stimulating interest in the band and choral movement- Bandsmen indicated that all was well with their organisation, but although there were offers of assistance for a choir the matter of forming a society to control it was deferred for the time being.

Henvy rain had fallen throughout the day, and, although the night was clear, there had been indications that there would be further showers. This no doubt prevented many Interested people from attending. Mr. A. Hood, who had called the meeting at the request of the Chamber of Commerce, explained to those pre sent that he had the Idea of trying to Induce a capable musician to come to Beaudesert to take charge of the band and choir. -A capable man could con duct both the band and choir. Mr. L. J. McFadden drew attention to the difficulty of getting a house for anybody coming to the town. Mr. Hood said that he had thought of that. If they could get a suitable man they could pay him a subsidy. The band could practice on one night, the choir another night, and the con ductor would be free to take private pupils. They could make inquiries and find him a suitable position. Mr. McFadden said that as far as the band was concerned It was just a matter of starting It off. They should have a choral society as well. Both Messrs. Dauth and McFadden explained that the band was not de funct. It only went into recess during the war years because It had insuffi cient players. Mr. A. Huffey said they should en deavour to form an orchestra for the town. He would give any assistance he could. Mr. Hood said that Beaudesert was big enough to support a band. Mr. McFadden said that the band had a full set of instruments and uni forms. Mr. R. Houston said that it seemed that it required a decision to start the band moving. Mr. Dauth said that the band func tioned until members went away. The last of the members had returned, and he thought all the former players would be prepared to start off again. They had a committee and it was properly . constituted. Mr. Houston said that In view of the information given the meeting they were not In order going on with the matter. Mr. Hood referred to the fact that the band had not a great membership, and that if they secured the services of a good conductor they could raise the standard. Mr. Dauth said that the band re ceived poor support from the public in the past. It relied on the collection box taken around at public appear ances. He did not know if the band was appreciated. Mr. Hood suggested that the pro grammes could be made more attrac tive if they included vocal numbers in the programme. Mr. Dauth said that he thought they would get assistance for the choral movement from bandsmen. Mr. Hood said that while there were no prospective choir members present several ladles rang to say they were behind the move. Ministers of religion at Beaudesert also expressed interest. He was sorry that they were not pre sent, but it was a bad night. Mr. McFadden: The band is well set up. It Is only a matter of deciding when it will start. Mr. Dauth; We have £4 In the bank.

When Mr. Houston asked If the meeting could request the band to start off, Mr. McFadden said that they could get 12 players without any .trouble. The highest number they had had in the past was 15. Mr. Dauth: We have had up to 18 players. The band went to the Bunda- berg contest In 1920. ' It included some Beenleigh players. Mr. McFadden - said that the band had been asked to play on Anzac Day, and it looked as if they could accede to the request. Mr. Hood: Let us try and get the public behind the band. Mr. Dauth: We received poor public support. Bandsmen received nothing out of the band, but played for the love of music. The band asked for the support of the Council but did not re ceive a subsidy. There were several donations. Mr. Dauth suggested that they leave the meeting stand in abeyance and the band call a meeting to see how it shaped. Then they could endeavour to- start the choir. The band would assist as much as possible. The attendance that night was not a fair test of public interest. . Mr. Houston said since the Cham ber had discussed a suggestion that efforts be made to cater for young , players, four fathers had spoken to him. TTiey were keen to have their sons learn to play an- instrument. He thought they should recommend to the band that something of that na ture be done. Mr. McFadden said that the band had always encouraged young players. They were invited to attend, and mem bers gave them all the help they could. It was agreed that boys should have a tutor to. teach them the rudiments of music before they-, went to the band- room. It was felt : that it was too big a handicap to teach a boy music when the band was practising. Mr. McFadden said bis Idea was to foster a band at the school. They had some old instruments that could be used if they had somebody to teach the boys, Mr. Hood said that he thought the meeting that night had not been called before time. Mr. Houston: It is up to the public to sponsor the movement, and not. leave it, t6 the band. It seemed that there . was a lack of finance in the past. The public benefited by having a band, and he could not see why they could not raise sufficient finance for the pur pose. A band was an acquisition to the town, and concerts on a summer's night were an education. Mr. Hood: It Is up to the Council jand other bodies to get behind the ''band. It Is possible to get players If you can get them a job. Distancing the lack of encourage ment given the band, Mr. Dauth said p that on one occasion the Show So ciety brought a band from Ipswich, ; and paid It £60 to play at the camp ! draft.

Mr. Hood said that there was noth- ! tog much for growing boys to do at Beaudesert but knock about the town. : It was decided that the band hold. ' its annual meeting on Monday night. Mr. Hood said that Beaudesert had . the voices but nobody to bring them ' out. . They could get a nicely balanced . choir. He had heard five or six good voices at the bowling club, but the members concerned did not realise that 1 they had good voices. 1 The matter of forming a choir was deferred for the time bring.

Miss Pauline Pehrson, who has been on the staff of -the school since last August has been appointed head teacher of the State School at Wooren- den, near Murgon, and left for that centre on Wednesday. So far it is not known whether Miss Pehrson will be replaced. For a considerable time Mr. H. V. Lahey has been sending some splendid magazines which have been of great use to the school. He has now arranged for the school to receive every month from America a copy of the National Geographic Magazine. The school is very grateful to Mr. Lahey for his gen erous action. Thanks are also expressed to Mr. G. Tranter for.-mi.king a truck available to transport the children to the river for swimming lessons. Some fifty child ren are carried each visit and quite a number have made good progress with their swimming. Every month the Education Depart ment, as part of its Adult Education Scheme, arranges for educational films to be screened to the" school room. About three thousand feet- of £ lfij £15 shown, the subjects covering a wide field. Parents are Invited to be pre sent at these screenings. There were satisfactory attendances at the screen ings held so far this year. There Is no charge for admission.

articleText:
"TIMES" IN CHICAGO

Writing to the Beaudesert "Times" Clemens Berens, of 6967 Ravenswood Avenue, Chicago, U.S.A., states:

"The "Times" arrived here very promptly, and I want to thank you for sending it. I enjoy reading it very much as I am acquainted with many people in that district. I intend sub scribing to the "Times" indefinitely. "It takes about three months for a letter to go back and forth by regular mail. "There are many boys here in Chic ago who were in Round Mountain at one time, and I am giving the "Times" to them after I am through reading It. Every one wants the paper .first, and

field. It had been stated that an 8st. limit had been decided on, but Wyn num had some hairylegged boys. Beau desert had lads like Frank Parrish. of Canungra (who played in the B' grade - team) who could have played with the schoolboys. The letter could be re plied to in a lot of ways. It was stated that 6d. a billy of hot water was sufficient charge. Mention was made of the fact that .the combined meeting of Geraghty Cup leagues decided on a B grade competi tion, and Wynnum had nlayed a sec ond A grade team against Beaudesert's B graders. ( It was decided . to ask the Brisbane Rugby League for a ruling for future games. The balance sheet of the Geraghty Cup game showed that £l'9/3/4 had been received for refreshments sold at the grounds, the profit being £4 0/1, and the profit on £31/5/- turnover in the drink stall was £16/3/6. The good work of the eight ladies working In the refreshment stall was referred to, and they and the gate keepers are to receive 15/- each for their assistance. Dealing with the complaint about meals for the visiting schoolboys, the President and others said that they were under the imoressinn that the boys were being given a sit down meal at the showgrounds. A pie and drink was not a sufficient meal. Mistakes had been made but these would not have to occur again.
heading: "TIMES" IN CHICAGO

articleText:
Brisbane Milk

Bid by Beaudesert Producers

MILK producers in the Beaudesert district are to make a determined bi£ to capture a greater portion of the Brisbane mlik market during the coming winter, and, wTjth this in

view, the Beaudesert Branch of the Country Milk Association has put the mjghinery in motion so that when there is a csHI for in creased quotas during the cooler , portion of the year the demand can be met iniiinediately. IT WAS CONTENDED THAT BEAUDESERT; ' «ECAUSE OF ITS CLOSE PROXIMITY TO BRISBANE, WASiTlTLED TO THE MARKET IN PREFERENCE TO CENTRES ON THE DARLING DOWNS. - A sub-committee of dairymen and milk carriers ;jvii& elected, and the members are to collect the necessary information as to pro bable suppliers, and milk runs for the benefit of 'jjpub-committcc comprised of Messrs. E. V. Kenny (Chairman) ,»iR, . L. Ilarriscn (secretary), W. Wilshire (Manager of the Logan'diitl Albert Co operative Dairy Association) and A. S. Hudson, whtfwill arrange a meeting of both committees in the first week in Apirii to complete the preliminary arrangements, "vi'/v

It was emphasised that there was no certainty that those approached would become milk suppliers, but the scheme was being put into operation so that no time would be lost organising runs if there was a call for more milk from week to week, Opening the meeting, which 'was at tended by about 40 people, some of whom were not milk suppliers at pre sent, the Chairman reported on doings at the Central Council meetings. He said that the wholesale company pur chasing their milk and the Milk Board had put up a better fight than ever to maintain quotas. When the question of Norco, and its supply of a thousand gallons, came up he asked how many members were prepared to guarantee to supply Norco's quota. They had to be prepared to maintain a level that would supply the market all the year round. He contended that if they were going to maintain production the Eoard should leave the quota months alone. ' Mr. Kenny said that they were going to receive 1/8 a gallon this winter. The Council was of the opinion that the milk was still worth 1/ 111. The. Federal Council was putting up a fight to get 1/10. ' ' " "I would like to -warn you regard ing the concentrates position" added Mr. Kenny. "Concentrates are going to be short, and wheat is going to be shipped to England. I am passing this on to you so that you will not wait until July and August to pur chase your supplies." Mr. Harrison said that he did not think the milk position would be any different this winter to that of last

winter. He thought more milk would be required on the Brisbane market. During the last few years they had to draw on supplies from outside areas. There was a temporary arrangement with Warwick last year, Toowoomba factory, and its district was about the biggest supplier. Autumn of last year was a difficult period, and milk was short. Mr. Harrison said he wanted Beau desert to be in a position to answer the/call if Br'sbane wanted extra milk. Last year Toowoomua i.i.isced on a quota, and received 1:. Nobody would come and force the dairymen to supply milk to Brisbane, and it was a- case of them being prepared, and able to advise Brisbane that the district was organ ised to meet the demand. Mr. Harrison said that often react ion followed a good season. Farmers had not been able to plant much feed and the concentrates position might be difficult. There was a tremendous opening for the milk trade in the dis trict. About a fourth of the dairymen supplied milk. "I think the district is getting more milk minded and I think it is better for the district. You will have to organise extra runs, and see if the factory wlU be able to handle the extra milk if you want to go for the extra trade," said Mr. Harrison. "The increase will be gradual. I think, if anything, the wholesaler in Brisbane we supply prefers milk from the Downs. . Last year they asked if Beau, desert could supply extra milk im- 'mediately, .but this was impossible. They said ihey wanted the milk and they had to go to Toowoomba for it." Mr. Harrison forecast an increased demand on the Brisbane market. He said he hoped that it was not restricted to milk. The regulations governing the control of fresh cream were not going to last for ever, and he looked to the time when the fresh cream trade would be an adjunct to the milk trade. Bris bane would provide a profitable market, Mr. Wilshire, when asked if the fac tory could'handle more milk, said that when the flood was on, and the sup pliers could not get their milk, to Bris- bane, the factory, without turning a hair, handled the milk. He was not going to say that it did not create dls- - organisation. It meant overtime to

the staff, but they coped with the position. When tiley had the new milk machine in opera|tjpn the factory would be able to hanftfe/?,fne extra supply. Mr. Wilshire ,'said?that before an ap proach was maH6j.to Toowoomba last year he advised,' Vtheit he had two runs ready to go interfile milk trade. The next thing he heftrjd was that Brisbane wholesaler had goh| to Toowoomba for the milk. He''urfd6rstood two runs were ready to changeover and there were others who migi)fjbe prepared to do the same thing:- Mr. Hudson suggested appointing a subcommittee' tl/twork out a scheme and report to a .father meeting. They were closer to. the;, market and had a shorter haul than'jToowoomba. They could ascertain', 'fie requirements of the Milk Board.>;. ; The President' 5saM ihey wanted the views of membersvc. at. The Seci'etary;9i:u<l the first thing was to get suitable runs. lie knew of good areas not? touched. They were going to have: suv headaches, but what was wanted" w:i; a whole cream run to turn overtf o milk. There was no intention to "finalise the cream producer. """"--X' i Mr. G. Masen said the milk was available in the district. I Mr. Wilshire said that the factory had dual carriers. They were against forcing a man from cream to milk pro duction. Mr. Harrison said he hoped that no body thought the proposal was an in vitation to start supplying milk im mediately. Milk supplies would de crease in April, and the decrease would be gradual. That meant they would call for additional milk to supplement the supply. Indications of the position would come from the wholesaler, who would go to the Milk Board. Any new suppliers would be protected regarding quotas under the Milk Act. They would only take on new suppliers cau tiously. V Mr. Kenny said that they wanted to leave individual suppliers alone for the present, but new suppliers would go through the factory. The following were appointed a sub committee: Messrs. Lewis (Tam- rookum), Masen (Rathdowney), Mur phy (Innisplains), Hugh Campbell (Christmas Creek), T. Thwaites (Nin- dooinbah), T, Rodgers (Tabragalba). They are to confer with cream carriers in their locality, and other suppliers, and forward the information to Messrs. Kenny, Harrison, Hudson and Wilshire. Mr. Hudson said they should work through, the factory; and get all the necessary information from the Milk Board. He thought the directors of the factory were getting more milk minded than they were. The factory should be in a position to advise the Milk Board of the position if it asked for more milk, and then moke the necessary arrangements to handle the milk. It was decided to have all informa tion collected for a meeting of the committees in the first week In April.

articleText:
More Racing Records

Beaudesert Meeting Well Patronised

fHE Beaudesert and District Amateur Race Club meeting on Wednes day provided keen racing, interest being added by the fact that a record number of bookmakers — 113 — fielded on the eight events which had 66 starters.

The weather was ideal, The track was a little dusty, but otherwise it was in good order, ' V The policy of the club in maintaining high prize mi;cy is bringing results, if the large attendance, a record for other than the last Melbourne Cup meeting, is any indication of the trend,

The club originally decided to race for £450, but it was necessary to divide two races, the Hack and the Seventh Division, because of the record eqtViesi received. The extra division meant, an increase of £70, and the "Hack £10. The outlay would be somewhat off- set by the fact there were 113 book makers, who' pay £5/5/- each for the right to field. A locally produced mare, Rivqpal, owned and raced by H. L. Ludwlg, pleased the bookmakers by winning the Second Division of the Hack Divi sion at up to tens. Several other heavily backed favour ites were defeated and one winner, Speaker, did not carry much money, as the fielders were not keen to take money as they wourd be unable to bajanee their books on the small field. In all 66 horses started in the eight races, the average being pulled down by the First Division of the Seventh Division, whioh had a field of five only, Always well placed, but serioUsly challenged by Glenusk when the pres sure was on, Akbar, ridden by George Moore, won the opening event, the First Division of the Hack Handicap. Some punters got threes about the winner, but towards the close of bet ting was generally quoted at 5 to 2. Glenusk and Speaker were the only others to be considered. Bronz Valley made the pace, and led into the straight. H. L. Ludwig's Rivopal gave a select Beaudesert following a good win in the Second Division of the Hack Handicap, starting at anything up to 12 to 1, and plenty of it, for the few takers. There was tons of. money for Bright Tint, who ran second, after starting favor ite, and Lindenette, who comes from Toowoomljia. It was a." close call, only a neck separating first and second after they contested the greater part of the " race'. " ' ' ' ' '

The Beaudesert track definitely is home to Smash, because he added an other win to give him the hat trick from his last three appearances. ' As' much as tens were taken. Mjarm£wonga after tailing the field; did not' give' hi? supporters at' two's much, hope; when he pUt In a run With two. furlabgs to go. 'Winning' Sq'ore made every post a Winner in the' Fifth Division of six furlongs, winning by two lengths, after having "four" in hand in the early running, McKinley looked a chance at one stage. They were the only two horses to draw any support worth speaking of, both starting -at twos. The Sixth Division of five furlongs' was a great betting race, with fours about three of them, and several others backed at fives and sixes; Lady. Monty, starting at' flyes, won from May Fiy, an early leader, and one of those shar ing favoritism- A field of ten lined up for the Open Handicap, which proved to be a good betting race. John Apple was sent out favourite at 7 to 2, and next in demand was the winner, -Ascertain. The race gave Moore his riding double, Riverain gave supporters a thrill the way he finished' on the fence, taking second place from John Apple, who bad made the pace in' the early running, and who was leading at the home turn. At his second start Speaker made amends; arid won the' First Division of the Seventh Division in grand style. He had been beaten into second plaqe by a length at his first stayt, whioh was rini in '1.2, the same as that of his win. He wM generally at evens, although spine supporters took short prices. Rio Chief, odds on favourite. for the Seventh Division, failed to make a place, phemeff whining all the way. Following the last raoe an inquiry was held, and the stewards found that P. Rheardon, on Main Beach, wns re sponsible for interference to Rio Cliief. Rheardon was severely reprimanded and warned that he would "have to exercise more control during rapes In the future if he was to avoid appearing before the stewards and Being pun ished. Results: Handicap Hack Race (First Division) about 5 furlongs. AKBAR 8.10 (G. Moore) .. .. .. 1. Speaker 8.2 (W. Brown) 2. Glenusk (Tindale) ,, ,, .. 8. Speaker jumped wcil, but Bronz Valley was the early leader, and, after opening a gap of two lengths at the "two," led Glenusk into the straight, with length to spare. Ackbar was handy. It was a good race, with Ackbar breaking away to win by a length, with two between second and third. Then came Gaine Prince, Len's Pride, Bronz Valley, Lochiynn and Vain Mint. articleText:
Beaudesert Shire

Elections

Policy of Candidates

INTEREST in the Beaudesert Shire Council Elec tions to be held in April is increasing, and a good deal of discussion is taking place regarding the prospects of the candidates for the chairman-

ship and in the divisions in which an election is necessary, IN VIEW OF THE NECESSITY FOR ALLOWING ELECTORS TO GAIN SOME IDEA OF WHAT IS IN THE MINDS OF THE CANDIDATES, THE "TIMES" APPROACHED THE CANDIDATES AND OFFERED SPACE TO GIVE TIIEIR VIEWS. TODAY, THE "TIMES" GIVES THE REPLIES , OF THE CANDIDATES FOR THE CHAIRMANSHIP, AND NO. 5 DIVISION. : Space will be devoted to the views of candidates for No. 3 Division in next Friday's issue, the statements to be handed into tho "Times" office by Tuesday morning.

ERN. HENLEY When Mr. E."E. Henley wot, s ;ked for his polie-j ho replied that it was as advertise'.: by him..i However," suppofirtrs of Mi. Henley . have delved into his 'life history, and a statement issuedfoi'" publication. ' The policy set 'out by Mr. Henley reads: (1) To work amicably with my fellow councillors. V (2) To be fair in my judgment on all matters pertaining to the Shire as a whole. j (3) To purchase,' modern machinery for road construction. (4) Permanent work. Avoid waste of funds on temporary work. (5) To favour a practical water sup- plv scheme for Beaudesert. (6) To encourage constructive criti cism from any source. (7) To investigate all avenues for subsidisation of road construction throughout the Shire. Should you honour me with your con fidence, I will spare no effort to be worthy of it; The statement reads: There are few activities in Beaudes ert jQverthe past -forty years, in which Mr. ijenley has notparticipated in one %'ay7bFah'otneiv"- "- '\„v ''Js"-.-"3"; We well remember, that when a young man he took a leading part in athletic sports, and in those days, lift was considered a "fairly good all- rounder." In the old Rugby football teams, he was a fast "winger," and with Dave Day, Johnny Tippett, and Tom Plunkett, the Beaudesert three- quarter iine was a formidable combina tion. Ernie Henley invariably "skip pered" the Beaudesert side,- and also most of the district teams which tried conclusions with metropolitan repre sentatives at least once each season. He was a keen cricketer in those days, with a number of "centuries" to his credit, and he led the Logan and Albert side which defeated the picked Bris bane juniors at Davies Park, Brisbane, in the early twenties. It was about this time, when he, with the late Jack Plunkett and Bob. Fuller and Charlie Stretton, annexed the "Plumb Tennis Cup" final at Been- leigh, in which all tennis teams within the Logan and Albert districts com peted. He gained second place in the "Brisbane" match against 200 com petitors, at the old Toowong rifle range, and was one of the team of 10 from Beaudesert, which won the "Lys- ter" Shield rifle competition. Dr. Beet, it is believed, is the only other mem ber of this team now living in Beau desert. Ernie won "putting the 321b. shot" at the show ground sports for 16 conse cutive years, and then was beaten by Frank Blow at a Church of England sports meeting on the same ground. He was a "back-marker" in most of the local sprints, and devoted much of his time to other athletics. He was a member of the Logan and Albert Jockey Club. Burgho Persse, Billy Massie and Pat. Doyle are the only surviving members. As a citizen, he has also played his part, and there are few activities hi this regard, in which he has not had a hand. With the late Dr. Pririg, H. Tomkeys and W. Green, he shared the credit of starting the first lending librai-y in Beaudesert, and later as secretary was mainly instrumental in building the present School of Arts and Technical Hall. With his. family, he assisted in the raising of funds for the building of St. Thomas's Parish room (the late Mr. John Yore was the builder), and with Mr. H. Bruxner, was one of the super-

visors of the erection of the Soldiers Memorial monument at Beaudesert. His work as Show secretary over the past 26 years speaks for itself, for with the exception of the grand stand and milking shed, all other improvements at the Beaudesert show grounds were erected during his term of office. In this regard, it may be said that the crowning achievement is the con struction of the new show ring, which is now nearing completion, and the new arena at the campdraft grounds, which will be built ready for the carnival in May next. The generosity of the mem bers of the Show Society, and the un tiring effort of the show executive is something that the town and district can be proud of, for this is a progres sive step, and one which will have far reaching results. The Royal visit to Beaudesert in 1927, and the Show Society Queen com petition are other outstanding events which have taken place during Mr. Henley's term of office. For the past ten years, he has held the high office of Vice President of the Chamber of Agricultural Societies of Queensland, the controlling body of all Queensland Show Societies, and up till his retirement in June last year, he was President of the Beaudesert Bowl ing Club for the record period of three consecutive years.

articleText:
Thirtieth Anniversary of Big Beaudesert Fire

DAMAGE ESTIMATED AT UP TO £4000

QN Sunday evening, March 12, 1916, Beaudesert had what the Beau desert "Times" file describes as the most disastrous fire in the history of the town, eight business houses being destroyed, and damage estimated at between £3000 and £4000 suffered.

The "Times" states that Mr. Harold Lahey, who was sleeping on the verandah of the premises of the Bank of Australasia in William Street gave the alarm at about 10.45 pan. The fire had burnt out by 2 a.m.

The fire started in Miss Macdonald's fruit shop and refreshment rooms. It then spread to C. T. Birkbeck's jewel lery store, and willing helpers moved a good deal of the valuable stock, but the flames forced them to leave a large quantity behind. Hart's refreshment rooms were the next to go, but nearly all the stock and effects were removed in time. Mr. J. V. Shay, dentist, who was lo cated above Birkbeck's store, lost al-

most the whole of his outfit, as it was almost impossible to get to his rooms because of the terrific heat and intense volumes of smoke. Men worked like trojans to salvage, as much property as possible but as the outbreak took place in the centre of the block- the flames spread to the east and west with equal rapidity. The Bank of Australasia was soon a raging inferno, and practically nothing v/as saved. All the books and docu ments not locked in the safe were de stroyed, and the loss will be consider able. Although most of the stock of to bacco etc. in McCrae's hairdressing and billiard saloon was rescued. The bil liard table was destroyed. Pert's tailoring establishment was next to the billiard saloon but most of the stock in trade had been removed before the flames reached the building. An endeavour was made to tear down the premises to make a break between the fire and Grand Hotel. The Grand Hotel was soon in dan ger, and blankets saturated with water were hung from a wire line on the side of the building. Men continually drenched the walls nearest the flames

with water and effected a marvellous save. The only damage was the blist ered wall nearest the fire. At one stage it was proposed to blow up Pert's shop with dynamite but this was considered to be im practicable. Men chopped the sup ports from under one side of ' the building, and pushed the wall near est the hotel into the flames. Dutt's plumbing and ironworks were completely destroyed. All the stock and appliances were removed in time. It was fortunate that the night was calm, otherwise the damage would have been more severe. With a west erly wind blowing nothing would have saved the hotel, and then all the build ings up to' Anna . Street would have gone. There was a strong possibility that the flames would have crossed the street to the School of Arts, and other premises. The heat cracked the plate- glass windows in Jenyns' stationery establishment. Souvenirs for presentation to sol diers, worth £20, were destroyed, also a valuable set of flags which were at the bank. Constable Holz Nagel re ceived a nasty cut on one of his hands. The fire was under control at 2 a.m. Monday morning, indicating how quickly it had spread. The bank safe when opened re vealed the cash intact, and the books but slightly scorched.

articleText:
Beaudesert Bowlers .Win Against Far Nth. Qld. Team

gEAUDESERT Bowlers were at home to a team of 18 players from the Far Northern Queensland District Bowling Association on Monday, 4 and, after an interesting game, the visitors suffered defeat by 16 points (107 points to 123 points).

i i been feared that Beaudesert would not be able to accept the .visit because a Monday had been selected, but when a call was made for players ..on Saturday the response was above expectations, and the game. .went on, much to the delight of all concerned. The visit will do much to advertise Beaudesert because the North erners conie 'from Cairns, Gordonvale, Babinda and Innisfail.

Members of the .team were Messrs. H. Townson, j. irvln, J. Griffen, D. Marsh, B.' Reed, H. Hansen, J. Lewis, G. McDougall (Gordonvale), A. E. Symons, A. Davies (Cairns), R. Thornley, G, Cecil, C. King (Cairns Masonic), B. Bevis, H. B. Moran (Innis fail), A. Whitechurch, J. Jackson and Watson (Babinda). The visitors, who were conveyed by- specially chartered bus, travelled from Warwick on Monday morning. They were entertained to lunch in the ball room at the Grand Hotel. The match was played during the afternoon, and ai night an impromptu smoke, social wit? held. It had been anticipated that the visitors would be proceeding to Southport after the gnmo but there was a change in plans, and they remained at. Beaudesert overnight, leaving on Tuesday morning. The evening function was a happy affair. Mr. L. Barnes entertained with conjuring tricks, and outstanding en tertainers in the visitors was Messrs. H. B. Moran (Innisfail) and C. Cecil (Cairns). At the tea adjournment the President (Mr. F. Hodgson) said that it was the first occasion that they had heen able to welcome Far Northern bowlers to their green, and the members hoped the visitors enjoyed themselves. When they received word of the visit it was doubtful whether they could arrange the match, because Monday was Beau- desert's busiest day. Then they received an urgent mes-. sage asking what they intended to do because the team would proceed to a Stanthorpe, if Beaudesert could not accommodate it. They set out to se cure 18 players, but instead found they had 24 names. He did not mind telling the visitors that most of the men were A.W.L., but there was no need to say anything .about it unless businessmen visited the green to see where their employees were. The speaker 'said that the Manager (Mr. A. E. Symons) had been stationed at Jimboomba during the war years. They were indebted to him for provid-

ing the brigade band for a President's At Home, and fqr an entertainment provided for Beaudesert. The artists were all professionals and the people would long remember those occasions. Unfortunately Colonel Symons, as he was then, had been; Involved in a motor accident and he was unable to return to Beaudesert. Referring to northerners Mr. Hodg son said that they were great British ers and great hearted people. They made visitors welcome and gave them a good time. He' spent some months at Innisfail and he never regretted the first day he went to the Innisfail bowl ing green. Mr. L. Barnes said the hospitality of N.Q. was well known, and Beaudesert hoped to extend the same hospitality to the visitors. He said tours of sport ing bodies were in 'the interests of the nation. It brought 'people together in the sporting world, and made them realise the north was not so far away after all. Dr. Beet said he hoped the visitors would enjoy their game. Mr. Hodgson thanked the ladies who were responsible for afternoon tea. He said he did not know Mrs. S. Dauth would be present, but her visit showed her interest in the club. They could ' see- her interest in the game by the number of times her name appeared on the club championship boards. They thanked Mesdames Dauth, Jurd and Armstrong for assisting with the re freshments. Mr. Watson, vice president of the F.N.Q.D.B.A., in responding, said that the cordiality of the welcome was going to take some beating by other clubs. The little they had seen of the town they had liked very much. He had been told it .was one of the most solid towns in Queensland. The members of the team had had a glorious trip to date. Mr. Symons, who organised the trip, said that he was pleased to come back to his old haunts. He appreciated the kindness of the Beaudesert people to the troops while stationed in the d's- trict. He tried to get the troops to play the .game in appreciation, and he thought they did. Mr. Symons said that in organising the tour he spoke to Mr/ Barnes. Beau desert appeared to always be left out of tours and it provided a break in the journey. On the tour they would have played all associations. He was pleased to see Mr. M. T. Sullivan present, and he had happy recollections of the Pre sident's Day referred to. It was a mar vellous afternoon. To date everything had" gone well. He also thanked the ladies for their afternoon tea. Mr. Watson then presented the club with a pennant, which had been struck for the trip, and presented Mrs. Dauth, Messrs. Hodgson and A. Dee (secre tary) with' one of their .special badges which depicted a northern bird, the cassowary. The play resulted,- the visitors being mentioned first: C. King, J. Jackson, J. Irvln, A. E. Symons .. .. 22 ''"v."-- G. Teese, P. Ebeling, W. Schmidt, T. Holding 18 J. Bevis and G. Cecil' '"ii .. .. 17 V. Geo. Day and R. Houston . . 23 A. Whitechurch, G.' McDougall, H. Townson, Watsoi). .. .. ... 24 . v. H. Buss, A. Hood./T. Enright, L. Barnes . .. .. 20 B. Reed, H. Morari, H. Hansen, D. Marsh , .. .. .. .. .. 23 v. J. Klumpp, A. J. Harvey, M. Blunck J. O. Grier . . . . . ......... 30 J. Lewis, R. Thornley, J. Griffin, A. Davies . . 21 .v.- W. Lawrence, Dr, Beet, W. Lupton, E. Lancaster ............ 32

articleText:
IT KiCUi llHIK Hill

MEETING AT BEAUDESERT BIG CROWDS WITNESS EXCITING FINISHES

IF the interest and enthusiasm shown in the first race meeting at Beaudesert for the year, held on Wednesday, is any indication of what is ahead, the Beaudesert and' District Amateur Race Club is destined to have a suc cessful year. :J

Many records were broken at the meeting, and ItTli estimated that the club wilt show a substantial profit. An Imjjpyement in the funds of the Club will be appreciated because a'.rod deal of money will be required to provide the necessary fa (Whiles at the course. It Is a tribute to the organising ability of the oloi> that there . should be such a big crowd at the meeting, and this reflects credit on the members of the committee for the part that they" Jiave played. While it might be admitted that the attendance included only a small percentage of district residents the meeting, andiothers of its kin, has done much to advertise the district, and improve the busi ness turnover of Beaudesert.

When heavy rain fell at the week end it 'was feared that the meeting might have to be abandoned. The track suffered as a result of the flooding, but by Wednesday morning it was lh per fect condition, testifying to the fact that drainage already carried out is a step in the right direction. So many people attended that the present facilities were shown to be In adequate. Of course the club can not be condemned for this because after the outbreak of war its funds were de voted to patriotic purposes. Then fol lowed some abandoned meetings be cause of wet weather, and a debit bal ance of hundreds of pounds was soon shown. Then ' further meetings were ' held but the percentage the club re ceived was used in paying off debit balances, and improving the track. Now that conditions have improved it is hoped that the club will be able to consider improving its buildings. In the meantime its officials can acquaint the committee of small matters that can be attended to. The club already has meetings allocated for February 6 and March 6. Officials had a busy time and al though there was some confusion at times it must be admitted that a grand job was done by all. It was inevitable that mistakes would be made, but with the experience gained there should be an improvement in the future. Mis takes and congestions destroy public confidence, and nobody realised this more than those charged with such a big task as faced officials on Wednes day. Officials of the day were: Patron, Mr. M. T. Sullivan; chairman, Mr. M. J. Smith; hon. treasurer, Mr. E. Hen- shall; committee, Messrs, D, M. Sifili- . ytin, IJWA Mvlb®e>v--W. J. Guilfoyle, S. Everdell, E. Henshall, F. Hodgson, C. Elleray; judges, Messrs. Thos. Moloney and J. V. Shay; starter, Mr. J. Kelly; clerk of scales, Mr. T. J. Enright; clerk of course, Mr. R. P. K. Tllley; timekeeper, Mr. W. Thwaites; handicapper, Mr. J. c. Anderson; stipendiary steward, Mr. G. Hunter; hon. stewards, Messrs. J. J. Guilfoyle and H, Selwyn Smith; totalisator stew ards, Messrs. T. R. Beck, E. G. Dauth and L. Walker; semaphore board stew ards, Messrs. P. Everdell, R. E. Jen nings and G. Manderson; hon. secre tary, Mr. G. Elleray. The first race was got away to time after a false start had caused a slight delay. Tom Pepper won easily by half a length. Opening at 7 to 4 the win ner was solidly supported to start at 5 to 4 on. After passing the post, Mon Lad swung out, and althugh Jockey Morsillo made a good effort to retain his seat, he failed to do so. His fall was not severe as his mount had prac tically stopped. The horse escaped from the enclosure, and this delayed the posting of "weight." Those who invested small amounts on Malliby got a thrill when that horse broke away from the start of the Second Division Hack, and opened a gap of three lengths from a bunched field. However, the even money top-

weight, Newslot, had everything re quired, and, in a stirring finish In which any one of four horses might have won got (.he decision by a head, with Visor a head worse, arid Malliby third a neck away. Many claimed t)mt Miss Bru, on the fence, might have been in a place. Newslot was never better ' than, evens, while Visor short ened from eights' tp fours, Punters and bookmakers agreed that nothing had a chance for the Third PivlsioB of 6 furlongs, other than Graceful Lad. Early takers soon scooped up the 7/4 on, and late ar rivals had nothing but twos on to con sider. Arubial drifted from threes to sevens and a little tens, and tens could be got about the others, excepting Field Leader, who went out at fives. Graceful Lad soon made a break, but England stayed with him for several furlongs. Field Leader set out, but had no chance, and was lueky to get within three lengths of- the winner. The fourth race, the First Division of the Maiden Handicap, went to the 6 to 4 on favourite, Crimson Chief, although he did not have tilings all his own way, the winning margin being- half a head. Maverick' held the leader until they swung into the straight, but he could not beat off Lady's First who made second place. Nothing but the winner was given a chahce by punters, but there was a little money for some of the others. The Second Division of the Maiden Handicap was a good betting race, Pir ate Miss, Gashfield, and Shining silk all being supported. In the early stages fives could be secured about Shining Sllk. but he finished up equal favour ite with Gashfield at 5 to 2. Gashfield

was generally called at twos at many stages. Pirate Miss'-Jed for the greater part of the distance, and went down by a length. There was nothing in the Fourth Division Handicap, Port Dale, the fav ourite, winning by : a head, with a twenty to one pop./Hazeldean, a like distance away third. Punters wanted nothing but the favourite, and Mine Sweeper and My Wish, both of whom were quoted at fours. Tens to twenties operated about the remaining ten : starters. The favourite,-/ Valagfred, was downed in the seventh race, the Fifth Division Handicap/ victory going to Visor by half a length from Tom Pep per, who won the "first race. Visor had filled second place m his earlier start,

and, although those who got in early secured fours and a few fives about the gelding's chances, there was so much money that most fielders closed up on him, arid refused to get. Tom Pepper was penalised seven pound for his win, but this was offset by an al lowance of a like amount, J. Page again riding him. Backers of Mannawonga received a shock in the Welter Handicap of sevei! furlongs when it looked as If the geld ing was in trouble when Field Leader challenged In the straight. Page had the whip out on Mannawonga, and ap parently it had the desired result, be cause Mannawonga came again, and won comfortably by 15 lengths. The race was robbed of some of Its interest when there was an Incident as the field settled down, and shortly after when Rheardon crashed on Master Gaine. Cavan Boy, who caused a good deal of trouble at the barrier, appeared to have a chance at one stage, and Field Leader was always well placed. The winner and British Gaine shared fav ouritism at twos. Results: HANDICAP HACK RACE (1st DIV.) about 5 furlongs Mrs. R. Simula's TOM PEPPER, 9.1 and 7 lb. over (J. Page) 1 R. L. Ludwig's Mon Lad, 9.5 (C. Morsillo) 2 O. J. Binstead's Cora Night, 8.1 (W. Byrne) 3 Others: A. E. Schmalz's Fancy Fern 8.6 and 2 lb. over (R. J. Finn); R. J. Manning's Will Lady 7.13 (L. James); L. Schultz's The Wren 7.7 and 6 lb, over (R. Ralston). Betting: 5 to 4 on TOM PEPPER, 4 Mon Lad, Fancy Fern, 10 Cora Night, 10 others. Dividends: 9/- and 7/6. Tom Pepper -was best away from Cora Night, with Win Lady a long way back. Although Cora Night had charge in the early running Tom Pepper bridged the gap and led into the straight. Mon Lad looked like making a good race of it, but Tom Pepper fin ished strongly to win by half a length, With a length to third. Time 1.6. HANDICAP HACK RACE (2nd DIV.) about 5 furlongs G. Fogarty's NEWSLOT, 9.4 ,<T. Murphy) , . . 1 W. Gulbrandson's Visor 8.0 (C. Morsillo) 2 W. N. Power's Malliby 8.7 and 2 lb. allowance (T. W. Hill) 3 Others: Mrs. M. Bryant's Miss Bru 8.2 (W. Byrne); G. J. Milne's Valley Queen 8.5 and 5 lb. allowance (R. Simms); M. Flynn's Lady Gale 8.0 (R. Ralston) ; J. W. Mahoney's Lilypal 7.10 and 1 lb. allowance (L. Murphy); W. Storey's Master Ruffian 7.4 and 4 lb. over (J. Page). BETTING: Evens Newslot, 4 Visor, Miss Bru, 8 Lilypal, 10 others. Dividends: 12/-. 3/- and 7/-. Lilypal was best away, but Malliby made the pace, and soon opened up a gap of three lengths. As they swung at the home turn, Malliby began to go back to his field, with Newslot show ing out from the bunch. Miss Bru looked like being a chance at one stage, but the run was not sustained. It was a stirring finish, with Newslot getting the decision by a head, with a neck to third. Then came Miss Bru, with Lily pal and Malliby handy. Lady Gale was a bad last. Time 1.5. Printed at Beaudesert and Published in the Beaudesert and Tamborine Shires for Beaudesert Times Pty. Ltd., by H. R. Tomllnson, Brayford Street, Beaudesert,

articleText:
Milk f Producers Alarmed

Reports on Beaudesert Products Q.D.&. WANTS EVIDENCE TO SUPPORT t > ALLEGATIONS V. :

THE Lpgan and Albert Sub-Executive of the Qieehsland Dairymen's Organisation is up in arihs ' regarding allegations that the milk suppli&d from the district to Brisbane is not all that it should be.

At the monthly meeting on Monday members attacked the Beaudesert Chamber of Commerce for the part it had taken of late, and speakers claimed that there was no reason for the state ments 'being made. It was . claimed that those people who were condemning the milk should prove, their statements, and the President (Mr. R. L. Harrison), who was not present, was quoted as having announced . that Beaudesert milk compared favourably with that from any other district, although Toowoomba milk might be a little better. It was alSo stated that Mr. Harrison said that other centred were having trouble with the quality of the milk at the same time Beau desert wn concerned. . One statement made during the meeting was that all producers were blamed for the faulty minority.

The meeting; was presided over by Mr. Mr. N. C. .Webb in the absence of Mr. Harrison, and'there were also pre sent Messrs. J. E. Markwell, O. Hayes, J. Moloney, E. R. Schwartz, G. Mason and the secretary (Mr. H. G. Johnson). Mr. Harrison sent an apology for his non-attendarice. During the meeting reference was made to the Beaudesert Chamber of Commerce attitude on the milk supply question, and reference was made to the report of last; Thursday night's meeting, which appeared in the last issue of the Beaudesert "Times." The Chamber of Commerce wrote soliciting assistance in its agitation for the appointment of a dairying inspec tor. Copies of all correspondence on the matter were included. A letter from the Logan and Albert Co-operative Dairy Association to the Chamber read: Seeing that we have already made application for an in spector, and that the Queensland Dairymen's Association ' is now re garded by the Government as the rank and file representative of the produc ers my Board are definitely of the opinion that your' letter should be written to the Secretary of the Queens land Dairymen's Organisation Board, who, we feel surp-vvill support our ap plication for a di'' inspector, and not

a combined stock inspector and dairy ing inspector as at present. The Chamber also advised writing to the Under Secretary of the Department of Agriculture and Stock in the matter. The chairman said the subject was a primary producers problem, and he thought the Chamber had exceeded its powers. Voice: Definitely. Chairman: It is a matter for the dairymen. Mr. J. E. Markwell: We took the matter up a few months ago. Chairman: What we want is not just an ordinary dairy inspector, but a herd tester and an agriculturalist who is a practical man. . Mr. E. R. Schwartz said he was glad that the chairman had objected to the way the Chamber took the jiositlon in hand. His own' objection was to the way 'the Chamber had taken it in hand. He objected to the way the Chamber handled the report, and he

was upset on reacting the proceedings at the Chamber meeting. Mr. Schwartz said he had brought up several meetings ago that they had to strive for quality, but there was no reason to say that the quality of their product was worse than others. If men made statements regarding the quality of the milk, compared with that "of other areas, they should consider the industry, and make inquiries into the matter first. If the Chamber made the accusation that they produced a bad quality milk the Q.D.O. should ask them to prove .their statements. If the

Chamber did they must show the qual ity of the product arriving in Brisbane compared with other areas. If the Chamber could prove the quality was inferior they should go to the Q.D.O. and not the factory. Mr. Schwartz added that no matter how the quality of the milk was they should strive to better it. What were' the duties of an inspector? Chairman: To see that the Govern ment regulations are carried out. Mr. Schwartz said that they wanted a tester. The butter factor'y meeting asked for a tester, but he doubted if anything had happened. Chairman: The State Executive has applied for a tester. Mr. Schwartz said a tester served much better than an inspector. The tester visited a dairy at the same tune about every three weeks, and the in fluence on the farmer was great. Dairy farmers might get . a little slack at times, not because they were lazy, but often they had too much to do, and could not attend to the little things. If a tester visited the farms regularly the producers objective would be to have things in order. The visits caused a routine, and the dairies would always be in order. The speaker contended that a tester was a better proposition than an inspector because he could give

--'-aav»ce;sHe was at the dairy during the milking and he saw the milk ing. The dairy inspector only looked for the yard broom and shovel etc. They should write the Chamber stating that in a way they appre ciated the suggestion, but also ob jecting to the criticism of their pro duct, if the Chamber had no know ledge of the comparison. They should also inquire from the factory as to the decision to apply for a

tester. Mr. G. Mason complained that when a dairy inspector was appointed on one previous occasion the Government had not selected a practical man. Mr. J. E. Markwell said that any subject brought up had been dealt with. They had been dealing with the matter for twelve months. Chairman: Two years. Mr. Markwell: We have been dealing with the question of a man who has passed all Ills tests. The tester 'has been promised to us. The chairman said that if they asked for a price fixing inspector to be brought to the district the Chamber would not like itr If half the producers learned how to farm they would know how to dairy. They needed to feed then- stock. The Minister for Agricul ture and Stock (Mr. T. Wijliams) had assured him that the - Government would send an agriculturalist and tes ter to the district. They could not force the Government to send the man along. If the Chamber wrote to the Q.D.O. it would get ail the informa tion it required. Mr. Mason: The rank and file want a man who can advise them and give them suggestions as to improving their dairies and stock. If they appointed a man they would have to get one with ability. A tester would be of assistance to the general farmer. His idea was that the factory should appoint a tes ter and the farmers pay for it. Following a statement that an offi cial appointed in the past was not competent the chairman and secretary said that the testers they had dealt with were good men. Mr. J. Moloney said that the Q.D.O. had the support of the dairymen. He did' not know If the Chamber had the support of the dairymen. Chairman said he was a member and he thought several others were. Mr, Moloney: The Chamber has gone over our- heads. We are capable of handling the position. We don't want any slight. Replying to a published statement that the matter would have to go be fore branches the secretary said the matter was domestic and they could handle it direct with the Minister. Mr. Schwartz said that they would have to get a tester or an adviser. The Government could not send out better men for testing than it was doing. Chairman moved that they ask the Minister for Agriculture and Stock to expedite the appointment of the tester and agriculturalist, and to ask the Chamber to refer dairying -questions to the Q.D.O. and its requests would get prompt attention. Seoretary said that Mr. Harrison (president) , who is also associated with the Milk Board, said Beaudes ert milk compared favourably with that sent to Brisbane by other districts, and Toowoomba might be a little better. Mr. Moloney pointed out that Mr. Harrison explained that other dis tricts were having trouble with the milk at the same time that Beau desert was. Both the chairman and Mr. O. HayeJ said that they personally couid not im prove the quality of the milk supply from their properties. Mr. Schwartz said he objected to tne Continued on Pago Eight.

MILK PRODUCERS I ' ALARMED (Continued from Column Five, Page One)

w 9 way Beaudesert was 'being slandered regarding its milk not' being up to standard. They should ask complainers to prove that their milk was not up tcr standard. They could take those who (iniflTllOlllOrl nVirtllfr end aah1/1

not substantiate their allegations, to court to prove their contentions. - Chairman said it was difficult to prove the standard of milk in court. Chairman said the whole trouble was that all producers were blamed for the faulty minority, and they would have to bring the faulty minority up to standard. The motion was carried, After members had - explained that they were often advised that there was a shortage of manpower it was sug gested 'the Q;D.O. might engage testers and pay for their services themselves. There was a difference of opinion as to procedure in this regard in. other States, but it was claimed that in the British Empire the authorities were In variably responsible for testers. It was said that the "producers undertook the , work on the continent. Mr. Schwartz said that if- they were prepared to vengage their own testers this would \ show the people they wanted to goV ahead. If they wanted to supply milk and get a good name again— it was not a case oTunaintain- ing their good name— Uiev v. mid hav;- to get a tester. It '.viw of question for all of them to go to Brisbane' but they should send a deputation. It was decided that Messrs. Schwartz and Mason proceed to Brisbane and interview the Minister on the matter. Mr. Harrison was to be invited to join If he was available. An appointment with the Minister is to be made through Mr. Muller, M.L.A.
heading: Milk Producers Alarmed Reports on Beaudesert Products Q.D.O. WANTS EVIDENCE TO SUPPORT ALLEGATIONS

articleText:
Splendid Entry for Beaudesert Show and Gampdraft

THE BEAUDESERT SHOW CARNIVAL OF 1946 MARKS A NEW ERA IN THE SHOW SOCIETY'S HISTORY, FOR NEXT WEEK WILL SEE THE ANNUAL SHOW STAGED UNDER CONDITIONS WHICH HAVE HERE-T0-F0RE REEN IMPOSSIBLE.

For the past fifty years the Beaudesert Show has been conducted under conditions which have not been conducive to good entertain ment from a pnblic point of view, but now that the Logan and Albert Agricultural . and Pastoral Society has completed their show ring, it

will be in a position to stage this year's show to greater advantage, and to include rfng events, which, under the old conditions, were impossible.

There is a splendid entry for all ring events, and, with an entry well up to previous records in the dairy cattle sections, the grand parade in the new ring will be a sight well worth seeing, and an event which the district will have every reason to be proud of. The horse section 'is very strongly supported, with 197' entries in the hackney classes, 88 ponies, 31 hunters and jumpers, 17 trotters and pacers, 9 for the pony speed tests, and there will be three competitors for the track re cord in the John Aldridge & Sons trot ting speed test. Ninteen entries of blood horses, and 16 draughts have been re ceived. In the dairy sections, the Jersey breed tops the list of entries with 173, with the Australian Illawarra Shorthorns a close second with 156 entries. Ayrshire cattle will make a good showing with 35 entries, and, in the ground milking competitions, there aTe no less than 29 entries. Seventy-six head of fat cattle will compete in their section, and there will be over 60 stud pigs, 8 sows with litters, 24 baconers, 26 export baconers. and 27 porkers. Poultry, sheep and dogs are well represented, and, -on the whole, the entries may be regarded as most satis factory. SIDESHOWS AND TRAFFIC Practically all the available space has been booked up for side-shows, and with fine weather, all is in readiness for a record show. Special attention has been paid to the control of motor traffic at the show, and expert officers will have charge of parking arrangements within the show grounds. Cars will be parked according to a special plan, which will enable ..patvons to leave the grounds whenever they desire. Temporary, seatiivg'—flccommodatlon has been erected at the northern part

of the show ring, and, for this show, there will be no charge made at the grand stand. It must be understoou, that neither the ring proper, nor the seating arrangements are completed, according to the Society's. plans, but it will be seen that great progress has been made with the general improve ments at the grounds since the work was commenced a few months ago. The carrying out of the Society's plans will to a great extent, depend upon the support of the people who, it is ex pected, will attend in great numbers, BUSHMAN'S CARNIVAL All reserved car stands have been booked for the campdraft. and the plan was closed a week ago. A large .number of late applications could not be granted. It is always essential that reserved car stands should be booked early to avoid disappointment. In view of the heavy demand for re served car stands, it has been suggested that, in future, some arrangement be made to provide seating for those who cannot obtain a reserve stand. The campdraft committee has in view a plan for ramps to be erected at vari ous parts of the ringside, but owing to the heavy expense already incurred in building the new arena and chutes for the rough events, the plan could not be carried out this year. The new set out of the arena, however, will give the public an excellent view of all activi ties from the grand stand. NIGHT ENTERTAINMENT

The annual show bail will be held in the Technical Hail. Beaudesert, on Thursday night, May 9. and the camp draft dance on Saturday night. There will be a social evening aid snickc con cert for judges and exhibitors at the, show on Wednesday night.. Charlie Tay lor's dance, band will .provide, modem, and old time dance music.
heading: Splendid Entry for Beaudesert Show and Gampdraft THE BEAUDESERT SHOW CARNIVAL OF 1946 MARKS A NEW ERA IN THE SHOW SOCIETY'S HISTORY, FOR NEXT WEEK WILL SEE THE ANNUAL SHOW STAGED UNDER CONDITIONS WHICH HAVE HERE-TO-FORE BEEN IMPOSSIBLE.

articleText:
"TIMES" AND RATIONING

Paper rationing is still with us, and it is impossible for newspapers to use more paper than is allow able by strictly policed regulations.

In order to allow political par ties convey their views to the pub lic the Beaudesert "Times" has been forced to condense reports appearing in this Issue. Until such time as paper ration ing is eased, the "Times" cannot be enlarged, a fact that is regretted by the management.
heading: "TIMES" AND RATIONING

articleText:
the federal elections

Responsibility for any unsigned matter appearing in this Issue of the Beaudesert "Times" is accepted by H. R. Tomlinson, of Brayford Street, Beaudesert.

CEMETERY UPKEEP Following an Interview with the Chairman of the Beaudesert Shire Council (Clr. E. E. Henley) and the Clerk (Mr. A. L. Lane), Mr. P. Gull- foyle has been appointed caretaker of the Beaudesert cemetery for twelve months at £48. The area is to be kept in first class order for the entire per iod, and the caretaker is to supply his own tools of trade. CRICKET ACCIDENTS ' Two cricketers were hurt on Sunday, both requiring medical attention. R. Stuart, butcher, suffered a fractured left hand. He was taken to the Beau desert Q.A.T.B. Centre where he was treated and then taken to a doctor. R. Jurd, carrier, who was struck on the left thumb and left thigh with a ball, suffered a contused thumb' and bruised thigh, was treated, and advised to visit a doctor. WOMEN'S AUXILIARY Those present at the last meeting of the Women's Auxiliary of the Beaudes ert Sub-Branch of the R.S.S.A.IX.A. were Mesdames A. P. Watson (Presi dent), A. Schmidt. Goodwin, Ferguson, Clark, Ball. Keating, Lane, Turner, Moody, Frederickson, Gardiner and Tomlinson (secretary). Apologies were received from Mesdames P.. Doyle, Col lins, Allpass, Ardrey. Dauth, Piatt and Kucks. Helpers at the recent Diggers Ball were thanked and it was decided to hold a dance cn October 18. Gifts of a kupper cloth from Mrs. Higginson and an iced cake from Mrs. P. Doyle were received with thanks. Plans wtsrs xuds for the fete,

WILLIAM STREET INCIDENTS There were several incidents in and near William Street yesterday after noon, following which one man was taken to a doctor and another was taken into custody. SCHOOL PROJECT WORK The Organiser of Project Clubs, under the direction of the Queensland Educational Department, Mr. J. Kah- ler, visited Beaudesert on Wednesday ana yesterday In connection with the work at the State Rural School.. At tention was given to the forestry plot at the school, and the trees have been thinned out,' leaving only selected specimens. AN INJURED FINGER Thomas Stanley (63), a ganger on tlio-Molo Hoad»-job o,t tlio ThrPP Milp. Lane, was assisting to unload logs when the third finger of his left hand be came caught between them, almost taking a piece of flesh off the finger. He was taken to the Beaudesert Q.A.T.B. centre, and treated for a con tused finger. Medical attention was ad vised. TREES AT RATHDOWNEY Following the planting of trees at Vjfi memorial grounds at Rathdowney trie workers planted one in a tree guard in the street of- the township, Mr. W. Downes having the honour, and the tree is in memory of his father. The monthly meeting of the council on Tuesday was told by Clr. R. F. Davis that more trees would have been planted only the committee was told that the council had given instructions for plantings to take place. SALE OF PETROL Speaking on behalf of about 20 farmers, Mr. C. J. Brosnan asked the monthly meeting of the Beaudesert Chamber of Commerce if petrol could be made available at night and at week-ends. He would like to see the matter investigated. Several said no body had been turned away in case of emergency and others said that on some occasions petrol could not be bought. It was decided to investigate the legal position of people handling this product. j HONORING POLICE INSPECTOR Messrs. B. Steele and J. O'Malley visited Beaudesert on Wednesday in connection with the testimonial to be accorded Inspector F. M. O'Driscoll, who has retired fx-om the position of officer in charge of the South Coast police district, which embraces Beau desert. The fund closes on September 25 and the function will be held in the Carlton lounge on October 4. Sgt. T. Holding and Mi-. L. J. Bright, of Beau desert, are authorised to accept- sub scriptions. FINAL WELCOME HOME Speaking at the monthly meeting of the Beaudesert Sub-branch of the R.S.S.A.I.L.A. on Friday night Rev. J. Lee Warner said that the Beaudesert Fighting Forces Welfare Committee was trying to make the final welcome home, to oe held on September 27, a most successful function. He appealed to returned men to give their fullest support because the committee had put in a lot of hard work. By attending members would show that the work done received the fullest appreciation of those for whom It had been done. CARE OF MONUMENT The vexed question of who Is re sponsible for the cleanliness of the Beaudesert memorial, and its surround ings was answered by the Chairman of the Beaudesert Shire Council (Clr. E. E. Henley) at the monthly meeting of the council on Tuesday. Clr. Henley, said that there was an amount of £150 Invested for the upkeep of the monu ment, and its surroundings. It was in a savings bank account carrying interest. A certain amount had been spent, and the money was being used for the purpose for which it was col lected. SCHOOLBOYS CRICKET On Saturday the Schoolboys Club- opened the cricket season with a match "Town" v. "Country" played on the Selwyn Park wicket. The standard of play proved very good for so early in the season. Several players showed great promise with the bat. Joe Fenton made 76 for "Country" and Don Ard rey 81 not out for the "Town." Others to reveal good form were Bryan Dry nan 17. Noel Cox 15, B. Kassulke 12. Noel Berg excellent with the ball se curing the hat trick. Other promising bowlers were Noel Cox, Bryan Drynan, Bryan Kassulke and Morris Pascoe. Doug. Salter acquitted himself well be hind the stumps. The game resulted in a win for "Country" on the first inn ings. Beaudesert meets Kerry on the Selwyn Park wicket at .10.30 a.m. to morrow. The following players will re present Beaudesert: D. Ardrey (capt.), C. Tllley (vice captain), G. Dauth, B. Kassulke, M. Winch, D. Slater, D. Crust, N. Berg, N. Oox, G. Lewis, K. Walker, M. Pascoe (12th man).

CANUNGRA SHOW - The most successful exhibitor in the vegetable section at the Canungra show was Mrs. L. E. Adkins. The weight of the pig proved to be 161 lbs., the successful guesser being A. Valen tine, Brisbane. FARMER SCALDED John Hall, a sharefarmer of Lam- ington, was carrying a kerosene tin of boiling water yesterday when he slipped on the concrete floor. He suf fered scalds to the left upper arm and side, and a probable fracture of the ribs. He was treated by the Beau desert Q.A.T.B., and taken to hospital. MOTOR CYCLE FIRE A motor cycle being ridden in Bris bane Street on Monday afternoon be came afire. Efforts were made to ex tinguish. It with hags. Thp. .nut.hrpnk . . was soon put under control when a fire extinguisher was played on it. Bystanders claim that the machine . would have been a complete loss only for this action. It was owned by Mr. E. c. Benyon. ALL NATIONS FAIR The Salvation Army All Nations Fair held in the Technical Hall on Monday night was a pronounced suc cess, there being an attendance of 240 people. The nett proceeds of the even ing were £22. Members of the Kalbar Salvation Army Band provided a pro gramme of music, as well as individual numbers, which was greatly appre ciated. Stalls were in operation, and did good business. WEDDING The marriage of Miss Audrey Schu macher (only daughter of Mr. Paul Schumacher and the late Mrs. Schu macher), and Cpl. Edward Vernon Glover, of Warwick, was solemnised at the Salvation Army Hall by Captain G. Abbott on Friday night. Mrs. K. Kealey was Matron of Honour. A re ception followed. Mr. and Mrs. Glover left to spend their honeymoon at Coolangatta. R.S.S.A.IX.A. MEETING The Beaudesert Sub-branch of the R.S.S.A.I.L.A. has been advised by the Tamborine Sub-branch that that sub- branch delegate to the district execu tive (Mr. Goldsmith) was prepared to act for Beaudesert and . Canungra as well. The monthly meeting of the sub- branch decided to thank the Beaudes ert Shire Gouncil for allowing it to use the tramway offices for meetings. Mr. Eldershaw was welcomed to the meet ing. The attendance was 33 members, as against the record of 39 at the Aug ust meeting. The next meeting will discuss the matter of serving refresh ments after meetings as facilities for preparing supper are not available at present, following the destruction of the C.WA. Rest Rooms by fire.
heading: THE FEDERAL ELECTIONS

articleText:
BEHIND THE SCENES

A representative of the Beaudes ert "Times" was privileged to' "get behind the scenes," and there to hear a discussion between the lead-

ers- of the movement, and so get some idea of what had taken place prior to the opening of the hall. And it was obvious that it was not a backpatting effort, but a sincere review of developments over a comparatively short period of time. First to receive plaudits was Tom Kcaveny, who had given an acre and half of land for the hall site. Tliis was described as the most suitable land in the district for (he purpose. Tom Thwaitcs sur. received a big measure of applause, becausi it was considered that he hau initiated the idea of building a hall, and had not let up in his advocacy o. such a progressive move. Much was said of the work of Jack Keaveny. who had acted as leading hand to the district men who had voluntarily given their services on the job. He had been there when the work was going on from soon after daylight until dark, eager that the building, over which he had spent such time designing, should take the shape he had anti-' cipatcd. While practically all district re sidents said that they had some thing to work for because their children would get a lot of en joyment from the hall, they em- fihasised the interest and enthus- asm of "Bob" Stephens in the venture. A single man, "Bob" had toiled as hard as anybody in order that the next generation would have somewhere to assemble to en joy itself. Builders Eric Bosworth and Bert Hacker were showered with the thanks of the community for their skilled work, and for the way tlicy had fallen in with the plans of the people, and worked with the labour residents had provided to make the opening of (he hall pos sible in such a short space of time. They were told that they had shown a spirit far from evident in the world today. One who does not live at Kerry, but who has the interest of that area at heart, and revealed it in many ways, was Father O. B. Steele. Some of the speakers _ let the cat out of the bag as to just what Father Steele had done dur ing the negotiations, and when the committee was up against it at some stages. His name will go down in history alongside the pioneers of the hail. The ladies of the district were not forgotten. The way they had risen to' the occasion was emphas ised, and Mrs. Tom Kcaveny, and her band of decorators was singled out for a little extra praise. How Mrs. Kcaveny had made the Keaveny home available for meet ings and gatherings was also men tioned, and she was thanked for this kindly gesture.
heading: BEHIND THE SCENES

articleText:
ATTENDING THE TEST

Representations of the Beaudes ert "Times" to secure press accom modation at the test match last Saturday were unsuccessful, despite

the persistent efforts made. The President of the Q.R.L. (Mr. V. Jensen) was contacted by tele phone on Friday after attempts had been made to speak to him from Thursday morning onwards. Mr. Jensen was told the position, and it was found that he knew nothing about what had transpired because he had been "Up North" attending to football worries, and trying to make the Englishmen happy, or something to that effect. Mr. Jensen said he would see what could be done, and it was arranged that he was to be 'phoned at 8 a.m. Satur day at a number given by him. Ftom 8 a.m. to 9 a.m. Saturday Mr. Jensen was not at the number given, and it was not thought that he would be there so . . . In his review of what he thought would, or would not happen on Satur day, Mr. Jensen remarked that he did not think there would be any "queue- ing" up to get into the grounds so . . . A representative of the "Times" was /-able to get to the game, and give a cover, despite the lack of assistance from the Q.R.L. However, a programme was not avail- ' able, and this and other factors pre vented the description of the game that should have been available to readers.
heading: ATTENDING THE TEST

articleText:
| the show moves on |

Dealing with the Beaudescrt show of 1916 the Beaudescrt "Times" of May 12, 1916, had the following to say: Notwithstanding

the severe drought experienced in the district during last year, and the early part of this year, the number of entries received exceeded 1000 which speaks well for the re cuperative qualities of the whole district. A proposal tc abandon the show had been made earlier in "the year. An interesting comment in connec tion with the show was: There was an excellent display in the pavilion. The expansion of the agricultural and farm products sections is most encouraging, as it points to. the fact .that the fertile lands of the Logan and Albert Rivers are being brought Into their proper use, and each year more and more cultiva tion and producing is taking place. "At one time the show was looked upon as being almost entirely a horse ' and cattle show, when agricultural anu farm products were but a side line, and it was a hard matter to find the ex hibits. and, when found, they were not promising specimens. The order chang-' eth. and at this show the display is one that the society and the district may well feel proud of. Mr. J. Stodart, M L A., who opened the show was introduced by the Pre sident (Mr. deBurgh Persse). Awards at the show included: Cham pion draught mare, ,). Markwell's entry; blood stallion, J. Doyle's Camp Fire; pony stallion, J. Asniery's Dumpling; pony jump, F. C. Nicholson's "Silver; hunter, Miss K. Anderson's Ben Arnold; Shorthorn bull. deB. Persse's entry; milking shorthorn champion bull, Mc- Intyre Bros.' Handsome Lad; champion cow, Hclntyre's Handsome; champion Illawarra bull, F. J. Ca veil's Prince Consort; champion cr.w. j. Murray's en try; champion Ayrshire cow. M. Buck ley's entry; champion Jersey bull and cow, W. J. Barnes' entries; champion Berkshire boar, J. Murray's entry; sow, T. F. Flunkett's entry; champion Mid- York boar and sow. H. S. Smith's en tries; champion cock and pullet, B. Holtorf's entries; home milking com petition, T. S. Champney's Possum; milking competition. Champnoy's Lucy. It was stated that the Kingston but ter factory reported iliat during April 83 tons 6 cwt, of butter were manufac tured. being a decrease of 17 tons 14 cwt. 2 lb., as compared with the pre vious April. Suppliers were paid 1/1:1 per lb. commercial butter. It was announced that, under the new Brands Act, 1915, thai all drivers of cattle to the Beaudescrt sale yards had to carry waybills.

ana paste on caraooaia, so mi mey can add the monthly totals from time to time. Shortage of paper, due to ra tioning, prevents the publication of the chart each month.

articleText:
KERRY RACE SEQUEL i

The Beaudesert "Times" of Frl-. day, July 21, 1916, reprinted the following from the Brisbane "Courier.":

"Punter" is informed that the stew ards of the Kerry Race Club -had ho power to refuse an appeal to the Q.T.C., with regard to Deanery, who won the Ladies' Bracelet. That horse was not eligible to start in the event, as, according to the Australian Rules of Racing, a "maiden" is a horse that has not won a race at time of starting. As Deanery had already won a race earlier in the day she was not eligible for the Ladies' Bracelet, which was fov maiden hacks. The owner of Deanery can appeal to the Q.T.C., setting out all the circumstances of the case, and pdinting out that the Kerry officials refused to take an appeal. A deposit of £20 must accompany the nppeai to the Q.T.C. Backers of Dainty Dancer were most unfortunate, for although the de cision of the stewards was obviously incorrect, they had no redress. Bets always follow the stake and the stew ards awarded the stake to Deanery, and bets had to' be paid accordingly. This is one of the things backers of horses have to attend with. Other items in the same issue were: Recently rumours have been freely circulated In Beaudesert, in common with other places in Queensland, that no further recruits were wanted, and that probably no more transports will leave Australia. These statements are characterised by those in authority as "dangerous lies,'! being without the slightest foundation. As a matter of fact recruits were never more urgently needed, and every effort must be strained so that our bays already at the front should be thoroughy sup ported in their gallant efforts to drive back the treacherous Huns. Mr. E. W. S. Hardgrave is in receipt of a letter from Mr. J. G. Appel, mem ber for the district, stating that the Government have decided to survey a number of quarter acre allotments at the site of the proposed township at Mt. Lindesay gates. These allotments will be for sale as perpetual leases, and no doubt there will be pretty keen com petition, as Mt. Lindesay Is destined to become a popular health resort, to which the jaded city man will rush to recuperate after months of weary toil

in the crowded metropolis. Mr. and Mrs. R. J. Logan entertained 60 guests at their residence "Glenburn," Cryna, at a gift evening in honour of Miss Hannafin's approaching marriage. Miss Hannafin had been teaching there for six years. Mrs. Wm. Collins received word from New Zealand that her brother, who was the son of the late Hon. Fitzclar- ence Roberts, of Dunedln, had passed away. Private O. Wease, of Canungra, was severely wounded at the front. Mr. Geologist Read will visit Mt. Lindesay with a view to inspecting the coal measures hi that locality. Andrew Ross, aged 13, of Gleneagle, was playing at school when he was ac- cidently struck hi the eye by the rope a girl was using for skipping. It was feared he might lose the eye.
heading: KERRY RACE SEQUEL
snippet: The Beaudesert "Times" of Friday, July 21, 1916, reprinted the following from the Brisbane "Courier."

articleText:
SEASONAL GREETINGS

AN this, the second Christmas of, peace, the Beaudesert "Times" conveys seasonal greetings to its read ers and advertisers.

Although the past year has been free of the clouds that were connected with war, adversity was associated with the period, due to unfavorable weather conditions, and other circumstances, some of which were the aftermath of the conflict that raged throughout the world. Beaudesert residents faced their measure of troubles, but these were met with a spirit that was reminiscent of that of the pioneers who made it pos sible for the present generation to en joy the potentialities with which nature has generously endowed the district. Australia is a nation that is quick to forget its good times, and equally prone to forget that it has its diffi culties from time to time, and it is with this spirit that we all' look forward to bountiful seasons, and freedom from strife and termoil, in the coming year. The Beaudesert "Times" joins in the wish that its readers and advertisers, with the remainder of the world, will make the most of the festive season, and that it will enjoy prosperity In the year that Is about to be born.
heading: SEASONAL GREETINGS
snippet: ON this, the second Christmas of peace, the Beaudesert "Times" conveys seasonal greetings to its readers and advertisers.
