articleText:
IMPROVED FACILITIES

" "Thirty, years ago, Friday, July 7, 1918, the Beaudesert "Times" made the following announcement: The telephone line between Beaudesert

and the Risk has been successfully constructed, and is open for public business. It is now possible to get in touch with the following cen- tres across the border: The Risk, Kyogle, Lismore, Casino, Wooden- bong, Urbenville, The Gorge and other towns on the Northern Riv- ers. We understand the line is in good working order, and business fairly brisk. Telephonic communi- cation can be obtained with Tam- borine and Tamborlne Mountain. The same issue of the ' Times" made the following comment: Tne following have volunteered to join the forces now so gallantly upholding our honour on the stricken fields of France: Har- old Smith, Norman Kingston, Joseph Lillis, George Harrison, Herbert Pas- coe, William Woodeson, Henry. Balmer, Henry Steinhardt. During June Kingston butter fac- tory output was 65 tons 6 cwt., an in- crease of 21 tons over June the pre- vious year. Suppliers were paid 1/4 lb. .The June price would have been 1/8, but for the interference of the Queens land Government in preventing the export of butter to Melbourne. Loss to producers in June due to the inter ference was £2299. . The Beaudesert factory turned out 34 1/2 tons of butter in June which is 8 1/2 tons less than the previous month, and 11 1/4 tons more than June the previous year. Suppliers would be paid 1/5 lb. -first grade. Clr. W. J. Barnes told a meeting of the Beaudesert Shire Council that a few ratepayers were trying to keep noxious weeds down, and it was oniy right that the council should do its best in this respect. The overseer was instructed to inspect some properties, and report to the next meeting. - A roll of honour list showed the fol lowing names:— Killed: Eugene Mc- Gowan, Grahame Peterson, E. Booth, Phillip O'Brien, Bert. Cooke, John Derrick; prisoner; Maurice Delpratt; wounded: Ewart Bowerman, Gordon Morris, Robert Kydd; Bertram De-l pratt, Andrew Day, Robert Stephens, W. Woods; died of illness: Henry Mac lean, Hugh Moloney, Beryl Corfleld; invalided home: William Drysdale, William O'Brien, Arnold Graham, Aus- tin Newham, George Picton, Ernest Witshlre. Repaired only a few weeks, some one cut one of the telephone lines at the Beaudesert rifle range in two places.
heading: IMPROVED FACILITIES

articleText:
NEW SHIRE CHAIRMAN'S \ VIEWS c

With the publication of today's ; Beaudesert "Times" the new Beau- £ desert Shire Council comes into - office. "

Following the announcement of the latest position on Monday, Mr. E. E. Henley, the new chairman, « .was approached to seek his views \ on several matters of interest to J the public. / Asked if he had any comment to J make upon the result of the poll, Mr. ? Henley said that lie was most' gratified J with the result: and asked the "Times" 1 to convey his thanks to the electors of \ the shire for according him such an J overwhelming majority vote. ? "It Js most gratifying to me," said J Mr. Henley, "that I should have re- J ceived a one hundred per cent, major- If ity vote, particularly in the town Di- J vision (No. 5) where I have lived for over fifty years." Ij ' "It is a great pity that some of the J younger citizens could not offer them- S selves for the position," said Mr. Hen- j ley. "I know several of our young coun- J cillors and citizens who are very cap- if able in this regard, and who would do \ full justice to the high office of chair- 5 man of the shire. i| "However, now that I have been J chosen to occupy the position, the elec- tqrs may rest assured that I shall do the job to the best of my ability." Asked if lie had any particular ideas , on the question of town improvement, : Mr. Henley said that he certainly had. E Much had been said, in the press, about the lack of civic pride which existed in Beaudesert at the present time, but : this was not to be wondered at. : Mr. Henley- added: "For example, we are not proud of our Council's head- : quarters. One has only to glance at the i dingy old station building, strewn with ! debris, worn out lino on the floors of the Council "chamber" (spare the : word) , leaky walls, two clocks that i ;won't go, a creaky electric fan, and a i motley brass plate screwed to the door, j which, if one peers through the dirt, : will indicate that here is the 'office of i one of the wealthiest shires in the \ state.' j "The miserable accommodation pro- : vided for our office staff, and the en- i tire lack of housing for our shire equip- \ ment, must surely receive the early at- j tention of the councillors. . i "I do not favour outside divisions i contributing to the cost of any 'wild j cat' schemes which may be advanced ' from time to time, but I do think all should contribute toward the cost of erecting decent headquarters for our staff." Mr. Henley said that lie was wholly in favour of a practical scheme for a water supply In the town area, but he stressed the point that the consumers must pay for this work, and not those outside a benefited area. Besides hundreds of personal con gratulations, Mr. Henley has received many letters and telegrams from all parts of the M'oreton electorate wish ing him well in his new office.
heading: NEW SHIRE CHAIRMAN'S VIEWS

articleText:
LOCAL AND GENERAL

/ SIGN OF THE TIMES ?

An hotel proprietor advertised In the Brisbane Press for a yardman and very soon after received 15 replies, the applicants, without exception, being discharged servicemen. Seme had around the five years service.

CHANGE IN POLICE Sgt. T. Holding, officer in charge pf the Beaudesert Police Station, has en tered on two months leave. During his absence Sgt. H. A. James will be In' charge. The relieving sergeant, who comes from Woolnngabba Depot, is no stranger to the district, having been on temporary duties In the past. RACING MAN KICKED _ James Ledger, 64, a married man re siding at Hendra, Brisbane, was assist ing to' load horses into a float at the Beaudesert racecourse on Wednesday afternoon when one of . the animals lashed out and kicked him on the left shoulder. The impact was so severe that the left collarbone was fractured. The injured man sought the services of the Beaudesert Ambulance Brigade bearer. After attention he was advised to seek medical treatment.

articleText:
A LONG JOURNEY

Times have changed.

Tms is wnat me Beaudesert | 'Tnncs" of October 29, ldlti, nad , to say: A long amoulance journey: i One of the motor cars of tlie

i Brisbane Ambulance Brigade 1 uuv tiietJ no fewer than 112 rinlcs | over bad roads to succour a man wno uad ines witn an acciiiuiii, and took him to the uiaiei, in.- . ...iniey Hitting 12 hours, anil tne rimbuiance men not getting baek lo tlie city till midnight. Tne ac cident happened at (Janungra. Alex O'hcyne, a carpenter, in the em ploy of Lahey's Ltd., fell througn the floor of a building in process of erection, and sustained internal injuries. 'Tne same issue included: At a meeting of the Tabragaiba Branca of tne Queensland Farmers Union a letter was received lroni the chan-man ol the shire council setting lorth that the council employees were disinclined to work in the Tabragaiba district, owing to their inabinty to procure grass for their horses. The reading of this letter caused some con siderable indignation, as the sta.ement w<is wionout loundation. A ietter to the "Times" stated that it was known that gambling had been, and was stni being carried on, most glaringly, it was to be hoped those in authority would not be deluded from doing their duty. It was not uncom mon, in strolling down the street, to hear dice being thrown. Then again, they could see prohibitioners wa.King in and out of hotels at their own sweet will. "Ned" Walsh, well known at Paien Creek, and who has been ailing for a considerable time, died in the Beau- desert Hospital early yesterday morn ing. O. Rohde, carpenter, of Beaudesert, cut his left hand rather severely at Canungra. Dr. Beet attended the suf- lerer, who is now doing very well. The latest casualty list included the following: Sgt. J. L. Gordon, severely. ' wounded; Pie. A. P. Bowerman, sev erely wounded, previously reported wounded; Pic. D. McAuley, wounded. A presentation was made to Miss Higgms at a function at the Bromel- ton State School. Miss Higgins was go ing on extended leave for three months.

articleText:
1 30 YEARS AGO |

. On Friday, June 16, 1916, a fare well to service personnel was held at Beaudesert according to- the Beaudesert "Times" file of June

23, 1916. On the stage were Dr. J. Shirley, Messrs. deB. B. Persse, G. D. Stan- fleld, J. A. Walker, G. M. Dash, (G.R.G.), S. II. Skipper and others. Souvenirs were presented to the fol lowing: Corp. r. a. Evans, Lance Corp. G. J. Geary. Privates M. C. Walsh, Young, D. W. Tullock, W. G. Stanley and N. C. Fredericksen. Nur.se Hart, who was In camp at Enoggera, was also presented with a souvenir by Mrs. deB. B. Persse. The election of officers at the annual meeting of the Kerry Jockey Club re sulted as follows: Patron, Mr. J. G. Appel, MXi.A.; president, Mr. A. Mark- well; vice president, Mr. L. Dunne; committee, Messrs. T. and J. Rafter, J. Gannon T. Ward, W. Johnston, V/. F. Wilkie, J. R. Smith, C. M. Gomm, T. F. Plunkett, D. Gorman J. Power, P. Smith, R. Deerain, J. O'Reiliy; secre tary. Mr. T. Dunne; treasurer, Mr. J. Rafter. At a function at Canungra, Mr. Ty son, officer in charge of the Canungra sub-centre . of the Q.A.T.B., and Mrs. Tyson, were farewelled. The wedding of Miss Ina Smith (eld est daughter of the late Mr. James Smith, of Cudgen, and Mrs. Smith, Chinghee Creek) and Mr. A. E. Stein- hard t (eldest son of the late Mr. Stein- hardt, and Mrs. Steinhardt, Widgee Creek) took place in St. Thomas Church, Beaudesert, on June 21. Rev. A. C. F)int""performed the ceremony. The bride was given away by Mr. R. Smith, and the bridesmaids were Miss E'sie Smith and Miss May Steinhardt. The bridal frock -was of white crepe de chene trimmed with shadow lace. The wreath and veil were kindly loaned by an old friend of the bride. Mrs. W. Oates. The wedding breakfast was served at the Grand Hotel. The bride looked very nice In her going away dress, a grey coat and skirt, and hat to match. The honeymoon will be spent at Tweed Heads.

articleText:
HAVE YOU BEEN TOLD ABOUT—

At the August meeting of the Beau desert Bowhng Club committee there was some straight talking, and this was reported in tne Beaudesert "Times"

under the heading of "Nipped in the Bud." At a committee meeting last week one selector said that the selec tors had finalised the matter between themselves. The remarks made at the time did no harm, and further discus sion would do no good. A motion on the subject had not ueen required at the time, as tne se-ectors tnemseives could settle their differences amicably. The meeting received a letter from one selector, and an explanation from an other who was not at the previous meeting. The last word was that the' committee felt that the business had been clarified. The chap who tried his lawnmower out last Sunday morning in anticipa tion. The voter who did not like the "How to Vote" card handed her on Saturday, and threw it to the ground, and put her foot on it for luck. Ti e con ten s of the parcel of "bread" that fell and broke. The Logan and A.bert Co-operative Dairy Association is holding £2929 in war savings certificates subscribed to by supp .eis and s aif. At tlie annual meeting of suppliers to the Beaudesert butter factory, Mr. N. C. Webb asked If by any chance employees were being worked overtime for which they were not paid. Manager W. Wilshire said the only man not paid for ove.time worked was himself. Mr. T. Flood Plunkett (chairman) said the men saw that they put their time sheets in. Nobody should work for noth'ng. The factory paid what the men were entitled to. On Monday night the parents of a man injured in an aeroplane crash at Tenterfield were being taken by car from Archerfleld, where they had tended after their journey by air from Longreach, to Tenterfield, and it was found that all cafes at Beaudesert had closed. The arrangements were in the hands of the Red Cross Society, and naturally the local secretary (Mrs. J. S. Cochrane) was contacted. She was able to provide a meal for the travel lers, who then carried on their journey Sir Alfred paid two ticket holders £5/6/- each on the totalisator at the Beaudesert races on Wednesday. Had he won. instead of filling third place, he would have paid £15/18/6 for each 5/- ticket. The turnover of £350/15/- was an average day for the "tote." During the Beaudesert races on Wednesday somebody dropped a lighted cigarette in the grandstand, and a policeman, with a bucket of water, was called on to put out what could have developed into a fire. The young lady, who had her py jamas chewed by a dog. A delegate to tlie Cricket Association meeting on Wednesday night returned home to And cricket still the chief at traction. He had a bat and ball in his bed. There was a scrap on the dance floor at the dance on Wednesday night. There was an unusual "engagement" late last Friday night. Two workmates disagreed over incidents on the job, and one was so keen to settle the mat ter there and then that he doffed his coat. The other, fortunately, showed better judgment. Even though they ' were on their own at the time, the arm of the law walked along shortly after. The chap who changed his mind and found that a "How to Vote" card would be handy after all. Beaudesert had its spasms at the week-end. There was a continual broadcast over a public address system on Saturday morning and afternoon, the latter period being devoted to sporting sessions. On Sunday morning, and again at night, a piano accordeon was played on a hotel balcony. Of course there was also the usual ping pong matches. Some of the paper contents of the money bag stolen from the Rose Cafe has been found, and it can be assumed that cheques included have been dis posed of. . . . The reference to a "generous" chap who could be" reiied on to give away last year's calendar. Either the horse must have grown, or the horse box had shrunk, but we noticed on Wednesday two horses In the one float, one fitting in quite nicely. As the other's tail was hanging out at the back the base of ltT»oc . securely wrapped, apparently to pre vent it rubbing on the back board, which fitted about four Inches below the tail.

In the Ladies' Bowls three bowls pairs semt-flnal yesterday Mesdames G. Day and J. Aldridge defeated Mes dames Goodwin (substituting for Mrs. Tester) and Hankey 25-23. Winners meet Mesdames J. Bogle and S. Dauth. Mesdames Brownlle and Jurd 33 v. Mrs. Winnett and D. Knowles 15. . Mesdames Burgess, Gardiner, Smith, Dauth 26 v. Mesdames Bourke. Tom linson, Schmidt, Mr. Bourke 25.
heading: HAVE YOU BEEN TOLD ABOUT
snippet: At the August meeting of the Beaudesert Bowling Club committee there was some straight talking, and this was reported in the Beaudesert "Times"

articleText:
FORGOTTEN PROMISES?

Recently the Beaudesert 'Times" published a statement by the Beau desert National Fitness Committee that the work of a party of farmers

ai> namingLon naa not oeen appre ciated by tiie authorities. The original letter to Mr. T. R. Doyle, secretary of the Hillview L.P.A. at the time, states that while the desire of bodies to assist by clearing tracks was appreciated the park was under the control of the Forestry Department, and any falling of or interference with vegetation, without apthority, was a breach of the law. The Department was formulating plans for the devel opment of the park which would be impossible of fulfilment if local bodies acted independently. That letter of June 1. 1937. was fol lowed by one on November 9. 1938. which stated . that intention of tiie previous letter was to bring under notice the necessity for securing per mission before cutting tracks. If the L.PA. desired permission to cut tracks further particulars were desired. It had not been possible to extend trie work to Christmas Creek area, but it was intended to bring the area within the scheme later. A newspaper report at the time credited Mr. T. L. Amos, aircraft in spector for Queensland or the Civil Aviation Department,, as saying that the Forestry Department had made arrangements to have the track from Lamington to the mountain graves of the victims of the Stinson disaster cleared twice a year. Mr. G. F. Mavor, secretary organiser of the Beaudesert National Fitness Committee, said trie track had not been cleared in the last few years.

articleText:
WISHFUL THINKING 30 YEARS AGO

Thirty .years ago the Beaudesert "Times" was hopeful that it would soon see a water supply scheme in Beaudesert, judging by the follow-

ing paragraph appealing in the issue of June 2, 1916: The work of surveying in con nection with the proposal to con struct a reservoir oil the Upper Lagan River is still prccecding. It is said that If this work is ever - carried out the line will come " within six miles of Beaudesert. That will mean a permanent water supply for the town. "Random Pars" in the same issue in cluded: May was a very dry month in Beau desert District. Hardly a drop of rain fell.

At the Q.T.C. autumn meeting at New Farm, Mr. deBurgh Pcrsse's chest nut colt Bachelor's Persse (imp.) was successful In winning a double. On Sat urday he won the Highweight Handi cap of 200 sovereigns, and on Monday the First Welter Handicap of 200 sovereigns. Not very long ago a man from this district was interned: he is alleged to be of enemy parentage. A petition was prepared asking for his release; and the man is again at large. The passenger traffic on the Beau desert railway is not very brisk at pre sent. On Tuesday night the train brought in one passenger, and he was a railway cleaner. Business is reported as being dull on the Northern Rivers of N.S.W. And it is not too brisk In Beaudesert. The profit from the recent Beau desert show was £60. Other articles stated: Sgt. E. W. Jenyns. who enlisted from Tambovine, was wounded in Franco. Frank, son of Mr. and Mrs. George SJieppard, was promoted to the rank of Second Lieutenant. Rev. Hill, of the Baptist Church, was given a farewell. A meeting discussed the position of the Town Band and those present who had been members ot the band agreed to attend the first p: actice. There was every prospect of trie band being suc cessfully restarted.
heading: WISHFUL THINKING 30 YEARS AGO

articleText:
"fifTLE m 3J YEARS AGO

Recording' a cattle sale at Beau desert 30 years ago llic Beaudesert "Times" file of March 3, 1916, states 300 head were yarded, and

that buyers were plentiful and good prices were realised. Poddy steers brought to £2/3/6; . yearling steers to £3/18/-; poddy heifers £2/2/-; yearling heifers £3/3/-; dry cows £3/10/- to £5/2/6; springers to £5/15/-; cows with calves to £6/5/-. A mob of 40 bul locks were not yarded because of the extreme heat. » The ''Times" paid tribute to the splendid productive orchard owned by Mr. Stan. Balmer, and commented on the class of persimmon being produced. One cluster of twelve fruit presented a fine appearance. Raimall figures were shown as; January 313 points, February 716; 'In gram," Woodhill (Mr. W. H. Brockle- bank), February 603 points; Beenleigh, January 189 points, February 913 points. Private H. E. Bowerman, who had been ill. had returned to duty. The following volunteers enlisted during the week:' Henry Herbert Stein- hardt of Hillview; Horace Twining, Ashfield, Sydney; Ernest George Dauth. Beaudesert; Bartram Barnark, Glen- eagle; William Todd, Bromelton. Railway Ganger Selvage was fare- welled prior to leaving Logan Viltage. It was stated that the recent wet weather caused a recurrence of the tick pest in an aggravated form. Owners were reminded that they had to dip their cattle before taking them to the sale yards. The following team was selected to represent the Logan and Albert Cricket Association in the match against Southport at Beenleigh: Dr. Beet, R. J. Fuller, J. Shepherd. G. Markham, F. J. Horner, A. .Rosin, J. E. Markweli, O. C. Schmidt, C. Stretton. P. Cecil. R. Woods. The "Times" complained that the light at the post office had died down to a miserable flicker that could hardly be seen from a few yards distance. It added : This is in no way a good ad vertisement for such an important in stitution. Perhaps the officer in charge could manage to get the loan of a lar ger and better lamp from one of our benevolent townspeople, that is if the Department will not allow him to buy one t from office funds. District Orders gave the following promotions: Capt. W. E. Markweli, 2nd Light Horse, to be Major, and Second Lieut. E. A. F. Stanfiold, 5th Light Horse Regiment, to be lieutenant.

articleText:
" COUNCIL WORRIES 30 YEARS AGO

The Beaudesert War Council was faced with a problem, accord ing to the Beaudesert "Times" of Friday April 28th, 1916.' A report of the meeting stated:

"Mr. D. Stanfleld reported that in

accordance with instructions received form the committee, he had endeav oured to arrange for speakers to visit Beaudesert on Anzac Day, but owing to the limited time he was unable to secure any prominent man to visit the town, as they had made arrangements to speak at other centres. A general discussion took place, and the town council was severely dealt with for the manner in which the matter was mismanaged, before asking the council to do anything in the matter. "Messrs. Jenyns and Durrand moved that Messrs Jenyns, Walker and Stain- field wait on the Town and Shire Coun cils with a view to getting a more har monious working between the three bodies. The motion was carried. The latest volunteers to join the colours were: J. Buckley, of Undulla, Woodhill; Gavern Edwards, and Ed ward Fraser, Beaudesert. Messrs W. G. Stanley and B. Fraser entered camp during the week. H. G. Tommerup, of Kerry, who rec ently went to Fraser's paddock, had been promoted to rank of second lieu tenant, and left for the Military Col lege, Duntroon. Woodenbong and Beaudesert met in a rifle shoot at Rathdowney range. The Woodenbong team won by 35 points. The report states: We under stand that the original arrangement ;for this match was between Rathdown- 'ey and Woodenbong, but when the team arrived at Rathdowney there was no team there to meet them. The cap tain of the Beaudesert team was com municated with, and he agreed to take a team of five, the other three to be obtained at Rajthdowney. When Beau desert arrived, no Rathdowney men were seen, so Beaudesert was three men short. Scores were: Dr. Beet 73, J. A. Wal ker 66. W. G. Stanley 65, H. Smith 53, Serg. Hurford 52. Woodenbong's 344 were made up of: T. Weary 56, E. Mol oney 55, H. Pethers 51, J. Powell 46, W. White 44, A. Taylor 38. C. Graham 28, G. Johnson 26. Officals elected to the Laravale Branch of the Queensland Farmers Union were Messrs. J. Hodgson (pres.), A. Parker and G. Hursthouse (vice presidents) F. Stretton (treasurer), Wl. Hart (delegate), and F. Arthy (hon. secretary). Mr. J. P. Moran addressed the meeting.
heading: COUNCIL WORRIES 30 YEARS AGO

articleText:
ORGANISERS OF SOCIAL FUNCTIONS

Organisers of social functions etc., desiring publication of proceedings should forward an invitation to the Beaudesert "Times." or to the author-

ised correspondent of the "Times" in ample time to allow of arrangements, being made for attendance. ELECTRICITY EXTENSION The poles for about half the trans mission line of 12 miles required to connect Beaudesert with the City Electricity Light Co. scheme have been erected. If rain does not fall before the end of the month only about three miles of poles will remain to be erected. There are about 12 poles to the mile. It is exected that a start with the wiring will be made at the begining of the week. VISITING SCHOOLBOYS Tomorrow will be a red letter day for budding Bradmans of the district as between forty and fifty boys from St. Lawrences College, Brisbane, will visit Beaudesert. They propose to spend the day with cricket matches. Combin ed teams will be picked to try conclu sions with the visitors. Boys desiring a game . could contact Father Steele. The players will be asked to cater for themselves, and one visitor. When the return match is to be played the Bris bane boys will do the catering. Players are requested to be at Selwyn Park at 10.30.

articleText:
(To the Editor)

Sir, — I would be grateful if you would grant me space to reply to Mr. T. F. Flunkett's letter appearing in the Beaudesert "Times" 15/2/46.

Mr. PlunkettJias avoided committing himself as to whether the L. and A. Dairy Assoc. holds a monopoly or not. I still maintain that they do hold a monopoly over milk and cream, whe ther it be by legal privilege or other wise, and I base my opinion on the meaning of the word "monopoly" as shown in Fowlers Oxford Dictionary. Mr. Plunkett states that the distribu tion of £265,058 is a very worthy achievement. The L. & A. Assoc. would have been in a much prouder position if they could have said they distributed this amount under a purely voluntary co-operative effort, against all com petition, like the two Co-operative Bacon Associations, operating in Beau desert, can say. The position as I see it is that the L. & A. Assoc. distributed this amount under cover of a mono poly, whereby it was practically made a compulsory co-operative effort with out competition. Mi'. Plunkett says that I held a license under the Cream -Transport Regulations which gave me the sole right to a particular cream route and says he does not remember me saying anything about monopoly at that time. That is quite correct. I, like the L. & A. Assoc., was in business before these regulations were gazetted, and on their gazettal about 1937, 'I admit that it gave me a monopoly over my particu lar cream route, the same as it gave the L. & A. Assoc. a 'monopoly over the cream in this district, but Mr. Plunkett failed to mention, that at the first available opportunity, I gave up that monopoly because it conflicted with my principles. We still find Mr. Plunkett controlling the L. & A. monopoly de spite the fact that he has publicly an nounced that he is opposed to mono polies. Mr. Plunkett also is not too sure that there are any discontenters. I refer him to the report of the Q.D.O. meet ing in Beaudesert "Times" 15/2/46. Producers and carriers have more to do than to go on deputations of this na ture if they have no cause for com plaint. Mr. Plunkett refers to the refusal of permits for necessary buildings. It would be interesting to know whetner the permits were refused for extensions to the present factory so as to cope with the cream situation or if the per mits were for buildings to manufacture powdered milk. Then Mfi-. Plunkett gives what he calls solid soothing facts. One of them being that milk supply having priority No. 1 had to be re ceived and treated with limited space first, thus delaying the delivery of cream into the factory. The milk supply had No. 1 priority long before the L. & A. Asoc. decided to dabble in it, and I would like to know why. with such limited space, was the L. & A. Assoc. plunged into the milk trade so soon when the direc tors had all those solid soothing facts, of no manpower, no materials, no per mits, no transport etc., before them. The solid facts are that the L. & A.. Assoc. has entered the milk trade be fore they were properly equipped to handle milk, consequently the cream has to suffer by standing on the road up to four or five hours, and cream producers can do nothing about it be cause the factory holds a monopoly over this cream. Not so soothing for those who are concerned. More like a bitter pill, but Mr. Plunkett has led us to believe it will be oaky-doaky. in the sweet by and by. (If some solid soothing fact does not intervene). Mr. Piunkett's comparison of grad- ings between 1944 and 1945 periods are amusing because four of the peak months in the 1944 period were graded under the same conditions as the 1945 period. It would be interesting to re call at this stage that for the year ending 30th June 1945, the L. & A. Assoc. had 27.57 per cent, of it's so called choice butter officially graded back to first grade and 125 boxes of the same choice butter graded into second grade; the 1943 figures show only 7.98 per cent, to be graded back. With this rapid advance what will the 1946 figures show? It is not the grade appearing on the cream slip, which are the monthly re turns submitted to the Department of Agriculture, that Mr. Plunkett has re ferred to. These are only eye-wash. It is the final official grading that ulti mately determines the price to be paid. Mr. Plunkett replies to my statement that suppliers are paying the price for delays by reduction in grade of cream, by stating that such statements are not borne out by facts. The facts are that for the year end ing 30th June 1945, out of a total of 45,732 boxes of butter submitted for grading only 27,074 boxes, representing 59.2 per cent., were officially graded as choice, leaving 40.8 per cent, of the yearly output as lower grades. The 1943 figures are 79.58 per cent, choice and 20.42 per cent, lower grades, thus showing an increase of 100 per cent. In lower grades in 1945. More soothing facts to show all is not well. Mr. Plunkett states that it was the present Government that brought in the Cream Transport Act. The Act was brought in by a Forgan Smith Government about 1937 and not by the present Government. I admit that I advised the Q.D.O. to take this matter of cream delays up with the appropriate authorities and not wait on the factory directors to be told solid soothing facts. The Q.D.O. already has the facts and I feel sure if these facts were placed before the pro per authorities steps would be taken to alter the conditions at the factory, either by Act of Parliament or other wise. In conclusion I would say that I can take anything Mr. Plunkett, as head of the L. & A. Assoc.. ean Inflict on me without the aid of Parliament as Mr. Plunkett suggests I should get. It is not with any thought of personal gain that I have taken up my pen but with the object of improving the conditions for farmers and carriers of this district. Yours etc. —

J. B. JENKINSON.
heading: (To the Editor)
snippet: Sir,--I would be grateful if you would grant me space to reply to Mr. T. F. Plunkett's letter appearing in the Beaudesert "Times" 15246.

articleText:
CAR REGISTRATION TAX

(To the Editor)

Sir,— Reading In your council reports in the Beaudesert "Times" I notice the roads are in a very bad condition. I would like to ask if the reason is that

the Main Roads Commission is collect ing excessive car registration and plac ing the money in the Victory Loan, in stead of spending the money on the roads or public works, for which pur pose it is collected. I would also like to know if this is legal. A statement shows that £120,000 was placed to loan by the Main Roads Commission. I would also like to ask through your columns if the 3id. In the pound gen eral rates collected by the councils for hospitals and the hospital boards, is going to be continued in our rates see ing we have a provincial social tax at a higher rate in our income tax payable this year. We men on the land already pay 31d. in the pound for hospitals to the councils In last year's rates, During Mr. Forgan Smith's time as Premier there also was £125,000 taken from the proceeds of the Golden Cas ket and placed to revenue, whereas usual proceeds go to building hospitals .and assisting hospitals, would not this amount have reduced our taxa.tlon? Yours etc. —

F. W. ARMSTRONG. Loganlea.

articleText:
Beaudesert Show Outstanding Success

VISITORS SEE QUALITY

Dairy and Beef Cattle and Pigs are Outstanding

Big Crowd Enjoys First Peace Time Exhibition

BEAUDESERT'S FIFTY-FIRST (SHOW HELD ON WEDNESDAY AND YESTERDAY TRULY PROVED TO BE,tTHE SHOP-WINDOW OF THE DISTRICT BECAUSE IT REVEALED TO SOME MEASURE THE CAPACITY OF THE VAST AREAS OF RICH FERTILE LANDS SURROUNDING THE LOGAN AND ALBERT RIVERS TO GROW THE BEST IN LIVESTOCK AND AGRICULTURAL PRODUCE.

The show, which had much of the gaiety of pre-war events associated with it, will be a memorable one because of the changes that have taken place in the show grounds. The new ring was used for the first time, and it served a long-felt want. THE GROUNDS HAD BEEN MOWN, BUILDINGS REPAIRED AND PAINTED, AND THESE PRO VIDED A SPLENDID- SETTING FOR THE SIDESIUIW TENTS, STALLS, GAILY JACKETED HORSE MEN, AND SMARTLY DRESSED WOMEN. THE ENERGY EXPENDED BY THE LOGAN AND ALBERT AGRICULTURAL AND PASTORAL . SOCIETY IN THE PAST YEAR WAS WELL WORTH WHILE BECAUSE IT GAVE RESULTS, AND SERVED .TO SHOW WHAT CAN BE DONE IF THE PROGRAMME OF IMPROVEMENTS INVISAGED IS PROCEEDED WITH FROM YEAR TfP"YEAR. A notable visitor was the newly appointed Minister l'or Agriculture and Slock (Mr. II. 11. Collins), who performed the opening ceremony yesterday. There were many visitors from all parts of the district, as well as further afield, and they could not but be impressed with the quantity, as well as quality of the exhibits. The show celebrations included a smoke social on Wednesday night, a ball last night, and the two day bushmcn's carnival to be held at Eclbogan course today and tomorrow will be concluded with a dance tomorrow night.

Visitors mode favourable comment on the splendid appearance of the grounds. The ring, which is carrying a fairly good body of gress after being planted for' such a short period, was clearly defined: with the new white fence, the flags marking the track, and the new hunting hurdles. The grandstand is a vantage point, and patrons viewed the events in com parative comfort. The scene in front of them was a pleasant one. The grounds have as their background, a patch of small trees, and these should be preserved for all times because they give just that finishing touch that an agricultural and pastoral exhibition re quires. The exhibition hall had been bright ened with the aid of quantities of paint, and the floors freshly covered with a layer of sawdust, something that is al ways associated with country shows. Pig and cattle pens had been given necessary attention, and there was ample bedding for livestock. A show without sideshows would lose some of its fascination to both young and old, and many the child and par ent that would go home disappointed if they could not fall for the lure of the sweet, fairyfloss and waffle stall. Sideshow alley was an attraction for young and old, with its shows, games and other attractions. There was a miniature, steam train, small aeroplanes for the children, as well as the larger ones that give the adults a thrill. Snakes alive, and plenty of them were the main draw at one tent, and early arrivals saw some of the bi fellows crawling about the grounds. The kids enjoyed seeing the monkeys riding the small ponies, and there was much speculation about the pony billed as one of the smallest in the world. The gloves were out for the contests in the tent show. There was plenty of action, and those who did not venture within enjoyed the performances out side. Cricketers, who are generally dead on the wicket, were given ample scope with three or four skittle alleys, and dart players were given a chance to show their ability. The alley was well set out, with ample room in the avenue for the crowds that

gathered to hear the spruikers tell of the wonders that they would see once the doorkeeper collected their coin. \ The State Rural School display of work produced at the school was o'f a very high standard, and was fav ourably commented on by all who saw it. Parents were able to sec just wha'l their children are taught right from the initial stages until they become proficient in all work. The girls showed what they can", do in the domestic science section, and many a mother remarked on the clear ness of the jams and jellies, as well commented on the finish of some of the other products. The boys are given a wonderful op portunity to bring out any talent they might have. In addition to the many- smaller articles that are very handy in the home there was such things as a laundry waggon step ladder, shaving cabinet and traymobile. Lads who pass right through the sad dlery section are proficient as far as producing many articles necessary on the farm, or mending and patching. There should not be a leaky dish, or handleless bucket, if the class of tin- smithing work is any criterion. The agricultural, fruit and. vege table sections were not as well pat ronised as they might have been, but there was some splendid articles on show. There was ample proof, if any is re quired, that the district has the soil and climate necessary to grow almost every type of farm produce. The potatoes were most outstanding, and there was a good deal of discus sion over the weight of the cattle pumpkins shown. When it was men tioned that Mr. G. Teese's biggest pumpkin weighed 175 lb., it was stated that this was only a small one as last year he -showed one that topped the scale at 209 lb. The stock melon that appeared to be a giant to some people was said to be a miniature-, others in the past having weighed 114 lb. The culinary efforts of the women folk of the district caught the eye of all. The articles were shown to advan tage in glass cases in the pavilion. (Continued on column six)

Johnson's Rosalie's Repulses Hazelette. Jersey type and production. 273. day test for M. Flynn's prize. — H. Johnson's Windsor Lady Gladys, production 418.748 lb. butter fat, standard junior 3. 270 lb. standard, points awarded for production 30, 36 for type, 1; H. John son's Windsor Lady Deanna, 374.83, 270 lb„ 21 points, 43 type, 2, (Continued on page seven)

(Continued from column two) With the limited stocks available in these difficult times Beaudesert busi ness houses made a brave showing with their displays. Several motor vehicles were lined up, and there were tractors and . other pieces of farm machinery. It was good to see refrigerators on show, and a line up of push bicycles. Beaudesert produced furniture of a high standard was Included In the pavilion display. The grounds were a hive of industry early on Wednesday morning prepar ing for the judging. This went oS well, exhibitors giving every assistance. There were three judging rings hi operation for the cattle, and the re spective judges were given a severe task. ' Cattle men studied the fat bullock and the competition proved a keen one. The animal will be slaughtered and the announcement of its weight will be awaited with interest. Judges, at a smoke social in the Grand Hotel ballroom on Wednesday night, spoke very highly of the qual ity of the stock seen tiiat day. The President (Mr. H. Bruxner), who presided, congratulated exhibitors who did so well. Visitors had remarked on the wonderful quality of the exhibits. The society always set out to get the best judges possible, and he was sure all agreed they had a splendid body of judges that day. , Responding to a toast in honour of the judges, Mr. J. F. Burnett (Harris- ville) said that he was very impressed with the setting of the grounds. The alterations were most marked, and Beaudesert had the makings of one of the sweetest little grounds in Queens land. Entries in the cattle classes that day were astounding.- The maiden hack drew 20 competitors, which was rather outstanding, and there were some good horses. The pony mare winner would be hard to beat anywhere In Queens land. Taken all through' the Society should feel highly satisfied with the show, and the fine horses competing. Mr. Bruxner apologised lor the ab sence of Mr. H. Simpson, who judged the beef cattle. He said Mr. Simpson asked him to repeat the fact that he said he had judged quite a lot of fat cattle at different shows, but he had never judged a better lot than he did

that day. They were fit to win in any show he had been toi Mr. Bruxner said that coming from such an eminent judge that was pleas ing news. Mr. James, A.I.S. judge, said it was the third occasion he officiated at Beaudesert, and he always looked for ward to seeing the Beaudesert people again. He congratulated the A.I.S. exhibitors on the wonderful show of cattle, and the condition they were produced hi. Some outstanding stock was paraded before him. "I travelled nearly 1000 miles to be with you today, and I am, not sorry," said Mr. S. Larbalestier, Judge of the Jerseys. He said' that a Victorian judge once advised him that Queenslanders were the greatest people on earth. He found this out. When he arrived tliey put him in a home away from home. Mr. Larbalestier said that the Jer sey section was a very creditable one for a country show, and one of the best he had seen. The winning pen of ' three cows — and there were nine en tries — was one of the finest he had seen for many a day. The young champion cow was the ideal type they looked for, and the champion bull was something out of the bag — a beautiful bull who would go a long way. Tire Ayrshire judge, Mr. J. Brownlie, found his section one of the best he had seen at a country show in Queens land, and he had been at many as judge and exhibitor. The section was small in quantity, but not in quality. He saw the finest type of cow they would see in Australia. The grounds were ideal for a country show. He con gratulated the exhibitors on the way they produced their cattle. They went to as much trouble as if they were showing in the Royal National show. He expected to see some of the stock at the Brisbane exhibition in August. He congratulated Mr. Dunn who was showing a fine team at his first show. Mr. Dunn had quality In his herd. Speaking on the stud pigs, Mi'. M. Moffatt. of Billlnudgel, said: It has been my privilege to judge many Queensland shows. You produced ex hibits today in one of the finest shows I have seen outside of the Brisbane Royal (Continued on page seven)

A WORTHY TRIBUTE Mr. Sam Loughbridge, of Bris bane, judged the Agricultural and Dairy Produce Sections at this year's Beaudesert show, and in do ing so broke a promise made to himself that lie would not be avail able for this year's shows. Mr. Loughbridge said that the only exception was Beaudesert. lie liatl refused a number of requests to attend other shows. lie first came to judge, a show at Beaudesert 32 years ago. — On<?" of '-thV-'sleWavas, '"Mr." X" P.' Deerain, was with Mr. Loughbridge at both shows mentioned.

Beaudesert Show Outstanding Success (Continued from page one) Mr. Moffatt continued: I am pleased to say " that? with the exception of a few, all were of cor rect type with long bodies and fine shoulders, and would hold their place anywhere in N.S.W. or Queensland. Mr. Moffatt said that some young pigs would be heard of in Brisbane later in the year. It was pleasing to see the young stock coming on. The cham pions of today would not hold their place next show as a fine lot of youngs ters were coming on. Five outstanding sows were put before him, and the winners were closely pressed by the , young sows. It was lite third visit to Beaudesert. He congratulated the breeders on the way they brought the pigs out. The judge of the export pigs was disappointed at the small number seen, but this was attributed to con ditions in the industry today. lie ad vocated young farmers being present at shows so that the decisions of the judges could be explained to them. He said that England did not want fat bacon. Australia had to breed to type, and the sooner producers con centrated on the long lean hog the better. He said the Government should prevent the export of fat pigs. Fat pigs were of no use, and only a waste of good feed. What was wanted for the Australian trade was wanted by Eng land. Mr. F. Walsh of the Department of Agriculture and Stock, who was in charge of the milk testing, said two of the classes provided keen competition. The cow that won the open also won last year which proved it was 110 fluke. A return of 1.0 lb. of butter fat was a very good performance. The class of cattle was very good. Mr. L. Barnes was Master of Cere monies, and he entertained with some conjuring tricks. Solos were contributed by Messrs. T. Bourke and J. Enrlght and Mr. G. Dauth was at the piano.
heading: Beaudesert Show Outstanding Success VISITORS SEE QUALITY Dairy and Beef Cattle and Pigs are Outstanding Big Crowd Enjoys First Peace Time Exhibition

articleText:
WATER CONSERVATION DISCUSSED 30 YEARS AGO

The files of the Bcaudesert Times of January. 28, 1916, show that at the annual meeting of the Woodhill Farmers Union on January 22, a letter was received

from the Water Supply Depart-

inciit relative to utilising nic waters of the Logan River for irrigation purposes. The meeting unanimously agreed to ask the Bcaudesert Shire Council's assistance in conserving the ratepayers' inter ests. The election of officers at the wood- hill Farmers meeting resulted: Presi dent, Mr. V. B. Hinchcliffe; vice presi dent, Mr. E. Kittle; secretary, Mr. Jos. Hopkins; treasurer, Mr. A. Day. A quiet but pretty wedding was cele brated at the home of Mr. Thos. Gor man, Kerry, on December 22. only a few relatives being present. The bride groom was Mr. Henry Bishop, second son of Mrs, Bishop, "Kent Hill," Cedar Creek, and the bride Miss Elizabeth Teresa Gorman, third daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thos. Gorman. The Rev. Father Enright officiated. The bride was given away by her brother, Mr. D. Gorman. The bride was attended by three bridesmaids, Misses Clare Platell (chief), and Mary Platell (nieces of the' bride), Louisa Bishop (sister of the bridegroom). Mr. Ronald Horan was best man, and Mr. John Ward grooms man. The handsome three-tier wedding cake was the work of Mrs. D. C. Fergu- . son, of Beaudesert. Mr. and Mrs. Bishop motored to Beaudesert en route to Brisbane where the" honeymoon was spent. Sapper King, who was telephonist at Beaudesert, wrote from his camp at Alexandria, Egypt. Bolden's announced that all shoe wear was going to rise higher in price. The shoe factories were engaged in military work, and this was likely to advance as time went on.

The return cricket fixture between Bcaudesert and Tabragaiba resulted in the former turning the tables on their opponents. Beaiidesert won by five wickets and 11 runs. It was announced that as each had won a match it would be necessary to play off to see who would meet the winners in the Beenleigh division. G. Markham lop- scored with 23. and Dr. Beet made 17 and 16 respectively. R. J. Fuller's averages were 5 for. 16, and 6 for 25. During the cricket match, Dr. Beet lifted a ball very high towards ihe boundary and a Tamborine Shire councillor, who was a member of Tab- ragalba team, attempted to bring off a difficult catch. The ball passed through his hands and landed on his forehead. Everybody expected to see a patient for the local hospital, but they forgot that councillors are not so easily laid out. After rubbing , his head a little the victim resumed his place in the field, counting it as only one more hard knock. Mollie Skipper was successful in the junior public service examination, and those passing the scholarship examina tion were: Patrick John O'Shea, James Enright (Beaudesert), Henry W. Hunt (Canungra), John Herbert Dauth, Ruby Krebs, Emma Maria R. Hester, and Mona Frances Nixon, of Beenleigh. James Enright' also passed the inter mediate examination in violin. Schools had resumed. Transfers of teachers included: Miss Mona Page from Beaudesert to Hamilton; Miss Jessie Wearing from Beaudasert to Junction Park; Miss Annie LeGrand from Junction Park to Beaudesert.

M. Selwyn Smith and son reported the following prices: Backfatters £4 to £6, medium baconers £4/5/- to £5/10/-, light baconers £3/5/- to £3/18/-, pork ers £2/5/- to £2 '10/6, store pigs (very forward) £1/10/- to £1/15/-, store pigs (medium)- 15/- to £1, weaners and slips 6/- to 11/-. It was stated that Charlie Chaplin in "Charlies New Job" was going to lnake Beaudescrtites laugh in seven teen different keys. Also being shown were "Trinkets of Tragedy" and "A slightly worn gown." Stock Inspector J. II. McCarthy wished to procure quantities of Pieuro Virus as early as possible. He stated he would like to be advised if the disease broke out in any of the district runs or farms so that he could secure sup plies, to be paid for at the usual rates. The L, and A, Jockey Club received work from the Q.T.C. granting permis sion to hold a patriotic meeting on March 2 with exemption as to regis tered and unregistered horses, condi tionally that only horse owners, train ers. and jockeys, not- otherwise dis qualified were allowed to compete, and that the whole or the proceeds lie do nated to tlie patriotic funds. It was decided to drop the March tr.ectin.;. and application was made for a show date.
heading: WATER CONSERVATION DISCUSSED 30 YEARS AGO

articleText:
BIG BLACK SNAKE

Mr. W. R. Murray, Canungra, writes: I notice in the last issue of the Beaudesert "Times," where a large black snake had been killed.

it being 5ft. 6ins. long. I have a snap shot here of a snake of the same specie, measuring 5ft. lllins. I understand that an Australian record for this type of snake is 7ft. However the report is most inter esting, and may still be of further interest.
heading: BIG BLACK SNAKE
snippet: Mr. W. R. Murray, Canungra, writes: I notice in the last issue of the Beaudesert "Times," where a large black snake had been killed.

articleText:
A FORGOTTEN ATTRACTION?

Thirty years ago geological for mations in the district attracted people, as the following from the files of the Beaudesert "Times" of.

August 25, 1916, show. The geolo'gy class from the Brisbane University, consisting of 29 students (maie and female) arrived In Beau- desert and afterwards proceeded to Walsh's farm, Lamington, where a camp was formed. The party was under the leadership of Dr. Richards, of the Brisbane University, who takes a great interest in the geological format.ons on the McPherson Range. The object in view was to give the students an opportunity of studying the geology of the area, as the locality is particu larly interesting, there being consid erable varieties of volcanic rock. The party' visited all localities of interest, including the famous Lamington Plat eau, and Lahey's cutting, and spent a very profitable time. A camp concert was organised, to which all local resi dents were invited, there being be tween 30 and 40 present, and a very p.easant and enjoyable evening was spent. The party, which included 13 ladles, returned to Brisbane on Mon day morning. The same issue states that at the recent Brisbane Exhibition Mr. D. Dunn's splendid cow, Blossom 3rd, was wonderfully successful and carried off the following prizes, in addition to those mentioned last issue: Cow 4 years old and over, averaging greatest dally yield of butter fat in 48 hours (lactation points included), D. Dunn's Ulawarra Blossom 3. 38.47, 1, W. P. Hammers Ayrshire, Sweet Marie, 34.4, 2. Cow, 4 years and over, averaging greatest daily yield of butter fat for 48 hours (lactation points not in cluded), Blossom 3, 35.37, 1, Sweet Marie, 34.4. 2, A. P. Walter's Tulip of Railway View, 33.35, 3. Special prize for national champion butterfat test winner, to be won three times, not necessarily in succession, or by the same exhibit: Blossom 3 (weight of milk 100.13 lb., lactation points 3.1). total 38.47. Previous win ners: D. Dunn's Blossom, Mclntyre Bros. Fancy, A. Pickles' Florrie of Blacklands, C. Bloss's Mary. Mr. D. Dunn's Blossom 3 won the special prize for the cow giving the greatest quan tity of commercial butter fat in 48 hours. Another successful district exhibitor was A. Orme with first in the home cured ham class. In the 1915-16 cricket season Beau- desert Cricket Club won six of the seven matches played. Batting aver ages were: R. J. Fuller 25.1, J. E. Markwell 24.4, C. Stretton 22.1, Dr. Beet 18.2, O. Schmidt 13.1, F. J. Hor ner 12.2, R. O'Shea 11, G. Markham 10.6, P. Cecil 9.8, R. Woods 9.0, A. Rosin 8.8. J. Sheppard 7.7. Fuller won the gold medal presented by Private W. J. Catchpole. Bowling averages in cluded Stretton 12 for 68, Fuller 50 for 301. Markham 24 for 185, Markwell 18 for 156. Mr. J. Willis Jenyns received a cablegram that his brother, Ted, a sergeant, had been seriously wounded, for the second time. An Anzacker, who did his bit at Gallopoli, he was woun ded in France, and after six weeks In England went to Belgium where he was wounded. Mr. G. Harrison, who had been edi tor and leader writer at the Ipswich "Times" for 24 years, visited his bro thers, Messrs. R., S., and W. H. Harri son before leaving for Brisbane to join the staff of the "Courier." The Red Cross Society outing showed a profit of £323. Advice was received that Private George Cook, of Maroon, died on the transport, Westralia. Les King and Leslie Egan were en listments of the week. It was stated that the Great Reaper had been busy on the Logan, at least two of the old pioneers having passed away. Mr. Andrew Drynan snr. one of the bpst known and most highly respected residents of the Up per Logan, passed away at the home of his son, Andrew, at the' age of 80.

He suffered a stroke 15 years pre viously, which greatly impaired his health, and for 31 years was practi cally an invalid. Mr. John Cotter, who came direct from Ireland to the Logan, passed away the day after Mr. Drynan. Mr. Drynan was the first man Mr. Cotter worked for on his arrival. Later he Joined the Tamrookum station staff, and then engaged in grazing on Tam rookum lands on Knapps Creek. He was 56 years of age. Mrs. Skinner of Running Creek, died at the age of 64.
heading: A FORGOTTEN ATTRACTION?

articleText:
j 30 YEARS AGO |

» On November 8, 1916, the Beau desert "Times" gave prominence to the visit to the border of a pic nic party of young people, the means of travel being by horse back.

The assembling point was at the Lamington Hotel, according to the scribe who detailed the happen ings of an enjoyable day. The party consisted of: Misses Power, Misford. Bridget, and C.ssie Doherty. Madge, Birdie, Essie, Cissie. Ei.cen, and Josie Cahiil, Elsie Doyio T. Keaveny, L. Gibson, and Grace Page.. Messrs. Luke O'Reilly, M. B. Sullivan, W. M. Cahiil. A. B. Smith. W. Burgess, M. J. Cahiil, Jack Kea veny j. Burgess. W. Starkey, Dickie Cahiil, S. Manning, O. J. Cah..l, D. Doyle, P. Keaveny. D. P. Cahi,., T. Keaveny, J. Knuth, Pte. F. VVoodgate. The Beaudesert Rifle Club heni a chout mer the SOU 900 and 1,000 yards. Dr. W. A. Beet's score of 94 off the iLle was a good performance. The other rnlcmen failed to come up to the average, the ranges apparently be ing a bit loo diffieu.t. Results were: A. Winship 71 off rifle, total 1)7: Dr. Beet 94. .96: W. Johnston 44, 85; J. A. Walker, 74, 80; J. Fuller 41. 7i: II. Smith 56, 73; ,J. Hawthorne 55. 73; W. Castle 31, 72; J. Holdgatc 6, 47. The voting in Beaudesert in connec tion with conscription was quite, and there was nothing to lead anyone to suppose there was anything more serious than a cattle sale on the tapis. The result of the polling in Beaudes ert was: For Conscription 389. Against 210. Beaudesert and District totals were: Yes 964, No 849. The majority for -No" throughout Australia at -that time was 77,578. Latest information concerning the condition of Sec. Lt. Frank Sheppard, who was dangerously wounded in France, was to the effect that he was convalescent and resting in England. His brother, Fred.r had been trans ferred to a new mine sweeping vessel. .One of the oldest residents of the district, In the person of Henry Francis Francis passed away at the age of 85 years. He left a grown up family of eight, including three daughters. Mes- dames W. W. Ferguson, E, Hill, and J. Gannon. The Beaudesert and District Patrio tic Fund stood at £4050. The Woodhill races added £28 to the amount.

articleText:
NEW YEAR'S DAY

The Beaudesert "Times" office will be closed on New Year's Day (Wednesday next), but will be open for business as usual on Thursday. Advertisements, other than chances

of those appearing weekly, will be accepted until 4 p.m. Thursday.
heading: NEW YEAR'S DAY

articleText:
BIGGER CABBAGES

Mr. R. Teese (Veresdale) wrote to the Beaudesert "Times" of September 17, 1946, that the 13½ lb. cabbage grown by Mr. Toohill was a good one, but they have been

used to pulling cabbages from the garden up to 29 lb. The plants were put in scrub soil, with a very small amount of farm yard manure. The same issue included: At Tabragalba State School a fare- well was given to Pte. Vince Harper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harper, of the State School. Quite a cold snap was experienced, and there was a slight frost in places. Pte. P. Anderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Anderson has been recom- mended for the D.C.M. for gallantry in France. Mr. Verney Chesworth Bur- gess was the only volunteer for the A.I.F. during the week. Pte. Hatfield Bozier was wounded in France. The Queensland "Times" made the following comment: Congratulations to Mr. deBurgh Persse, who is one of the veteran sportsmen in the State, on the success of his imported horse. Bachelor's Persse. in the Queensland Cup. He has been a constant patron of the turf for the past 50 years. His name has been associated with horse races and annual exhibitions of stock for a half century, and there is not a more enthusiastic racegoer in Queens- land.

articleText:
SHOW TAKINGS INCREASE X

Those who attended last week's show, and the show of 1916, will be j , interested In a note from the ,> Beaudesert "Times" of 1916 which ij

states that the gate takings on that j i occasion were £69/3/-, against , J £69/14/6 the previous year. . The same issue of the "Times" Ji stated that the hospital funds were i j getting low because " the ' monthly 1 , expenditure exceeded the income. ji It was stated that the Six O'clock ji Closing Movement, which was pressing ij for an early closing of all liquor bars, had been launched in Queensland, ji The fat bullock at the show which ij dressed at 819 j) lb. was sold to Mr. Ben. ji Hopkins for £14/12/6. Mr. Fred. Fresh- ,( water's guess was 1& lb. out. ij The death of Mr. T. Yore (32), who j, was well known at Beaudesert and , Tamborine, and that of Private H. Ma- % loney, in the military hospital at Enog- J gera, was announced. There was a very big drop in the price of fat pigs, which was chiefly caused by bacon from New Zealand and other states being sold at very much under- recent market rates. The Woodhill Farmers Union held a meeting, but for the second time the secretary of the Queensland Farmers Union had failed to put in an appear ance after arranging to attend a meet ing. Ten enlistments left four to make the May quota. They were E. Groth (Rathdowney), H. V. Turnbull (Hill- view) , P. J. Smith (Beaudesert) , Gaven Edwards (Beaudesert), J. Buckley (Woodhill), J. H. Robinson (Rathdow ney), R. O. Cameron (Beaudesert). W. T. Exton (Beaudesert), G. J. Geary (Bromelton), D. Tullock (Veresdale).

articleText:
WEDDING 30 YEARS AGO

The Beaudesert "Times" of September 1, 1.916, included: A quiet but pretty wedding of great interest to the Upper Logan District was celebrated a<t the re-

sidence of Mi-. George Robinson jnr., Mount View, Katlidowney, on August 22. The contracting parties were Mr. William Dommett, only son of Mr. and Mrs. Dommett, Rasvhle, Musgrave Road, Red Hill, Brisbane, and Miss Sarah Robinson, only daughter of Ml-, and Mrs. George Robinson, snr., Rath- downey. The bridesmaids were Miss B. Meck- len, cousin of the bride, and Miss Dommett, sister of the bridegroom. Mr. James Robinson jnr., cousin of the bride, acted as best man, and Mr. H. Robinson, brother of the bride, was groomsman. The bride was attlredi in a beautiful ivory silk dress ornamented with true lovers knots and pearls. The brides maids dresses were made of silk eolium. The wreath and veil were kindly lent by Mrs. J. C. Stewart, sister of the groom. The bride carried a white prayer book, a present from the groom. The bouquets were made by Miss Langdon, a friend of the bride. The bride's travelling dress was of grey tweed with hat to harmonise. Both dresses were made by Miss M. Piatt, pl Beaudesert, an old schoolmate of the bride. Tne bridegroom s present to the br.de was a gold watch, chain, and pendant. The bride's present to the groom was a shaving ouri.t. The couple travelled by motor to Sandgate where their future home will be. Officers elected at the 1916 annual meetuig of the Logan and Albert Jockey Club were: Patron, Mr. deB. B. Persse; president. Mr. C. W. Bundock; vice president, Mr. M. S. Smitn; treas urer lvir. J. W. Ka.s.on; auditors, Messrs. C. S. Speirs and J. P. PlunKect; comm-ttee, Messrs. M. Enrigiit, deB. B. Persse, C. J. Coll.ns, H. B.uxner, J. T. Yore, O'Donohoe, J. Deerain, J. Mc- Dougall, J. shay, P. Lillis, T. O'Neill, J. Dowiing, J. Devereux, F. Strecton, G. D. Stansiield. The c.ub membersnip had increased from 71 to 120, but memoersmp lees of 30 guineas were outstanding. The Beaudegert Rifie Ciub opened the season by shoot.ng over the 200, 30j and oOO yards ranges. Tne attend ance was noc -arge ow.ng to tne en listment of some oi the crack shots. Several riflemen were m good lorm the most successful being Dr. W. A. Beet, with a score of 98 out of 105 off the rifle, which included a possible at 200 yards, and 34 at 500. J. A. Walker also snot wen, his score being 9i, with a poss.ble at 500 yards. At a meet.ng of the hospital com mittee Mr. H. Bruxner was e.ected vice president, Mr. A. Winship a member of the committee, and Mr. J. W. Rais- ton treasurer. Because trouble was often experi enced getting back cutlery, loaned for social functions, it was decided to call for a deposit of 10/- in the future, and missing cutlery was to be paid for. Private Stewart Franklin was slightly wounded in action. He was progressing favourably In hospital in France.

parks — Mt. Rawiter National Park. Se quoia National Park, Oregon National Park, Yellowstone National Park and others? As early as 1901 President McKinley's Government, by a Bill of Appropria tion, set aside £5 million dollars to purchase huge tracts of forest country for reserves and nationaL parks in the Southern Alleglienies to be known as the National Appalacian Park com prising 43 peaks of 6,000 ft. elevation and upwards. Since then America has spent millions of dollars to give people access to the health giving high alti- : tudes of their great national parks. Others may have opinions for : greater improvements to bring the \ Lamington National Park nearer to tourists. The National Fitness Organ- : isation of Beaudesert has something | in trying to bring the Lamington area : under review with the Christmas Creek watersheds, rich in flora, worth opening up. What better area for the : youth of today? Sheltered by fern-clad gullies, with : the rumbling music of the thundering | waters, nestling beneath the crowned : monarchs of the tree-clad forest, are j the remains of one of nature's gentle- 1 men, James Westray, who gave his life for his friends. Whnt more fitting sur roundings, and what better example of sacrifice? Where are the young Australians of : to-morrow? Pressure must be brought to bear. : Lamington National Park must be j accessible to all, young and old, hikers, motorists. 1

articleText:
CHEAP HOUSE 30 YEARS AGO

Present day houscseckcrs would have been' pleased to read an ad vertisement In the Beaudesert Times of May 26, 1946, reading as

follows: Very choice residence, Anna Street, Beaudesert, standing on one acre of ground, elevated, and beautiful location, the pick of Beaudesert. Nice garden, .and a number of splendid fruit trees. Good house in splendid order, all lately renovated. A number of tanks, good outhouses. With all modern conveniences. A gift at - £260. Good reasons for selling. It was stated that Mrs. James Waters E was going to sell 400 acres of her Bud- 3 dai Estate, Christmas Creek. 3 The Christmas Creek Jockey Club s was holding a patriotic race meeting, 5 in Mrs. D. Cahill's paddock for prize = money of £98. 3 Members of the War Council reported E that Private D. Salisbury, at present E hi the Beaudesert hospital was making good progress towards recovery. = A reminder was given that dips had E to be registered. E Messrs M. Selwyn Smith and Sons = announced that owing to the alteration s in the running of the tramways the E Hillview pig sale had been cancelled. E The programme of sales was mapped = out at the beginning of each year, and. E no date was available. Until a sale E could be held a truck would be sent to = -Hillview to convey pigs to Beaudesert = free of charge, and a representative E would be at Hillview to assist with the E loading and consigning. E At the home of Mr. and Mrs. Deerain, = Bromelton, friends of Miss Corcoran E made her a presentation in honour of E her approaching marriage. E It was understood that a petition = was being signed at Palen Creek, and E Rathdowncy, asking the Government E to take over the tramways, and other = areas had been asked to sign similar = petitions. E Included in "Random Pars" was the = following: Private P. J. Cameron, of s Jimboomba. who is at present on ser- E vice with the expeditionary forces, is 5 ill. : Between 60 and 70 pigs from N. S. W. ; were sold at the Rathdowney pig sales. : Town and shire quotas for May have E not been made up. Four more men are ; still wanted — so is conscription. : An inspector lins been stationed at : Tweed Heads to prevent the passing of : diseased banana plants from Queens- land to N.S.W. j A farewell had been arranged to : Rev. H. R. G. Hill at the Baptist Church prior to his going .to Brisbane. Rabbits are in great demand in Bath- urst N.S.W. at 1/- to 1/1 a pair, and trappers are making from £6 to £12 a week. .Still in the cities there are un employed hanging around street cor ners.

articleText:
1916 BRISBANE SHOW

After stating tliat "Nearly everybody who xs anybody went to the show and races," llic Beau desert "Times" of August 18, 1916,

makes reference to iiie Brisbane exhibition, the Wednesday of which attracted an attendance of 56,000, and a. gate of 11921 (the re cord was 1914 With 60,000). The "Times" went on to say: At this year's Brisbane exhibition many district exhibitors were success ful in carrying off prizes in different sections. In the home milking competitions Mr. D. Dunn, of Valley View, Nin- dooinbah, seemed file Honours in the Illawarra breeds with his splendid cow Blossom 3rd, while Mcxntyre Bros., of Christmas Creek, were tlnrd in milk ing Shorthorns, with Lark 2nd. The conditions in each cia- s were the same, namely cow or heifer averaging the greatest daily yield oi butter for 48 hours under Babcoek test, milk to con tain not less than 3 per cent, of but ter fat. The test to be conducted on the farms by officers of the Depart ment of Agriculture and Stock. Blos som 3rd produced 5.15 l);s. in 48 horns, and Lark 3.31 lbs. in ; like period. In the blood horse section Mr. M. F. Yore, of Logan Village, was success ful with his blood s.aliion Sunripe, and secured first and champion prizes. In the dairy cattle section Illawarra breed Mr. D. Dunn was again success ful with Blossom 3rd m the aged class, securing first and champion. His cow, Jemima 2nd, being second, was awar ded the reserve champion ribbon. In the aged bull class he obtained third prize, .with Marquis, ol Baileyview. In the pony hunting contest Mr. F. c. Nicholson's Silver secured first prize. Mr. C. J. Collins' Eisinora was sec ond in the maiden hacks. It was stated that during the run of the Q.M.E. mcativnrks Mr. W. G. YVhile had trucked to that company from Beaudesert district -1700 head of fat cattle. That about concluded tl(o season. Mr. deB. Persse's chestnut colt, Batchelor's Fersse ran second in the Metropolitan Handicap at Eagle Farm on Wednesday. Second Lieutenant it. f. Sheppard had been removed from the danger ous! v ill list

Private W. Wease was wounded in fighting at the front. Claude Rasmussen. m the post office staff, was transferred lo Oakey. Private A. Day was reported missing from the front. A Metropolitan pap. !- had the fol lowing in reference iu a well-known Beaudesert singer: Brisbane has a budding Clara Butt o; Us own, and in days to come this town will probably have every reason ;o feel proud of Miss Ivy Norman, the . uung contralto who made her first appearance at a recital at Beales conti.u .salon on Wed nesday. At present Mi>-; Norman has not attained her full power. Her lower notes are full, deep, and glorious, but her middle register is- .is yet not fully developed. In the rei-native and aria "Ombra Maifui" (Hamuli she sang with wonderful sympathy, and fur ther, the cello obLga o by Miss M. Stuart added greatly to the effects. The "Sapphic Ode" ' Brahms) which Miss Norman sang sub . equcntly proved that she has emerge;: tvom the chry salis stage, and, if she adds effort to the undoubted gift she possesses she

has mounted the firs: rung of mnnv of which are ahead of her on the ladder of success. Miss Lena Hammond, under whom Miss Norman rudies, was a sympathetic accompanist. It, is not often that one contralto (or indeed any public singer) is ready to help a possible rival into the limelight, but Miss Hammond is noted for her con sideration for young singers, and her delight in her pupil's .uccess was quite evident.

articleText:
FORMING FIRE BRIGADE |

The Beaudesert "Times" file of : July 28, 1910, states that at a-meet- : ing of the Fire Brigade oommittee : it was decided to take immediate

steps to form a fire brigade at ; Beaudesert. It was stated that a : brigade was a great necessity at jj Beaudesert, and it was hoped that ; all interested would attend'the next ' - meeting. s The same issue announced the pass- s ing of several well known and highly : respected residents. E Mrs. Sarah Murray died at Canun- - gra at the age of 84 year's. . E Mrs. Holdgate, relict of the late Rob- : ert Holdgate who passed away .nine = months previously, died at the age of < 76 years. She resided in Brisbane until - seven years previously, when she came , to Beaudesert to Join her son, who had I established a business. i Rathdowney correspondent - advised ! that plans were being made for a race ! meeting, and interesting gallops were j held at Mrs. Stretton's course. Amongst ; horses noticed were Blaze Away, Nagel, ; Sir Herod, Lady. Olive and Jack. j . At> the annual meeting of the Beau- j desert Rifle Club the following officers i were elected: President, Mr. .C.. W. C. ' Bundock; patron, Mr. deB. B. Persso;. I vice presidents, Messrs. C. A. Bestham. I and C. J. Collins; captain, Mr.. J. Al' ! Walker; treasurer Mr. J. Hawthorne; j secretary. Mr. A. Winship; committee, | Messrs, H. Smith, A.-' Orme, Harold | Lahey, J. Holdgate, Dr. W. A. Beet; auditor, Mr. J. P. Piuiikett; handicap- | per, Mr. H. Smith; delegate to the Logan and Albert District Rifle Club j Union. Messrs. H. Smith and Harold ; Lahey.' ' .

articleText:
| SHOW OF 1916 |

© People do not change their habits much throughout the years. 'Che Bcaudescrt "Times" of May 5, 1916, had the following to say about the

snow Deing neitl that monin: En tries received for the show arc quite satisfactory, and well up to the average of previous years. Farm produce, dairy cattle, . and beef cattle are particularly well sup ported, and although some of the ring events should have received better support, nevertheless, the most attractive classes have filled well, and the public will have the opportunity of seeing some of the greatest equine celebrities in the Commonwealth. A galaxy of talent will appear at the concert. Notwithstanding the dry season Mr. J. Willis Jenyns managed to raise from seed some of the finest dahlias of their kind we have seen. They are a speaking testimony of the fact that given water Eeaudesert could hold i:s own in the production of flowers with anywhere. The output of the L. and A. butter factory for April was 44 tons, and the cream pay at the rate of 1/2 per lb. first grade. In April, 1915, the output was .1 ton less, but the pay was nearly £1400 more at the rate of l/5i per lb. The real market value was about the same this year— but the paper added, "We have a different type of Govern ment in now." About 200 head of cattle were yarded, and practically all were sold. Prices realised were: Cows with calves £6/19/-; cows, good quality, £6/12/6; 18 months heifers, £3/15/-; poddy steers, £3/19/-; 24 year steers £6/13/-; springers med ium £5/17/-. Prize winners at' the Rathdowney sports were: 100 yards open handicap, W. Pett 1. J. Masen 2: 220 yards open handicap, J. Masen 1, W. Pett 2. Pony race under 14.2, Lady Olive 1, Malt Mary 2; consolation hack. Jack 1, Malt Mary 2; handicap trot, Don 1, Lou Harold 2. The waltzing competition at the dance at night was won by Mr. J. Healy and partner. It was started that advice received was to the effect that Mr. J. Pratt snr. was killed at Bunya Road, near Dalby. Deceased was engaged driving a team of horses' hauling timber from Bunya Park to Kaimkillenbun. Two other teams driven by George Ronosch and Harry Collins were' on the same road. Ronosch saw deceased stop his team, and attend to one of the horses, and then drop back. He said he had been kicked in the chest. He was sensible to the last, and died 15 minutes later. Two of the eight children, John and Edward, were at the front. It was announced that supplies of badges for rejected volunteers were, available. The name could be engraved on the back. Sgt. McCarthy (recruiting Sergeant) told a meeting of the War Council that there was an alarming falling off in recruiting, and sdmeihing should be done to place the position before the public. It was decided to hold an open air public meeting in front of the Shire Office on show night. The Christmas Creek Jockey Club ad vertised a patriotic race meeting with prize money of £98. The trial handicap carried prize money of eight sovereigns; Tamrookum Plate (handicap) five sovereigns and trophy valued at 25 sovereig-„r Christmas Creek ladies' bracelet value five sovereigns; Christ mas Creek Handicap. 20 sovereigns. A compulsory handicap for sovereigns was tachu: d. . 7;, was com- vr-'V-y f, ..cart, and op- tional for losers to ' o in the latter event.

articleText:
ONE PICKS RUSSIA

Last week the Beaudesert "Times" gave out what some of the sporting fraternity thought of the chances of the horses in the Mel bourne Cup.

Cordale was made a red hot fav ourite, a few mentioned On Tar get, but Jack Shay snr. was the only one to plum for Russia. On the Wednesday night, when he was called over the telephone, he said lie was reading how the money had gone in for Russia, and in the morning he repeated that what he had read 'was good enough for him. And he supported his selection with hard cash. Incidentally the "Times" selec ted: Cordale 1, Russia 2, On Tar get 3, and Cordale did not produce the form expected of him. The placings were Russia 1, On Target 2, Carey 3.

articleText:
I BUTTER PRODUCTION I I 30 YEARS AGO | CJ a

There was a big Tailing off in butter production in the dis trict hi January, 1916, according to the Beaudesert "Times" files of February 11, 1916.

The output from the Logan and Al bert lactory for January was 27i tons, being an increase over the previous month of 7 tons, and G3:I tons less than the output for the previous year. Sup pliers were paid 1/0:1 per lb. first grade, f'or tlie half year ended 31 December the output was 114 tons 240 lb. which is 154i. tons less than for the corres ponding period in 1914. Butler sales mounted to £17200, and might easily have been £2000 or £3000 more (on a low estimate) but lor the Government's interference with the trade. The cost of manufacturing and selling was 2.44 per lb. which includes depreciation against 1.46 in 1914. The half yearly balance shows a profit of £27/7/-. The secretary of the Kingston butter factory advised that during January 56 tons 17 cwl. 1 qr. of butter was manufactured, be.ng a decrease of 72 tons 7' cwt. 3 qrs.. as compared with the corresponding period of the previous year. .Suppliers were paid 1/1 per lb. commercial butter. Alter business hours at Emlglits Store employees n-sembled to make a presentation to Mr. M. Enrigbt jnr. prior to lit; going into camp at Enog- i;e:r, Mr. w. Wilson made the presen tation oi a smoker's outfit. A r idclii, war fiuieu on a charge of cruelti iowls. It was alleged that a box 2 ft. 6 ins. long, 1 it. 9 ins. wide, and 1 ft. 3 ins. deep consigned to Bris bane contained 20 head of full grown birds. This gave each 4i ins. of ground space. The fowls were literally stand ing on one another when they arrived at Brisbane. One was dead, and four others on their last gasp' when taken from the box.

Dealing with the Beaudesert Shire elections the "Times" said: At one time there was every indication that the annual elections in at least two divisions would be contested, thus giv ing the ratepayers an opportunity of expressing their wish through the bal lot box. But some of the probable candidates, alter counting heads, ap parently came to the conclusion that discretion was the buiter part of valour and did not press their candidature so that when nominations were declared on Tuesday by the returning officer (Cr. S. Mylett) it was found that only suffi cient had been received lo fill the va cancies. The following nominations were received: No. 1 Division, . John Waters, No. 2, William Drynan, No. 3. Joseph Hopkins. It was stated that the Tamborine Shire elections caused a little more than usual interest, and ratepayers even, worked themselves up to a pitch ol' great excitement. The bone of con tention was introduced by Mr. David Lahey, who resigned his seat its a member of No. 3 Division in order to contest No. 1 Division in opposition to the retiring councillor (Mr. W. Wnlsh)

This action on the part of "The Hope of Canungra" raised a tremendous amount of opposition and certain mem bers of the "free and independent" freely denounced the move. Ratepayers took a keen interest in the elections, and polling was heavy. Results in No. 1 Division wore: William Walsh 77, David Lahey G5. informal 6. The re sult was received wlLli much cheering and congratulations by Clr. Walsh's supporters. The fate ol No. 3 Division rested on some challenged votes. Messrs. J. H. Delprait and Amos Finch were the nominees. Edwin Franklin and A. J. Battles, nominated for No. 3 Di- vision vacancy. The death was announced of Mr. John Hopkins, one of the oldest Logan pioneers, at the age of 77 years. He spent 45 years .n lite district. A farewell was given lo Mr. R. Mar tin jnr. at Tamborine. it was stated that Mr. Martin was a very popular young man, and would bo greatly missed in the district. Clr. Walsh pre sented him with a gold wrist watch. Mr. Martin wont into camp on Janu ary 24. Including in Random Pars was: The Town Council is on the war path after unpaid rates. The erring ones arc re quired lo pay up or toe the carpet at the police court. We advise them to pay up and iook plea- ant. More trouble for the properly owners in the im proved area. The Town Council now re quires that all overflow water lie di rected under Pa looinatli. and into the gutter. Advice was received that Private A. Graham, of Tabragalba. had been in valided home. Bowlers wove on top in the match between Beaudesert and Tabragalba. the final of the Beaudesert division of the competition. The home team won by an innings and 23 runs. G. Mark-

ham took 7 for 37 and A. Hart 5 lor 21.
