articleText:
SHIRE PREMISES

The December meeting of the Tamborine Shire Council, as re ported in the Beaudesert "Times" of December 15, 1916, accepted tenders for the erection of new shire chambers and residence, the

Srice being £283 and £344 respec- vely. The successful tenderer was Mr. A. M. Irwin. The allow ance of the chairman (Clr. Thomas Strachan) was again fixed at £15 for the year. The same issue included: Word was received that Gunner Russel C. C. Phipps, eldest son of Lady Henry Phipps, of Gleneagle, had died in London hospital from a severe at tack of influenza. The December rifle shoot was won i by P. Cecil 99 points (58 off the rifle) ; 1 A. Winship was second with 97 (72. off ! the rifle), and J. A. Yore third 93 '(87 j off the rifle). i At the Methodist church fair stall i holders were: Sewing, Mesdames Mar- i tin and Robinson; refreshments, Mrs. I Willie; soft drinks, Messrs. Addison | and Kingston; Christmas tree, Mrs. A. i S. Logan; produce, Mr. A. S. Logan; i sweets, Mrs. Addison; flowers, Messrs. i R. Cecil and Kingston.

articleText:
CYCLE AND CAR HIT

Neal Rasmussen (17), apprentice printer, employed at the Beaudes ert "Times" suffered a fractured left wrist on Sunday afternoon as

a result of a motoring accident at Archeriicld. , The injured lad. and M. Henley, had been to Brisbane '.o visit the latter's father, Mr. P. Henley, who was in hos pital, and a cousin who was recovering from injuries suffered in an accident at Tweed Heads. . When proceeding along the Beaudes- ert-Brisbane road on motor cycles, the front wheel of the machine ridden by Rasmussen struck the front portion of a car proceeding along, the Sunny- bank Road. Rasmussen was thrown into the ah-, coming down on to the roadway on his hands and knees, and the car ran over portion of the cycle wrecking .it. The motorist took the injured lad to the Brisbane General Hospital for attention. He was able to return to Beaudesert on Tuesday.

TYPOGRAPHICAL ERROR

As a result of a typographical error It was stated in the last issue of the. Beaudesert "Times", that £30,000 had been decided on by the Beaudesert

snire council to meet pre lmmary in vestigations on costs of a water scheme for Beaudesert. This should have read £3,000, and not £30,000.'

articleText:
TOWN COUNCIL RATES 30 YEARS AGO

Speaking at the June, 1916 meet ing of the Beaudesert Town Coun cil, as reported in the Beaudcsert "Times" of June D, 1946, the Mayor

(Mr. deB B. Perssc) said that the council was £1000 behind, but it was no time to increase the rates, espec ially as they had so many income taxes etc to pay. He thought they should strike a similar rate as that of the previous year. To wipe out the. overdraft perhaps at the end of the year the North and South Wards might help the Central Ward,, but no doubt the North Ward was in a better position than the South, as there were more roads in the South Ward to keep up. Aid. M. S. Smith said that the £700 overdraft on account of the street im provements required to be wiped out. . The special loan rate of 2d. was not sufficient to pay interest and redempt ion, and it required a heavier rate. It was decided to strike a 3d. general, and 2id. special rate. The South Ward rate was fixed at 3d,, and that for North Ward was deferred for a month. The new Waterford bridge, built of reinforced concrete, was opened by Mr. ,Tas. Stodart M.L.A. Other items included: The output of the Kingston butter factory during May was 81 tons 13 cwt. 2qrs. of butter an increase of 25 tons 13 cwt. 2qrs., as compared with May the previous year. Suppliers were paid 1/5 lb. commercial butter. Although recruiting in the district was far from brisk, volunteers contin ued to come forward slowly, and the town and shire quotas for May were completed. The latest enlistments were: Wm. Dunn (Christmas Creek), T. G. E. Parker (Bcaudesert) , Neil Fredcr- ickson (Tabooba), II. Massam (Beau descrt), V. A. HincliliiTe (Veresdale). The Beaudesert and District Patri otic Fund was shown as having reached £3661/3/3. It was stated that the two day Logan Village Rifle Club, shoot had been con tested by 19 members. First honours were won by C. Ferguson, with a score of 97 including 35 of a handicap. Next came A. J. L. Pope, and then J. F. Potts. A. G. Hinds and A. Ross in that ordqr. Work in connection with the con struction of the stop butt on the Beau- desert rifle range was progressing satis factorily. The club would be able to start practice in July. Over 500 head were penned at the monthly cattle sale, the prices realised being: poddy steers and heifers 25/- to 40/-; yearling heifers to 60/-; yearling steers 63/- to 70/-: steers, 2 years 85/- to 100/-: heifers, 2 .ve irs 57/- to 70/-; store cows 90/- to 105 -; beefy cows 130/- to 141/-; spring cows 130/- to 175/- bulls 130/- to 200/-. Neil Frederickson, who had been ac cepted for service with the A.I.F;, was given a function at Tabooba school. A public meeting formed a branch of the Early Closing League. Officials appointed were: Rev. C. M. P. Heath (president), Rev. A. C. Flint (treasurer), Messrs Hawthorne, Pert, Le Grand, Bradshaw, Johnstone, Rev. W. Kidd and Adj. Thomas i. executive) , J. W. Jenyns (secretary) .

articleText:
MINERAL SURVEY

Of interest was announcement regarding mineral deposits in the district, published in me Beaudes ert Times of August 1, 1916,

The report stated: Mi-, j. H. Reid assistant Government Geologist, is in the district making ar. angernenis lor a geolog.cal survey cxain.nauon of the country south ol Beauuesert along the proposed railway routes to Kyogle, via Lamington and Ml. Lindetay. Coal seams are known to occurm parts of the district, and a:.so iripolite, some times cahed diamaeeaus earth, which is used largely as an aDsoroent, for nitro-glycerine, in the manutacture of ammunition, and as an insu.aiing ma terial. Efforts are being made to place the Queensland material on the mar ket, and Mr. Reld will investigate any deposits known in the clstr.c., as we,l as any coal or other mineral deposit. Triponte is a white material not un like chalk, but mucn .igiuer because it will float on water. It was announced that the Upper Logan Jockey Cluo womd hold a seven race programme the ioi.ow.ng day. At the Red Cross gather.ng ac the show grounds, Mr. H. A. Lmiey wen tilting the ring while in a motor, car, capturing three ring.s Other competi tors were: Mrs. Fraser (Mundoolun), Mr. deB. B. Persse, Tamrooktun car, Dr. Beet and Mr. Siy. Gate takings were £22. Announcements Included: Private T. Rabnott, youngest sen of Mrs. E. E Rabnott, of Beaudesert, has been killed In action in France. Sgt. Donald W. Walker has arrived safely at Salisbury Plains. Others from the same battalion to arrive were Pri vates R. A. Ferguson, of Jelbyn, and J. Stanfleld. Second Lieutenant R. Sheppard is dangerously wounded in action but is progressing favourably. In July Kingston butter factory manufactured 57 tons 19 cwt,, which was an increase of 15 tons 17 cwt. over the same month the previous year. Suppliers were paid 1 3 per pound commercial butter. The report added: "The loss to suppliers during the month owing to state interference was £1603, approximately 3d. lb. commercial but ter." Retiring officials re-elected at the annual meeting of the Logan Villaga Rifle Club were: Captain, Mr. T. S. Kilby; secretary, Mr. J. w. Edmunds; treasurer, Mr. A. G. Hinds. The mem bership was 34, and nine members had joined the A.I.F.

articleText:
BEAUDESERT PIG SALE

M. Selwyn Smith & Son held their usual weekly pig sale in Beaudesert on Monday last, when 520 pigs were penned. One New South Wales firm was represented, and two local firms. Competition for all lines, was good, and the market showed a firmer tendency, prime bacon pigs making 9 id. per lb„ with heavy pigs at slightly lower rates. The yarding of store pigs was smaller than has been the case for some little time, and prices generally, were a shade firmer. The following were the ruling rates; Heavy bacon £4/19 - to £7/11/-: light to medium bacon £4/0/6 to £4/16/6; porkers £3/16/- to £3/18,6; forward store £3/6/- to £3/13/6; medium store £1/19/6 to £3/2/6; slips £1/10/- to £1/17/-; suckers and weaners £1/2/6 to £1/5/6. articleText:
BEAUDESERT v. POLICE

Although lain spoiled the Beau desert A grade second team-Police Welfare Club match at Selwyn Park as far as a spectacle and en terprising cricket was concerned, ncver-the-iess it was a good game. Police batted first and made 144 for the loss of seven wickets. Duncan bat ted splendidly for 60, and Quinn handled the slow bowlers to get 25. Beaudesert tried out eight bowlers, the only respectable average being A. Draheim's 4 for 27. Three of these were taken by Sullivan behind the stumps. The keeper had a bad day of it, re ceiving a hit in the eye, as well as one on the elbow and finger. Strong took a good catch. It was an example of what can be done once a player goes after a difficult one, and decides to carry on against what ap pears to be the impossible. He skidded along in a dive, to hold the leather. Having no spin bowlers the visitors rel.ed on theiV fast bowlers, but they did not have much success. The ball was sodden by this time, and the trundlers were not used to the concrete wicket. G. Strong and M. Tilley top scored, and three were down for 134 when time was called. It is hoped that a return match will be played at Victoria Park on March 10. Bob Fuller and Jim Gill spent the day umpiring which was appreciated. POLICE CLUB, First Innings

articleText:
BEAUDESERT CATTLE SALE

M. Selwyn Smith & Son held their usual fortnightly cattle sale In Beaudesert on Wednesday last, when 300 store cattle were yarded, consisting of about 50 steers, 100 Hereford heifers, 50 dairy heifers, some store cows, with the balance being beefy cows and tinners. There was good competition through out, everything fprward with the ex ception of one pen of steers being dis posed of. One of the Brisbane meat- works was represented, and purchased, in all, 92 tinner and beefy cows. The following were the ruling prices: Steers, Hereford crosses, 3 years, £6/19/- to £7/7/-; steers, good quality Herefords, 2 years, £6/8/- to £6/18/-; steers, good quality dairy breeds, 3 years, £6/14/-; store cows, £4/10/- to £6/2/-; beefy and tinner cows £2/13/6 to £7 '3/6; cows and calves £1/16/- to £5/1/-; old cows and cows in low con dition, 10/- to £1/16/-; dairy heifers, A.I.S., 2 years old, £4/14/- to £5/3/-; dairy heifers, grade Jerseys, 18 months to 24 years old, £3/10/- to £5/14'-; dairy heifers, Grade Jerseys, 9 to 12 months, £1/10/-. At the dairy cattle sale, 56 head were yarded. The attendance of buyers was smaller than it has been for some time, there being practically no outside re presentation, tills being mainly due to the fact that outside buyers were afraid to operate owing to the uncertainty of railway transport. Prices in consequence, were lower than they have been for some consider able time, and quite a number of cattle were not sold, as prices offered did not meet with owners' approval. The top price of the dav was £9/10/- secured for a nice quality A.I.S. cow with calf at foot sold an accoun' of Mr. James Moloney. Others sold at from £4/15/- to £9/5/- according to quality.
heading: BEAUDESERT CATTLE SALE

articleText:
beaudesert pig sale

M. Selwyn Smith and Son held their regular weekly pig sale at Beaudesert on Monday last, when 600 pigs were yarded. New South Wales firms were again in the market for prime ba con pigs, as well as representatives from local bacon factories. Competition for all classes of bacon- ers was well maintained ,at recent rates, prime lines making 9d. to 9id. per lb., heavy descriptions at slightly lower rates. A big yarding of store pigs for which there was a good demand from outside, buyers at the best of recent rates. Backfatters were again purchased over scales, as has been the case recently. The following were the ruling prices, viz.: Heavy bacon £4/19/- to £6/14/-; light' to medium bacon £3/18/6 to £4/16/6; porkers £3/4/- to £3/15/i- ; for ward store £2/14/6 to £3/2/6; medium store £1/18/6 to £2/12/6; slips £1/6/6 to £1/16/-; suckers and weaners £1/1/- to £1/5/6; backfatters £4/7/6 to £7,V13/-. articleText:
THE SHIRE ELECTIONS

THE "Times" today provides electors of the Beaudesert Shire with food for thought. The views of candidates for the chairmanship of the Beaudesert Shire, and for No. 5 Division, have been published to give voters some

assistance. Naturally all are thinking of the chairmanship of the council. They have two men to think of, David Knowles, a member of No. 5 Division at the present time, and Ernest Henley, who Is seeking tip enter local politics for the first time. " Both men are no longer young, and so can be claimed to have passed that stage of "life where they were likely to act, without thinking. The views of both men are set out, and naturally each seeks election. Electors have to consider firstly the man, secondly what .he has done in the past as an individual, citizen, and as a public man, and , cast his or her vote according to the summing up that must follow. No matter which man secures 'the majority, the people have to remember that he is to be the leading light of the council for the next three years,— a most important stage of the history of the district. The right man can lead his council to success, and the depressing type can result in Beaudesert being left behind in all matters such as secondary industries, road works, water reticulation, and other angles that mean the difference between a progressive district or otherwise.

articleText:
THE COUNCIL POSITION

Costs of Victory Day in the Beaudesert Shire were referred to at the monthly meeting of the Beaudesert Shire Council held on

Tuesday. The Finance Committee report read: "The small committee which resulted from the public meeting called carried out the arrangements for Victory day to the best of its ability. Assistance was given financially by the business people, and others also subscribed".

which allowed sufficient funds to be available to pay the cost of prizes, ice creams, buns, etc.; soft drinks were re tailed at cost price. "Accounts have not yet been final ised but it is anticipated that all ex- ?enses will be met by public subscrip- ion. "The Council may be asked to pay Mr. Sidey for the cartage of water to the showgrounds. Transport charges would be a legitimate cost for claiming subsidy from the government, but any charges for foodstuffs, which were sup posed to be covered by the 1/- per head subsidy, would not be allowed. Mr. D. A. Salter, Hillview, wrote that three schools had pooled the Govern ment subsidy of 1/- a child as follows: Hillview £2/16/-, Chinghee Creek £1/2/- and Darlington £1. He added: As I have been informed the council intends to give a like amount I would be obliged if the Council will forward £4/18/- to add to the general expenses. CU'. P. V. Campbell said that he told a meeting of the committee that the council was going to subsidise them, and his fellow ooilncillor supported him. Other councillors, and the shire clerk, disagreed with this statement. Clr. A. Stephens said that he had been to'd of this by Mr. Salter, but while he did not think it right, he did not disagree as he thought he might be wrong. Mr. Lane said that they agreed to subsidise transport only. Clr. Davis said that Rathdowney was going to make a claim against the council for about £6 for its celebration if Beaudesert made any claim. Mr. Lane said he thought subscrip tions at Beaudesert would cover the co-ts. No further action was taken. It was decided to inspect the road through Markwell's property to Stock yard Creek. Clr. A. Stephens said the Council was faced with a headache in the future. The Chairman (Clr. E. E. Henley) said he would take part in the inspec tion with No. 1 members and the en gineer. The following letter was written to

the Tamborine Shire Council: "It has been suggested that the site of Cainbabel bridge be altered owing to the result of the floods in the early part of the year. It is proposed to in vestigate the site further, and I will advise you of the result. The construc tion of this bridge will be commenced In the 1946-7 financial year. It is anti cipated that the cost is likely' to be In creased, owing to the advance in the cost of mater.als and labour since the estimate was prepared. "A loan has been applied for Cu- sack's bridge and p'ans and specifi cations are being prepared. The esti mated cost is £600 at present rates. ''Advice will be forwarded to you of the estimated costs of each bridge In time-tor your new budget."

The Shire Clerk was instructed to inquire into the best means of arrang ing the necessary finance for both bridges. Stephen Mylett, Josephville, asked for the closure of the road in portion 83, running from the Logan River to the "tramway." He also advised that a quantity of stone had been taken from his property. Four gangs had removed the stone. The Shire Clerk said he tried to trace the amount of stone used. Some had been taken a long way back— some 25 yeai's ago. He could work out the amount used in recent times. It was decided that No. 2 members and the engineer go into the matter of the road closure, and the letter lay on tlie table for a month. Clr. A. Stephens said it was easier to close a road than open it. E. H. O'Neill, Kllmoylar. Woodhill, advised that the road from Undullali to his Woolooman hut was in an im passable condition. Clr. C. F. Henderson said nothing could be done during this month and he would move they give consideration tq the work in the next financial year. This was seconded by Clr. P. W. Everdell and carried. To a question by Clr, Aldrldge, the engineer said that all work done by private people was inspected before payment was made by the council. Clr. Aldridge said he saw where a job had been done by a resident for £20 and be did not think it was worth two "bob."

Clr. Henderson saia usuany me coun cil allowed a resident a certain amount ' to keep a road in repair for- the year. j It was remarked that neighbours kept the man up to doing the job. W. Webuer, "Avondale," Gleneagle, draw attention to the bad state of his roads. He said the one to Todd's corner I was almost impassable for motor traffic. Clr. Everdell said something should be done on Brabazon's road in the next financial year. This was agreed to. i J. M. & N, Swain, Tylervllle, via Rathdowney, asked for work on the o.d Mt. Lindesay Road, where their mother was the owner of property. They added: "The road is in a very had state, and, we being returned service men of five years service, should receive first pre ference instead of men living four and five miles distance. I would appreciate

getting the work close to my home. We are only milking 15 cows at present and the returns are insufficient for our keejJingavk sald work on the road had been done. Clr. Davis and the engineer are to go- into tlie matter of work near the turn- off, the former saying that residents desired to discuss the matter with the council. C. B. Klan and other, Innisplains, asked for the removal of two gates on the bottom end of Tamrookum Creek. They also asked for work to the road. The matter was left to the members of No. 2 Division. The Co-ordinator General of Pub lic Works advised that the proposal - to erect shire chambers at an esti mated cost of £6500 was a project that was not eligible for subsidy within the provisions of the approved subsidy scheme. The clerk said they did not expect the subsidy. Blunck's Garage asked permission to allow the A.CF. hut to remain on Its William Street property until not later than June' 30 next year, by which time they should have adequate buildings to fill their needs. (Continued on pose sovon)

| The Council Position | a - a

(Continued from page one) The letter said that the. situation, regarding buildings was little, if any thing improved since the last applica tion. it was decided to extend the period a further six months. Clr. Aldrldge drew attention to the long grass on the land and adjacent blocks, which constituted a Are danger. Clr. Henley undertook to have the matter attended to. N. & J. C. Dennis, Josephville, asked permission to cross the road with a telephone line. Norman H. Love. Hillview, made a similar application. No objection was offered, subject to the regulations being observed. Inspections are to be made to roads leading to A. R. Ludwlg's and H. P. Kbeling's properties. Clr. Stephens suggested each division have an inspection, with the engineer, of the division. H. G. Johnson alj complained about the road to his property. This was included in the No. 5 Di vision inspection to be made. The Treasury wrote that the proposal of the council to carry out a drainage scheme of Spring Creek at an estimated cost of £6000 was receiving considera- tion, in collaboration with the Depart ment of Health and Home Affairs, in conjunction with other local authority mosquito eradication projects submit ted for inclusion in the 1946-7 works programme. The Treasury had ap proved of a £500 loan being carried forward to the next loan programme, pending a decision as to the additional provision to implement the larger scheme proposed. The Under Secretary to the Treasury advised that the Treasurer had ap proved of the acceptance by the coun cil of the offer of the Trustees of the Commercial Bank of Australia Guar antee and Provident Funds of a deben ture loan of £5143, with interest of £3/10/- per centum per annum for 10 years. The Engineer reported on the loan of £5143 as follows: "The completion of the plans and estimates shows that to carry out the works outlined at current costs and prices of timber, pipes etc. the esti mated costs will amount to £6930. This would mean an extra loan and subsidy of £720 or loan £594 and sub sidy £126. This would not delay the work. "The scheme for the 6 ft. diameter eulvert in Anna Street has been in creased by the proposal to raise the road and provide a gravel surface, seal coated with bitumen, commencing from William Street for a length of 280 ft. and 16 ft. wide. The additional cost is £372. "Divisional increases are: No. 2 £33 (loan) £27, (subsidy) £6; No. 3. £72, 'loan) £60 (subsidy) £12; No. 4, £243, (loan) £200. (subsidy) £43; No. 5, £372, (loan) £307. (subsidy) £65; totals £720, (loan) £594 (subsidy) £126." Advice was received that S. F. Wal ker and W. J. Wolff, the only nomina tions received, had been elected to the Brisbane and East Moreton Pest De struction Board. Nerang Shire Council advised it could not support Clr. R. F. Davis's nomina tion for the South Coast Hospitals Board as it had supported Aid. Firth, of Southport. It was stated that Southport was advocating a hospital, and that shires in the vicinity were supporting the move. The Beaudesert A.L.P. asked for an extension of the sanitary service "over the railway line" at Beaudesert. Mr. Lane said that the extension in cluded the black settlement. It was no good giving them the service with the sort of conveniences they had there. They were supposed to comply with the regulations. Clr. J. Aldridge: They should be in it. If they caused an epidemic we will be in it. It was decided to ask the health in spector to report on the matter. The action in asking the Main Roads Commission to call tenders for the con struction of a section of the Rath- downey-Maroon Road was endorsed. It was decided to charge the Beau desert Sub-branch of the R.S.S.A.I.L.A. lighting and incidentals charges only, for conducting a dance on Victory night.

A day's work on the road at Stock yard Creek to Mrs. J. Markwell's pro perty, was approved. The Deep Chinghee Creek-Hillier's section is the next job .set down under the loan. The "tramway" section at Tabooba is also to be attended to. Work was requested for late in the month on the Josephville road, towards Mrs. Brook's residence. Clr. Davis is to go into the matter of work on Mr. R. Richard's road. The engineer is to go into the matter of a crossing at Spring Creek to assist

cattle owners. An inspection is to be made on the culvert on Kerry Road near Mr. George Martin's. The report from the Finance Com mittee recommends the following ac counts to be passed for payment; Shire fund £2103/1/2; Electric Authority £591/1/3; Trust account £228/9/6: L. & A. Health account. £52 8 11. The following amounts are required to.be passed for emergency purposes: — Works No. 2, £125: Works No. 3. £142 and £125; Works No. 4. £70: Works No. 5, £50; general works £300; stores, tools, £20; freights £5: blarksmithing £50; telephone £30; refund rates (2) 7/5; loan works £1000; M.R. maintenance (1) £4/1/7: MR. maintenance £1000; plant maintenance £125; election ex penses £30; suspense account £581 '7 '5; wages advance £50: pay roll tax £250; sanitary contract £50. Electric Authority: Power plant £7/15/-; fuel and oils £100; wages £125; utility £75: E.R. & I. account £50;. freights £30; engineer's supervision £17/10/-; interest and redemption £15: deposits £6/5/-.

articleText:
THE NATIONAL PARK 2'

Mr. C. J. Payne, Canungra, s writes: "An unwarranted attack by 3 Mr. Arthur Groom, of Binna- £ Burra, in Beaudesert "Times" of S

rioay, August a on my article, — "Lamington National Park Tracks" s is completely uncalled for. 3 "I am the one who is amused, not £ Mr. Groom. He should know his sub- 3 ject, but apparently, he should brush £ up on his correct history. The history s of Blnna-Burra and O'Reilly's Is well 3 known to all.- Both are private con- a cerns. His mistakes are many. 3 "Firstly Bell-Bird Track I is in the £ National Park, I being the Sub-Fore- s man in charge of the construction a =

few years ago. This track runs from z Illlnbah along the Beechmont Range : in a southerly direction towards Binna- £ Burra. : "This area is the biggest sanctuary ' £ of bell birds in Southern Queensland, s hence the name. In my article a few = years ago, I specially referred to this - track. Mr. Groom raised no objection S at the time, so why now? £ "I am not concerned with tracks on n private property, solely the National Park, and Mr. Groom's "Bell-Bird" he refers to, is Bell-Bird Lookout looking toward Numinbah Valley and angle- ways to hidden Palm Gorge. Oh, yes, Mr. Payne has been there 1 "What did.it cost the Forestry De partment to bring these Binna-Burra voluntary tracks on crown land up to the Forestry standard? "All existing tracks were brought up to standard by the Forestry. "My map assures me and I believe it to be correct, that Mt. Roberts is still the correct name for Binna-Burra, "My comparison as to tracks built in the National Park, had no personal views in favour of monopoly interest on either side. My modern views are "nationalisation." No monopoly exists, and nature in any form should not be commercialised. The Park is there, for all to enjoy, and ac cess should be for everyone, rich and poor, not to "many guineas per week," which is catering for a section at a profit.

' One section should not enjoy th-> privilege of a cha.n of -guest houses through crown lands for a profit. I teiieve the pol.cy of the park connec tions were for camping spaces, for motorists and caravans, at vantage places right throughout the Lamington National Park. "Regarding Curtis Falls. Owing to my style of writing (I am not allowed to purchase a typewriter yet) the printers mistook Coomera for Curtis. Hence the error. "However, Mr. Editor, being em ployed by the Forestry Service as Sub- Foreman, for a number of years in charge of construction gangs at Lam ington National Park, I have a fairly good knowledge of these tracks, and my small contribution to your paper was an effort on my part to supply the National Fitness Organisation at Beaudesert with a summary of infor mation regarding the tracks. "So, Mr. Editor, I hope Mr. Groom will be not so amused now. I surely touched a sore spot, which has been a burning question for years. I do not intend to be a party to a marathon of exchanges between private concerns and I. "The National Park is still the heri tage of all Australians and one day, perhaps, young and old will enjoy these cool mountain breezes and panoramic vistas, and no better memorial could be erected than to give access to this nature's wonderland to all."

articleText:
Belle of the Ball

The Technical Hall will be specially decorated for the Beaudesert Ambu lance annual ball to be held next Fri day night. Dancers will be catered for

by an orchestra arranged by Mrs. Stuart, and the first euchre prize will be a ham, with a large box of choco lates for second. A special prize will be given the belle of the ball, who will be chosen by a visiting official from Brisbane. The Ambulance functions this season have been particularly successful, outstanding being the barn dance at Enrights new factory, and it is expected that the bail will be no ex ception. The Beaudesert "Times" will provide cards for the ladies to ensure the publication of the tracking. The euchre tournament will be started at 8 p.m. sharp, and ten games will be played.

articleText:
THE DIGGERS HALL

Several speakers at the monthly meeting of the Beaudesert sub- branch of the R.S.S.A.i.L.A. on Friday night expressed concern at

the fact that better progress was not being made with the move to build a soldiers hall at Beaudesert. The Patron (Mr. R. E. Stephens) questioned metnbers as to what had been done in recent months regarding the proposal. ' , After members had aired their view it was decided to make a drive to raise additional money, and suggestions made include the running of a Diggers' Ball in August, and the circulation of let ters of appeal. The President (Mr. A. Stephens) had reported earlier that the Building Fund was going along well. He said they should thnnk the Church of England Ladies' Guild for holding a dance for the fund. It was not the first- time that body raised money for the sub-branch. A donation of £5 from Mrs. E. S. Graham was acknowledged. The President said that it had been suggested that local committees raise funds. Except for the Race Club's ef forts the fund was going slowly. The secretary (Mr. A. P. Watson) said that it had been suggested that they hold, a Diggers -Ball. The idea might be worthy of consideration. They could make it a debutante ball.' The President said - that he had booked the hall for the Friday before the Brisbane exhibition. Mr. R. Jurd said balls held in the past did not pay, as only a few people attended. Several speakers said that with so many young men in the league they should be able to make a success of a ball now. Mr. A. L. Lane undertook to organise a ball in August. He.sid that he would secure his own committee, but would be calling on members to lrnd assistance in many directions. It was also decided to circularise re sidents of the district seeking donations and to inquire into the possibilities of securing assistance from funds raised for patriotic purposes during the war period. All donations to the fund are to be acknowledged through the columns of the Beaudesert. "Times."

articleText:
THE CRICKET SEASON

The Beaudesert District Cricket Association A and B grade fixtures will commence on Sunday, Sep tember 29, with tbe draw an-

nounced in next Friday's issue of the Beaudesert '-Times." This decision was arrived at at the meeting of delegates lield on Wednesday night. Rathdowney Club announced thiyt it, could not tield an A grade team be cause of the shortage of players, but would enter two B grade teams. Mr. IS. Wisnart (Pres.dent) advised that the affi.iation fee had been fixed . at £1/1/-, and 1'- a registered mem ber, as against £1/10/- and 1/6 In pre war seasons.- He drew attention to the lact that this year the association had to maintain a turf w.cket. which was not the case last year. Feeling was that this had been over looked at the annual meeting, and that if the position was such tnat the association could not meet its finan cial obligations a levy would have to be struck later In the season. Tne desires of B grade clubs are to be ascertained to see if they want oc casional matches on the turf wicket, if these can be arranged. The Beaudesert shire Council wrote- that it considered that the wicket on the -'Flat" should be controlled by the associat.on. and asked if the associa tion was prepared to accept control at a rental. Mr. Smith said that Mr. P. Everdell advised the Gleneagle wicket was available, and it was essential the as sociation take charge of the "Flat" wicket. The fixtures had to be drawn up accordingly. He had been informed Cryna wicket had several large cracks in it. The Council is to be contacted re garding rental of the wicket. Messrs. Jock ancl Leu Wright ad vised tbe meeting that they desired to present a shield to the associa tion for the A grade competition, This was to be contested in perpet uity, and lliey would give a cup to the premiers each season. The shield would be known as the "James Wright Memorial Shield." Mr. Smith said that Mr. Wright had been interested in all sports, particu larly cricket,, and the association ap preciated the gesture. The members of the premiership team would also re ceive caps. It was decided to place on record a vote of thanks to the Messrs. Wright brothers for their gift. Mr. E. Duff moved against the ad mission of the Maroon B grade team as itr. would make the distance to be travelled too great. Maroon also had an A grade team hi the Boonah As sociation, and the Beaudesert players did not know the capabilities of the Maroon players. Mr. G. A. Teese said that Innisplains hoped to field a B grade team, and suggested that it might be possible to zone the B graders. Mr. Duff said that zoning would re strict cricket for the young players who should meet as many different teams as possible. It was stated that Maroon had not sent a delegate to the meeting, and it was telt they were not proceedmg with their intention; also tnat it was not thought Rathdowney would enter the competition if zoning came about. It was decided to advise Maroon that, in view of the distances to be travelled, the club could not be ad mitted, and no action was taken on tne zoning proposal. Mr. Teese said Innisplains might find it difficult to field a team in mid summer because they came ' from a smail district. The players would' do the best they could to keep going. It was decided to accept the offer of the Beaudesert "Times" to pro vide score cards for record purposes, the winning team to be responsible for having a completed card lodged at the "Times" oftice by noon on the Tuesday following a match. Messrs. W. A. Watt, V. Day and J. Gill were re-elected A grade selectors. Messrs. W. Strong and A. Draheim were also nominated. In reviewing what had taken place regarding the selection of teams last year it was stated that at least on one occasion one selector announced "a team himself, and that on other oc casions two selectors picked the side over the lelephone. Some of the matches for the second teams had been arranged at such short notice there had not been time for selectors to be ' contacted. Mr. W. Strong considered that in some cases age had been given prefer ence over youth, which was a mistake. Mr. Gill said If he were selected he would see that confusion over selec tions did not happen again. Mr. M. Barrett said that there had not been a B grade interassociatioiv match last season. B graders should be given preference to second A grade teams. Messrs. E.-Duff. S. Hiscock, R. Willis, V. McGovern and J. C. Barrett were nominated as B grade selectors, with

tne last tnree eiectea. Delegates said they hoped that cattle would be kept off the Selwyn Park oval this season. . Mr. C. R. Kerlin is to be thanked for providing water for the turi wicket. The President, secretary, treasurer, and Messrs. E. Duff and J. Gill were elected a Fixture Subcommittee. A move to commence the fixtures on September 22 was defeated by a nar row margin. A meeting of ten members of the Colts Club on Monday night decided . to change the club name to the "Beau desert Cricket Club." Messrs. S. Cal- lanan, J. GUI and W. McGuire were elected selectors, and Mr. W. McGuire has replaced Mr. Callanan as a dele gate to the association. Subscription fees were fixed at 15/-. Wanderers Cricket Club team to play Kerry A at Beaudesert on Sunday is: G. Strong (capt.), B. Stuart, E. Hodge. N. Holding, D. Yuke, W. Sandy, J. Sandy, W. Haylock, J. Veivers, Ces. Willis, Ray Ferguson, W. Howard (12th man). Wanderers B grade to play Kerry is; Bob Willis, Jack Willis, L. Crust, C. Yuke, H. Miller, R. Jurd, W. Winkley, T. Fredricksen, B. Allen, W. Radford, A. Stegeman, C. Harman. FRIENDLY MATCH A friendly match played betwee#. Rathdowney Cricket Club and Joseph- ville Cricket Club at Rathdowney on Sunday resulted: JOSEPHVILLE: Max. Tilley, retired 51; J. Teese, b. J.. Flanagan 25; Chas. Arthy, c. V. McGovern, b. A. Ward 47; E. Arthy, b. A. Ward 29; Merv. Tilley, b. L. Sim 20; A. Arthy, retired 33; Cliff Arthy, retired 66; H. Dennis, b. N. Beitz 25; N. Barlow, b. A. Ward 18; T. Dredge, not out 8; A. Platell, b. A. Ward 0; sundries 10; total 332." Bowling: R. Virtue 0 for 34, N. Beitz 1 for 48, A. Koplick 0 for 43, J. Sim 0 for 40, L. Bright 0 for 20. R. Jenkins 0 for 48, A. Ward 4 for 15, L. Sim 1 for 34, J. Flanagan 1 for 40. RATHDOWNEY: A. Koplick, c. T. Dredge, b. J. Teese 19; L. Sim, c. A, Arthy, b. T. Dredge 4;- W. Koplick, b. H. Dennis 17; J. Flanagan, c. and b. Cliff Arthy 9; N. Beitz, run out 25; J. Sim, stp. N. Barlow, b. J. Teese 1; R. Virtue, 0. A. Arthy 10; A. Ward, c. Max Tilley, b. A. Arthy 1; V. articleText:
THE PARK TRACKS

"It is good to see interest by Beau desert people in Lamington Nation al Park tracks; but wnen Unas. J. Payne submits matter lor pub-

lication, as appeared in the Beau desert "Times" of July 2d, it is difficult to know whether to be amused by iiis fabrication of in accuracies, or insulted by his in sinuations. In this instance 1 am much amused," writes Mr. Arthur , Groom, of Binna Burra. Mr. Groom adds: Mr. Payne elects to tell the people why Binna-Burra "en- Joyed the use of more walking tracks;." and resorts to compansion between Binna-Burra and O'Reillys, and com ment on the Sub-Department of For estry and Main Roads Commission. Companions are usua.ly odious, and comparers should know their subject. Both the O'Reilly and Binna-Burra organisations have battled for years towards an ideal of national service to the public. Mr. Payne's first quoted track dis tance is a big mistake. He claims the Bell-Bird track is six miies long. This place is on Binna-Burra private pro perty. The track is only three-quarter mile long, and every inch of it con structed by voluntary and paid Binna- Burra labour. Hereunder, I give some of the correct history. Prior to 1933, Binna-Burra did not exits as a tourist centre, and the only graded track in existence was a short length of half a mile constructed as an experiment under the supervision of Mr. R, W. Lahey, many years before. I do not think Mr. Payne knows the location of this trackl In March, 1934. Queensland Holiday Resorts Ltd., (the small company controlling Binna- Burra), was registered with its tiny capital of £2,300, and a commitment to purchase private property for a sum in excess of £3,000. This property had no access whatever; and for some years maximum accommodation could be pro vided only in tents. However, mainly through the energy of Mr. R. W. Lahey. it was decided by the Binna-Burra directors to Introduce Into the Lam- ' ington National Park, a graded and constructed type of walking track which would aliow elderly people and convalescents to appreciate the scenery. Air. Lahey and others did an incred ible amount of voluntary work in thus founding a movement and type of track wnich Is now standard in several of Queensland's National Parks. This fact has never been "shouted from the rooftops." Paid and voluntary labour were used. Mr. Payne declares that the Main Roads Commission "favoured Binna- Burra with a good gravel road;" but he omits to exp.ain that Binna-Burra surveyed and built the first road three miles over very difficult country with several large and long rock cuttings; nor does he explain that cars can drive into O'Reilly's now, and Binna- Burra still has no road to the summit. Nor does he point out that this road and track work by Binna-Burra ate up £1,100 of the tiny capital resorces avail able, almost putting the company into liquidation time after time. Air. Payne d.d not state that Binna- Burra from its inception, ran and guaranteed a car service from Binna- Burra to Brisbane on a registered time table and fare, and faced a loss of £309 in its first year of operation. No wonder a gravel road was built! Mr. Payne has not explained that Binna-Burra build all graded tracks from the lodge to the park boundary; constructed the graded track to within one third of a mile of the Coomera Falls, down to the Gwongoorool Swim ming Pool, out to the head of Nixon's Creek, one and a half miies of what is now the main track between Binna- Burra and O'Reilly's, most of the track to the Aboriginal Cooking cave (Kweebanl), and to other places — a total of just over 10 miles. He did not point out that Binna-Burra ran trial surveys and locations to a large net work of scenic spots on both "sides" of the Park; much of which was of great assistance in subsequent track construction. Mr. Payne apparently does not know that after all this foundation work an offer was made by the Forestry de partment to both Binna-Burra and ' O'Reiily's that further track construc tion be subsidized on a 50 per cent, basis. Binna-Burra accepted and con tinued with the work. It is not surprising then, that when the Forestry Department found it pos sible to finance and take over all fur ther track construction and mainten ance within the Lamington National Park, that Binna-Burra had a con siderable lead which it has maintained ever since. Mr. Payne has not pointed out how Air. R. W. Lahey, as a Dir ector of Binna-Burra, did all the early survey work on both "sides" of the Park until a departmental man was trained. He has not pointed out that the O'Reilly's might well have had more tracks had they constructed con necting tracks' across their private property, as was done at Binna-Burra. Air. Payne has forgotten to point out many things. He should brush up his general knowledge. Why refer to the O'Reilly area as Lamington Plat eau, -when it has been so long known as Robert's Plateau? Why remark on the change of a temporary name of Mount Roberts to that of Binna-Burra,

when O'Reilly's quite justifiably are changing the name of their area to Green Mountains? Why quote Curtis Falls as being within the Lamington National Park, when, as far as I know this beauty spot is still 'on Tamborine Mountain? Why call Orchid Bower, Orchard Bower? and Araucaria Lookout as Aur- encarla? Wagawn as Wagawun? Why suggest that Egg Rock is within the park and has a five mile graded track to it, when it really it well out of the park on private property, and has no graded track anywhere near it? Why call Gwongoorool as Wangarool? Why divide the Lamington National Park into "sides" at all.

Mr, Payne attempts to cleave a way through a glorious area which in no way belongs to the O'Relliy or Binna- Burra organisations, but to the people of Queensland. I can understand iair enthusiasm in anyone concerning the Lamington National Park and the people who have pioneered tourist traffic within it; but I suggest that Air. Payne should begin entirely anew in his study of the history of the Lam ington National Park, and of the pion eering stories behind the O'Reilly and Binna-Burra organisations; and when he has spent 19 hard years at It, as I have, he m.ght accomp.ish something worth-while in the way of helpful ad vice and criticism. In his comparison of mileages, Atr. Payne declares Binna-Burra has 60 miles of graded track, and O'Reilly's 30 miles. The official list I have be fore me gives three zones. That based on O'Reilly's as 31 miles of graded, track construction; that based on Hlinbah to westward and until just recently in disuse as 5 miles, and that based on Binna-Burra as 475 ( Mr. Payne also has omitted to point out that for some years past, Binna-Burra has opened up trial tracks and viewpoints well down the southern end of the National Park from Echo Point, over Worendo, Wupawn, Throakban, and out to the end of Widgee; ancl that this work will be of great assistance in future graded track construction, which, geographic ally will be far more accessible to O'Reilly's than to Binna-Burra. I trust Mr. Payne and other readers do not think my reply Is a criticism of the O'Reilly effort. Binna-Burra does not lose sight of the fact that the O'Reilly family met obstacles and hard-

ships and disappointments which would have cracked the average person time and again. However, it is good to see and hear Beaudesert people talk of National Park development: but rather than listen to criticism which can only split the whole glorious area into oppos ition ' camps, would it not be much better for these enthusiasts to pause awhile and survey as one unit the scenic rim of mountains running from Cunningham's Gap (also a National Park) to Sprlngbrook (where ..there Is still another important National Park) ? And would it not be more -national In spirit to work for the creation of' one large National Park for all this area? What better war memorial? Do the Beaudesert people know that Brit-

ain is spending £50,000,000 in a similar movement to honour their war dead only by close co-operation throughout the whole of the settled areas of Boonah, Tamborine, Rathdowney, Ca nungra, Beaudesert, and Beechmont, can such a grand gesture be made pos sible here

THE A.C.F. HUT r

Blunck's Garage asked the Beaudes ert Shire Council at its ' meeting, on Tuesday to consider allowing them to leave the A.C.F. building in Beaudesert in its present position for six to twelve

montns untax tne position naa easea sufficiently to enable them to erect a first class building. Approval would tide them over a very difficult time in re gard to floor space. They would use every endeavour to extend their own building at The earliest possible mo ment so that the building In William Street might be removed with as little delay as possible. It was decided to allow the building to remain and the

articleText:
THE WRONG EMERGENCY?

Two selectors of the Beaudesert and District Rugby League asked the Management Committee of the league why F. Callanan had taken

the field with Beaudesert against Wynnum, when a forward had been hurt. ' Nobody was able to answer the question, and the selectors stated that they had chosen K. Geiger as first emergency in the forwards. It was suggested that F. Callanan had been made first emergency be cause lie was shown to be so in the official programme. The correctness of this was ques tioned. (The official list of players sup plied to the "Times" gives F. Cal- lanan's name ahead of that of K. Geiger, and consequently the "Times" printed the names in this order) .
